PETITION.TITLE: X-rated and Violent Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:
The Petition of citizens of Australia points out:

that all State Governments, State Attorneys-General, most womens' groups and the majority of men in Australia, including significant numbers of Members of Parliament, are totally opposed to the importation and distribution of `X' and excessively violent `R'-rated video pornography in Australia.
that most `X'-rated material available in Australia is imported.
that the Federal Government, by its Customs power under the Constitution, and not the A.C.T. Government, is solely responsible for controlling the importation of this pornographic material.
that by continuing to allow the importation of such pornographic material, the Federal Government is neglecting its responsibility to the women, children, and families of Australia.
Your petitioners, therefore, request the Senate to:
1. Ban `X'-rated pornographic material at the point of entry into Australia.
2. Exclude from the `R'-rated all gratuitously violent material.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Patterson (from 2,025 citizens), Vanstone (from 365 citizens) and Watson (from 100 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Community Services and Health Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and the members of the Senate. We the undersigned oppose changes to general medical practice contained in the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Act. We believe there should not be two levels of Medicare rebates for general practice. We also believe there should be upgraded undergraduate training and postgraduate training for general practitioners to obtain appropriate skills. Current and proposed Medicare rebates for general practitioner services are inadequate, and there should be appropriate Medicare rebates for doctors who provide out of hours consultations.
Therefore we humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will support general practitioners to achieve the above.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469, 274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Privacy Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
The Hawke Labor Government's Privacy Amendment Bill concerning Credit Reference Reporting will

(1) prohibit many legitimate uses of credit information by organisations such as real estate agents, mortgage underwriters, insurance companies, businesses selling goods on credit, and companies renting or leasing goods and equipment
(2) add to the cost of business and increase interest rates, and insurance charges and lead to over commitment by borrowers
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
Reject Labor Government's Privacy Amendment Bill to enable businesses to have access to credit information they require to make sensible commercial decisions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray:

PETITION.TITLE: Australian National Botanic Gardens, Education Unit: Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Government's decision to abolish the Education Unit of the National Botanic Gardens is a betrayal of the Federal Government's professed commitment to conservation, protection and management of Australia's unique flora. The Education Unit fulfilled an important role in increasing the knowledge, appreciation and enjoyment of Australia's plant heritage of visitors to the National Botanic Gardens, including many school children.

Therefore your petitioners request that the Senate require the Government to recognise the importance of the work carried out by the Education Unit and reverse its decision to withdraw funding for the Unit.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1989SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 4 December.
SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1989

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989. Senator Powell has moved amendments Nos 7, 8 and 9 together. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the interruption of this debate last night, which took place in order for the chamber to debate its own procedures-I would like to put it on the record that the debate resulted in conscience votes, which are not available to members of the Government and the Opposition on this legislation-we were considering the amendments of the Australian Democrats. We believe that the terminology surrounding the information that needs to be provided should be changed and that the words `information that might be relevant' ought to be changed to `information that is relevant'. Senator Calvert, on behalf of the Opposition, has responded to these amendments by saying that the Opposition opposes welfare fraud. He also said that he did not quite understand what the Democrats' position was. I respond to that by saying that we also oppose welfare fraud, but we do not take the view that everybody on welfare is fraudulent and defrauding the system. We also oppose tax fraud, of course-fraud in all its forms-but we do not assume that fraud on behalf of all welfare recipients. One of our major concerns with this, and many other aspects of the social security legislation, particularly in recent times, is that the assumption of fraudulent approach is made so often.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Calvert also said that the Opposition was not supporting this series of Australian Democrat amendments relating to the assessment of de facto relationships because the Opposition accepts the Government's position that we must not disadvantage people who are married by comparison with those who are unmarried. I want to reiterate the points I made in my speech on the second reading for which I used Alison McClelland's paper for the Australian Council of Social Service about the value of parenting. I am very much afraid, and this is the reason for the amendments in this section, that we are in fact discriminating between different kinds of parents.

The exhortation for us to continue to value parenting in our community needs to be put again and again, in particular in relation to that group of parents who are performing that task on their own without a partner. The majority of that group are women. We believe that support for parenting as a valuable contribution, socially and economically, in our community is at risk. If we accept some kind of economic argument that we can save money by making sure that people do not get on to benefits of one kind or another, if we allow one group of parents to be discriminated against, the whole concept of support for parenting is at risk.

I reiterate the point I made: if we are talking about the difference between married couples and unmarried people, there is no expectation in our community, as Alison McClelland has said, that in two-parent families both parents should work. There is no expectation of that kind at all. The fact is that in many families both parents work but it is not part of our total community expectation. Increasingly-in this piece of legislation specifically-we come to the position that for a sole parent the goal must be that that person goes to work. That expectation is put on that group of parents. To our minds, and I would be interested to hear Senator Calvert's response, that actually discriminates very markedly against that group of parents vis-a-vis the other group of parents who are parenting jointly rather than singly.

These are amongst the reasons why we have moved this group of amendments and other amendments in this section of the legislation. We do not accept the basic premise that fraud is what is in the minds of people who are on benefits and that therefore we must have draconian legislation which ensures that the tax dollar is not misused or abused. In fact, those people who do qualify for benefits, either before this legislation is passed or again afterwards, have to meet a most stringent set of requirements. The benefits they receive are really very much at subsistence level.

The issue of fraud is a major feature in this part of the legislation. I think it is very important to note, particularly in the context of these amendments, that, as the Government's amendment stands, the discretionary clause refers to `information that might be relevant'. When one is talking about information that might be relevant in the context of applicants being seen as potentially fraudulent, we think it is important that the clause be changed to refer to `information that is relevant'. The vast majority of people who are making these applications are not, in our view, wanting to rip off the system and intending to be fraudulent. Some of them may be people who are needing to be fraudulent, and that is perhaps another issue. People on sole parent benefits are being gaoled as a result of a range of circumstances which have meant that they have been overpaid; they have needed extra money above the benefits they have been able to get under our system.

I want to point to some examples of the sorts of people we are talking about. I have taken these examples from the book by Jenny Trethewey called Aussie Battlers. I mention three people who have made application for this very benefit and who, we are afraid, if these words are not changed, in the circumstances of this legislation may have had some problems in qualifying. These examples demonstrate the sorts of people we are dealing with in these amendments. For one thing there is this myth that women applying for the sole parent pension are doing it to get on some sort of gravy train-young girls who have got themselves pregnant in order to get on to the Government payroll. Lyn Thomas is one of the people in Jenny Trethewey's book. By the way, this book is based on a study where families were looked at for a whole year, kept a diary for two weeks of every month, and were interviewed monthly by the researchers. Lyn Thomas's marriage broke up in 1985, and she says:
My husband was a foolish spender and ran up debts. The electricity and phone were cut off when he didn't pay the bills. I am relieved to be in control.

Her weekly income was 67c below the poverty line. I note that this research study was done before the introduction of the family package, but she is the sort of person who has not been benefited to the extent of many other families under that package. She had to rely on family and friends to give gifts of money and clothes and to take the children for holidays because she could not afford it on her own income. She had left school early and so decided to go back to study but had enormous problems both with transport and with trying to pay for books for study. As the study progressed through the year it was apparent that friends and family gave gifts of money and clothes so that the children could have a better life than they would have on the benefit she was able to qualify for. She was paying a very high level of rent-between a quarter and a half of her income-and she could not get a housing ministry house. She did get an interview and was put on a two-year waiting list.

The point I want to make about this woman relates to her attempt to get herself into the work force. She did not need the sort of direction of policy that is being put forward by the Government and the Opposition. As I pointed out in my speech on the second reading, there is a strong self-motivation which results in sole parents being on the benefit for an average of only some 15 or 16 months. This is her final comment in the study:
I think staying at home with the children is important. They need me, but in five years time I hope to have nearly finished uni and to be on my way to a successful career.
Her children were aged four years and two years at the time of the study. Her hope was that her time of dependence would be short.

That story is repeated in one way or another throughout this book. Jenny Lloyd is another woman who left her marriage because it was a financial disaster, with her husband gambling, drinking and never paying the bills. The marriage ended in anger and violence. Again, this woman said that she felt well off on a pension which in fact began with her being $26 below the poverty line. She also began to study, at the same time not being able to afford new summer clothes or shoes for her children and wishing that she could have one night a week free, having no-one else to share the parenting, and being grateful that her children were young enough not to notice that their clothes came from the opportunity shop. Her children were aged six years, four years and two years. They did have a ministry of housing house, which was helpful, but because of the location of the home she had high transport costs. She needed a car, but when she used it, she had trouble buying the petrol. Her final comments in this study are:
The children need me at home but I'd like a part time job because I'd feel better if I contributed some money myself rather than having it given to me.
The book goes on to say that she felt pessimistic about her job prospects. She says:
I've been out of the work force for so long and I have children. I doubt if they'll give me a job because I have kids, the same as when you're looking for a house.

Those are just two of the stories in this book. We believe in moving these amendments and proposing to move further amendments that it is important to look at the reality of the lives of the vast majority of people who are making these applications and who are having to provide information. In the case of applications for the sole parent pension, under the criteria for determining de facto relationships in this legislation, we believe that much of the information which will have to be provided-let us not forget that the trigger here is for an applicant to have resided in a shared residence with a person of the opposite sex for a period longer than eight weeks and that information on a number of other criteria has to be delivered-will relate to people with whom the applicant does not have a particularly intimate relationship. To us the 14 days clause is not appropriate in that context. It could very well take considerably longer than 14 days for information to be provided about people with whom one does not have a particularly intimate relationship and, there, a call on that sort of information. So these three amendments take into account all those background aspects.

In commenting on the remarks of the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) last thing in this debate last night, we say that, while similar provisions to what the Government proposes in this Bill may exist in other contexts in social security legislation, we do not believe that they are appropriate in this case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (10) Page 13, clause 28, proposed paragraph 43a (4) (b), lines 7 and 8, leave out ``the claim will be taken not to have been lodged'', insert ``the claim may be rejected''.

This amendment relates to one of the aspects of this legislation which has been commented on by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, which is of particular concern to us. Clause 28, proposed new paragraph 43a (4) (b) states that, when a determination is made and `information is not given to the Secretary within 14 days after the notice is given, the claim will be taken not to have been lodged'. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee said that it believed that deeming an application that has been submitted as not having been lodged is likely to make it more difficult for applicants to obtain benefits. We are concerned about this terminology particularly from the point of view of the right of appeal for those people who have lodged applications but have been deemed not to have lodged them. It is a question of when an application is not an application.

We are proposing that the words `the claim will be taken not to have been lodged' be replaced by the words `the claim may be rejected'. A rejection of the claim triggers the appeal procedures in the normal course of events. It seems to us totally unfair and quite anomalous to deem something not to have happened when it has happened. If an application has been made, an application has been made. We believe that this terminology, as it stands in the Bill, not only puts at risk appeal rights but also the opportunity for the payment of arrears under the current social security system where, once an appeal is successful, arrears are paid to the time when the application was lodged. If the application is deemed not to have been lodged we cannot see how there could be some right of appeal. The Minister might try in some way or the other to persuade us that there is, but what then is the situation in regard to the payment of arrears? We feel that it would be just to change these words so that if the application is deemed to be not appropriate, if the right information has not been given within 14 days, as this clause states, the Department simply rejects the claim rather than saying that the claim has never been made.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not be supporting this amendment of the Australian Democrats. Basically, we feel that the 14-day period is reasonable but we have given an undertaking that we will monitor how these provisions work and in government we will take action to remedy any defects that we find as a result of that monitoring. Similarly, we sought an assurance from the Minister that all these provisions would be administered in a fair and equitable manner, it is that administration that we will be monitoring.

—The Government does not accept the amendment. We ask the Committee to recognise that we are talking about an overall process which allows two contacts. At the first contact further information which is required from the applicant for a pension is requested, and at the second interview the applicant has to provide that information. We have not adopted the approach that has been suggested by Senator Powell because situations arise where a person who chooses not to provide that information, having had his claim rejected, can provide information at a subsequent Social Security Appeals Tribunal (SSAT) hearing. SPEECH.PARA: I was particularly disturbed by one of the reasons which the Minister for Consumer Affairs gave for not supporting our amendment in which we propose that for new applicants a rigid system should be in place. In amendment 19 the Australian Democrats seek to change a number of words in paragraph 43a (14) (b) of clause 28. I summarise by saying that we are concerned that the subsection as set out in the legislation is likely to set off a routine procedure of the Department sending out notices under the earlier clauses of the legislation requiring the pensioner to provide information to show that he or she is not in a de facto relationship on a regular 12-week basis. We would find it grossly unfair and intrusive were that group of pensioners to have to justify their position on a pension on such a constant basis. There are sickness benefits and invalid pensions for which recipients have a set of regular requirements to meet because eligibility for those pensions is based on diagnosis of the health and physical capacity of those pensioners and beneficiaries.

We see no reason why we should run the risk in legislation of having that kind of regular intrusion into people's lives in the case of the sole parent pension. Our proposed amendment would require the Secretary to the Department to have good cause before deciding to send out another notice within 12 weeks. Subparagraph (c) in the amendment would make a routine review permissible every year. We do not see an annual routine review as a problem. We simply would not want to see a review for this particular group on a quarterly basis.

Amendment 20 is quite long because it includes a number of consequential paragraphs. The effect of the amendment is to require continuation of payment where a review under section 43a (5) or (7) of a decision is sought within 14 days. A general discretion to continue payment applies currently when a review of any adverse decision is sought within three months. We welcome that. But we think that the general discretion should continue to apply to all adverse decisions, including those made under section 43a. Further, we feel that, because there are so many situations within which a pensioner or claimant could reasonably dispute issues relating to this legislation, it is important that the continuation of payment under the appeal provisions take place as a matter of course. We think that this amendment is particularly important to this part of the legislation which, I remind the chamber, we would prefer not to be dealing with anyway.

SPEECH.PARA: I can understand that some of the strongest words in this debate have come from Senator Bolkus on these amendments, because they are amendments which are based on an assumption that the people who, having gone through the process to this point, are receiving the pension and are entitled to it, not the assumption, which is coming from both sides of the chamber, that if women are on the pension they are probably ripping off the system so we had better set these automatic mechanisms in place to make sure that we are on their heels the whole time and make sure they do not shack up with someone and get that person to support them, and so rip off the taxpayers. These are the taxpayers at the top end of the scale who are having their tax rates decreased, and many of them at the executive level are getting vast salary increases. The motivation of these beneficiaries as we have seen, is that they want to use what the community provides-and increasingly less-by virtue of this and other legislation so they can parent their children, albeit on their own, for the necessary period of time while they, as many of them do, educate themselves and often relocate or repartner themselves.

I referred to some of the case studies in Jenny Treathewey's Aussie Battlers. This particular comment made by the Minister moves me to talk about Tania Parry who was keen to establish her independence when she left her marriage. She had no money in that marriage and the husband provided no money for clothes for the children and so on. She felt she was better off when she left the marriage even though, as with many others in these case studies, her income was quite minimal. She got some maintenance from her former husband on a sporadic basis, but this was before the child support scheme, which has been a major contributor in these situations where the former spouse can be found but has no money. In the case of Tania Parry, amongst the support group around her-a support group which, as I outlined before in some of the other cases, includes friends, parents, grandparents, and family generally-is a person referred to in this case study as Tania's boyfriend who helped with the amount spent on food by taking the family out to eat for meals. He loaned her $50 in one month in which she was having trouble meeting the rent payments because her small amount of maintenance had not come and, when Tania decided that she must buy a home because she wanted to be in the mainstream of home ownership for her family, he paid a $200 holding fee when she was liaising with the Minister for Housing for a loan. He later lent her $1,500 to cover solicitors' fees. During this process, in the interviews in this case study, Tania makes the point:
I don't mind him making it possible for us to get out of the flat a bit. He offered to set us up in a flat. I knocked him back because I won't be beholden to him.

This is a woman expressing her desire to be independent. The view is expressed in the end of the case study that, having gone through a whole process of purchasing a house, relocating and finding it unsatisfactory and then moving back to the city, she saw that the long-term, future security of her family lay in her finding full-time work and entering into a new relationship with someone who could help her support the family. When I read that, I thought that she had better form that new relationship in under eight weeks.

The whole process of the redevelopment of relationships and repartnering is a very fraught process for those kinds of women in particular, who are bringing up children on their own on very low incomes. It often begins as it did in this case, with the woman actually wishing to establish her own independence. It can be part of the goal for the future, as expressed in this case. Assuming that if that kind of repartnering does take place the Department of Social Security will not be notified is to assume the worst of people who are on sole parent pensions, rather than assuming the best or taking even some kind of average approach to their right and expectation of some kind of financial support from the community as they bring up their children. As far as amendment No. 20 is concerned-and I concede Senator Bolkus's point in part-we are attempting this change because we believe that the process which has been set up to this point in this clause of the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989 is wrong. It discriminates against sole parent pensioners, or applicants for the sole parent pension. Because of that fact, we are moving an amendment, quite openly, which if passed would actually place those people in a better position with regard to appeal mechanisms. We do that because we believe that by virtue of this legislation and by virtue of the attitude taken towards those people in the community-which is fostered by our political leaders; our Government and our alternative government, regrettably-they need the extra consideration which this amendment would give them. I conclude my remarks on this amendment and on that point by quoting from a paper by a sole parent in which she concludes by saying:
These two problems-inadequate levels of basic income support, and traps which lock sole parents into poverty when they undertake paid work-are difficult enough.

The exploitation of these women in the work force is as a result of the whole thrust of the labour market orientation of government policy which is pushing women who are mothers on their own into the work force in a way that does not happen if they have a partner. I have made the point several times that that is difficult enough. I also make the point that most of them wish to be independent, but are conscious of the needs of their children to have a parent there for them. This has been expressed several times in the case studies that I have quoted. This paper goes on to say:

When social isolation, and prejudice and antagonism from the community are added to, the lives of sole parents and their children become not only impoverished but alienated. The Government also needs to take action in this third area: instead of following, or even aggravating, negative community attitudes through its policies-
I interpolate, through this piece of legislation-
it should be leading public opinion towards a more rational and supportive understanding of one-parent families.
That is what we are trying to do in these two amendments in particular.

These amendments relate to the direct payment of social security benefits and pensions into banks. This system was put in place several years ago by the Government. It has been possible-if one can argue the case sufficiently-for a person to have an exemption and receive payments directly, but the vast majority of payments have been paid directly into the banks. There has always been a question mark over whether the Government actually had the power to do this on a compulsory basis. The Government has now decided-or discovered; I am not sure which-that it did not have the legislative base to have been doing this all these years, and this legislation provides that legislative base.

We wish to move an amendment to clause 48 in order that this payment might be made compulsorily only if it does not cause financial hardship or detriment to the pensioner or beneficiary. That is the subject of amendment No. 21. During the time these payments have been paid directly into the banks, the banks have engaged in the process of automatic, if you like, garnisheeing of the funds of pensioners and beneficiaries wherever there has been some overpayment and, therefore, some debt owing to the bank as a result of overspending, at least on the surface, by the pensioner or beneficiary. It is the sort of process that takes place in the normal course of events between banks and their customers but one which many of us have been concerned about in regard to pension and benefit payments. We have taken the view that under the Act those payments are absolutely inalienable and, therefore, ought not to be available to banks in order to fix up the arrangement they have between them and their pensioner customers. We have also been concerned that this garnishee approach has been taken without the need for the bank to prove the debt that it says is owed to it by the pensioner or beneficiary and, therefore, to use pension or benefit money for the purposes of balancing its accounts.

That leads me to the second of this pair of the amendments, amendment No. 22, which seeks to add a subsection to ensure that a pensioner who wishes to change the nominated account into which his pension is paid must do so within seven days of the next payment being due. We want to put that new subsection into the Bill because one of the defences that pensioners have against a garnishee by their current financial institution is to ensure that their next payment does not go to that institution. We want to ensure that there is no possibility for collusion between the Government and the banks-and, goodness knows, we see enough of that going on around the place. The banks have a very favourable position under this Government. Indeed, they get buckets of money whenever they ask for it.

We want to see that the interests of pensioners and beneficiaries in this situation are met, especially as the banks have no responsibility to prove their claim that a debt is owed. This would give the pensioner or beneficiary an opportunity to maintain his or her pension payments while pursuing the matter with the bank. Both of these amendments are put in the context of compulsory payments being made, now with a legislative base, but in the interests of protecting those payments which we think are inalienable anyhow, under the Act.

Before I discuss the substance of these amendments I would like to say that there are a number of aspects of the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989 which the Australian Democrats are pleased with. Several of those relate to the extension of eligibility for homeless person's allowance, the provisions for payment for the spouses of deceased pensioners and a number of other areas of that nature. This Bill also includes the increased indexation provisions which have been pursued by the Government in the Budget and during this year in general. The earnings credit applies to pensioners, but not to other beneficiaries, and there are a number of other issues that one should note.

Nevertheless, the Democrats have other areas of extreme concern. The first of these is embodied in the first six amendments. They relate to the initial change, and the consequent changes throughout the Bill, to the definition of a dependent child. We are concerned about the exclusion of a child who earns $100 per week from this definition of a dependent child. We are concerned about this because, amongst other things, it is expressed in terms of weekly income. In social security legislation generally, the whole question of assessment of income is fraught legislatively and administratively-particularly administratively. We think that to insert a weekly income figure here will make the situation much worse. In particular, it will make it worse and inappropriate for a particular group of people. The effect of this is that a child who earns $100 a week is now no longer considered to be a dependent child. The consequent effect on the family is that it is now no longer eligible for family allowance payment in respect of that child. The child that we are talking about here is a 15-year-old child who is not a full-time student, because the provision does not relate to full-time students.

The removal of eligibility for the family allowance would mean, to a family at the top level of income where eligibility for family allowance applies, a loss of $9 a week if the child has earned $100. Basically, that family is $91 better off. However, again I stress that we are looking at a provision which will definitely affect sole parent families much more significantly than other families. If a 15-year-old child earns $100 at the award rate of $3.38 an hour, that child has to have worked 33 hours in the week to earn $100. If that child resides in a single parent household, $65 goes from that household's income. In other words, that 15-year-old child is working a minimum of 33 hours a week for $35.

The Government says that this provision will save $11m in a year. I point out to the Committee that that $11m will come from households comprising a single mother and a child of 15 who is working for 33 hours a week in order to earn $100, and $65 is going into that household from the child working to substitute for the $65 which was previously going to that household from payment of the pension and various other allowances such as mother's guardians allowance and the child payment rent allowance. We have used the figure of a pensioner who is eligible for full rent allowance in determining our figures in this instance. That is the case with a family on maximum benefit income. Another $20 could be taken off that figure.

Low income working families, on our calculations, would suffer a loss of some $43; so a child from that family would be working a 33 hour week for $57. This does not leave us with a very nice taste in our mouths. It might be nice for the Government and the Opposition to say in the next election campaign, `We have cut welfare to the bone'. We know the Government has cut welfare to the bone. It is putting out less in welfare payments than the Fraser Government did. We know that it has targeted particular areas and there are poverty traps as a consequence.

It is really important to us that we do not save taxpayers' money in this way, by having a 15-year-old child going out to work for 33 hours a week, actually receiving $35, in his or her hand and the remainder going to compensate for the payments that are lost. The other consequence of course is that another woman is not receiving a sole parent's pension and is not getting a payment for being a parent-something that we are supposed to value. The Government and the Opposition will be saying during the election campaign, `Motherhood, motherhood, motherhood' unfortunately much more than they will say, `Parenthood, parenthood, parenthood'. They will say that they believe in parenting, that it is good and that the institution of the family is wonderful. But it has got to be the right kind of family, otherwise if a 15-year-old child goes out to work and brings in $100 the sole parent will go onto the unemployment benefit. The mother will go into that wonderful labour market which is problematic for women, particularly women of the age that a woman with a 15-year-old child would be. Look out if she happens to live in the country, her child is earning money by fruit picking and there is no job there for her. The Democrats believe that this has a very Dickensian flavour. We are not happy about saving the taxpayers' money if a 15-year-old child has to go out to work for 33 hours a week for a net gain in the household of $35 between that child and its mother.

Hence we move this series of amendments. We do not see how this legislation fits with the social justice approach proposed by the Government or with the family support approach proposed by the Opposition. All our amendments ask is that we put an annual figure into the legislation. We accept that if a child goes out to work full time we are not sure what the figure is. Because it is a weekly figure we do not know whether we are talking about full-time employment. We want to put an annual figure into the legislation to ensure that at least the current administration of income testing which applies in the social security system can be applied here also. We would prefer not to see it happen at all because it impacts on a very small number of people. It seems to us that this is part of a goal that seems to be abroad virtually to eliminate payment of sole parent pensions as far as possible and to make sure that as few people as possible can receive the sole parent pension, again something that runs counter to all that we say we believe in about the value of parenting in this community.

For example, almost 50 per cent of the 38 new Commonwealth Employment Service offices opened since 1983 have been in non-metropolitan locations.
—Rah, rah, rah.
—Well, Senator Lewis, it is very nice for you, as a city-based senator, to say rah, rah, rah.
—Order! There are too many interjections. Senator Reynolds, would you address the Chair and ignore the interjections.

—Mr President, I get rather annoyed when I hear the derision of people on the other side of this chamber when I am talking about matters of great concern and significance to 33-1/3 per cent of Australians. That is how many Australians live outside metropolitan areas. Members on the other side of the chamber might not find it particularly interesting; they may not be particularly concerned, but the Hawke Government is committed to rural and regional Australians. As I was saying, over 50 per cent of the 56 new Social Security Department offices opened since 1983 have been outside capital cities. In addition an increasing number of those offices are collocating with the Commonwealth Employment Service. An overwhelming majority of the Skillshare programs are operating outside metropolitan areas. Departments such as Social Security maintain a very decentralised network of outreach services, including a special unit to examine the special needs of rural women. On that note I will very quickly, Mr President, with your patience and that of my colleagues on the other side of the chamber--

—It must be the Christmas spirit. I would like to indicate to the Senate that part of the statement that was made in Warragul on Friday was a response to the report of the Country Women's Association of Australia, Life Has Never Been Easy. Honourable senators will know that the Country Women's Association, in conjunction with the Office of the Status of Women, initiated a major survey--
—And road funding was a major issue.

—Road funding was certainly a major issue. I am very well aware of that, as are the councils I talk to. One of the major concerns of rural women was access to services and information. I will detail very quickly some of the major initiatives that will benefit rural women: $4.5m to provide support for long term carers of disabled people in rural areas; a $3.4m rural women's health strategy incorporating funding of mobile breast cancer screening units. That program is part of our pilot initiative. It has been very successful and will be extended. We are also looking at improved family planning services, and a number of honourable senators would have heard the announcement by Dr Blewett in relation to utilising the services of the Flying Doctor Service in family planning initiatives. We are also very concerned to provide better information and counselling--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. If Senator Reynolds wishes to make a ministerial statement about the Hawke Government's inadequate response to the problems of rural Australia we would be happy to debate it. To use Question Time as a method of putting down a statement of this sort is an abuse of Question Time. You have attempted on a number of occasions to draw Ministers' attention to the fact that they are abusing Question Time with the nature of the answers they are giving, and I invite you to extend to Senator Reynolds the same strictures which you have attempted to give to other Ministers in the hope that she at least might be prepared to listen to them.

—Order! Whilst there is no point of order, I point out to Senator Reynolds that this is the second answer from a Minister today that has gone well over five minutes. I would hope that it is not a trend that continues.

—I am sorry if my answer has been a little lengthy. Because of my enthusiasm to detail the initiatives relating to the provision of services for rural Australia I have gone over time. I have nothing further to add.

—Mr President, my question, which is directed to you, relates to a question I asked on 20 December last year regarding the energy used in Parliament House, especially for lighting and air-conditioning. I further asked you whether an energy audit for Parliament House had been prepared, together with the identification of ways in which energy could be conserved. Given that 12 months has now elapsed, has such an audit and identification of areas of saving now been carried out? In your written reply the next day you indicated that the cost of electricity for Parliament House was running at approximately a quarter of a million dollars per month. In view of the reply of the Minister for Local Government a moment ago, it is interesting to note that $3m a year compares with some of the figures that she has just given us on spending in the women's area. Every night when I pass or visit Parliament House I notice that most of the offices are unoccupied and ablaze with light.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. A question has been asked and the honourable senator is going on to make a statement. Mr President, I ask you to draw the honourable senator to order and get him to complete the question which he is asking.
—Order! I ask Senator Coulter to ask his question.

—Thank you, Mr President. Observing that Parliament House is ablaze with light all night, would you confer with the Speaker of the House of Representatives to see whether all unnecessary lights could be turned off at night and could you provide an assessment of how much electricity this might save?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —By way of background, I advise that the management of energy costs in the building is largely dependent on the building monitoring system (BMS), which is operated by the engineering services section of the Joint House Department. In my response of 21 December last year to a question from Senator Coulter about this matter, I advised that the BMS was due to be operational in late January 1989; the BMS being an essential prerequisite either to energy management or to an energy audit. The BMS did not become operational for lighting until March 1989 and for air-conditioning and other services until August 1989.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Joint House Department has been addressing the question of energy management since it accepted responsibility for maintenance. With the agreement of the other parliamentary departments, operating hours of lights in areas such as corridors, committee rooms, chambers, the members, hall and public spaces have been progressively rationalised and reduced since 16 March 1989. An extensive program of recommissioning and balancing of air-conditioning and ventilation systems has been undertaken and this has enabled a more cost-effective use of the systems. The use of the BMS has enabled further savings by the lowering of maximum demand during peak energy charge periods. The above initiatives have so far resulted in a 9.4 per cent reduction in electricity consumption for the spring of 1989 compared with the spring of last year. Programs to reduce consumption during the forthcoming summer and winter months are in hand. The Department has advised that the conduct of an energy audit has been dependent upon the full implementation of the BMS and the proper working and balancing of air-conditioning and ventilation systems. An audit is planned during the latter part of 1990. In the meantime the Department will continue to refine and streamline existing energy saving measures.

With regard to office lighting, in the main, the Department does not have any centralised control mechanisms. The lighting design provides for individual occupant control in most instances. Some reduction in lighting has been achieved by occupants turning off lights when leaving and by attendants turning off lights in unoccupied areas during recess periods. Further savings can be achieved with the cooperation of all occupants of the building.

While there are no mechanisms which separately identify the consumption of electricity on lighting, based on approximate data relating to the total lighting capacity of the building, the Department estimates that savings in excess of $100,000 per annum have been achieved so far. With the continuation of present measures and the cooperation of building occupants we believe that this figure can be doubled. Honourable senators can be assured that I fully support the Department's initiatives in the area of energy conservation and I urge senators and other users of the building to help conserve energy by turning off lights whenever possible, particularly when leaving in the evenings.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to last Thursday's Australian Financial Review which reported the world competitive manufacturing survey and showed the practical steps that have been taken at the company level to help Australian industry improve its international competitiveness and productivity. What further action does the Commonwealth Government now intend to take to encourage firms to become more efficient and productive?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been a few questions this week about this matter of productivity.
—You thought you would get this DD up, did you?

—Yes, that is right. A sophisticated person like Senator Lewis should not be surprised about that. The point that has been made is that many external factors affect the international competitiveness of firms, such as exchange rates, tariffs and transport, and the Government will continue to address these issues.

ANSWER.PARA: But in answer to a question asked by Senator Chaney, I think a week or so ago, I referred to the importance of performance at the firm level. In answering Senator Maguire's question I just want to say something about that because management and work practices and other things are vital to performance at the firm level. The Government, in partnership with both the State and Territory governments, introduced a program three years ago to provide private sector management skills to a variety of firms that were perceived as being in need of that consultancy assistance. The national industry extension service is such a program and that program helps firms to make use of the array of private sector and government organisations with resources that can benefit the international competitiveness of firms. Of particular importance are the enterprise improvement programs to help firms develop skills in strategic and business planning, marketing, manufacturing operations, innovation and design, and quality.

The article in the Australian Financial Review, to which the honourable senator referred, emphasised that of most importance is sound strategic planning. In this area the national industry extension service developed the world competitive manufacturing approach so that firms can develop strategic plans to sustain expansion in domestic and export markets. More than 200 firms, represented by over 1,600 senior managers, have now participated in workshops relating to world competitive manufacturing and 160 consultants have been trained and licensed to deliver the program.

Right now a model program for the implementation of total quality management in firms `How to Approach Management for Improvement' is being developed by private sector experts. This is not just a matter of the quality of the end product; it is how well a company manages its operations and the production line. Further improvements will be made on the basis of advice from the private sector and elsewhere on these needs of firms. In this process the Commonwealth will play a key role in coordinating the advisory mechanisms and developing new services. I must emphasise that this is a collaborative arrangement between State and Federal governments in which all governments are agreed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and Minister for Industrial Relations, also concerns the leaked New South Wales Labor Council report which the Minister yesterday attempted to dismiss. We now learn that the Prime Minister has personally intervened indicating the depth of the Government's embarrassment. I ask the Minister whether he agrees with the report's comment, in relation to the claimed success of the accord in achieving higher employment levels:

QUESTION.PARA: Many workers no doubt resent the fact that they or their spouses have to take second or part-time (often low paid) jobs to keep up with inflation and ballooning interest rates.

Can the Minister understand the majority public rejection of the accord revealed in recent opinion polls, when the main boast the Government makes about it is a direct result of depressed real wages and high interest rates forcing thousands of people to obtain additional jobs in an attempt to make ends meet?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I might say so, I am disposed to elaborate in a moment upon how confused that question is. Let me first say, lest this excitement over the Prime Minister's alleged actions be pursued in Question Time, that Senator Chaney asked me about this and I am advised that the Prime Minister did not phone Mr Easson as suggested by both Senator Chaney and Senator Reid. The Prime Minister was phoned by Mr Easson, who made numerous efforts to get in touch with him, the Prime Minister being in Victoria at the time. Mr Easson phoned the Prime Minister to express his regrets concerning the accuracy of those statements which were made. The point which I seek to make is simply that these two questions are very much dependent on the allegation that the Prime Minister phoned Mr Easson and sought some sort of retraction or apology from him. That is quite incorrect, and if Senator Chaney has farmed out further questions on this issue to other members of the Opposition, which is the normal procedure in the Opposition, then I suggest that the two neurons be rubbed together and that the questions be phrased differently for later in Question Time. That event did not happen.

ANSWER.PARA: In so far as Senator Reid's question followed on with some other comments allegedly made in the statement by the officers in the Labor Council of New South Wales--

TALK.START.PARA: —It was in the document.

—One never knows whether documents are accurately quoted here. I am not retreating from the substance of the issue; I propose to answer that. On the question of high interest rates being a product of the accord and people having to work because of high interest rates, these allegations were not made by the Opposition 12 or 18 months ago because interest rates were not nearly as high as they are now, and were not nearly as high as when the Opposition went out of government in 1982.

ANSWER.PARA: Employment growth in this country has been very steady throughout the period of this Government from 1984 to 1989. It is not a phenomenon of recent origin; it is a phenomenon which has been commented upon by many people overseas as one of the great achievements of this period of government in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at what has happened in that time.

—Senator Lewis keeps interjecting. The Opposition put 11 per cent of the population on the streets in 1982. People will not forget that. If Senator Lewis were familiar with the Budgets of the time, he would know that the Opposition was spending enormous sums as a government on unemployment benefits. The fact is that employment growth has been very steady under the life of this Government, and that is, in the Government's view, directly related to the accord, as the accord is directly related to the share of profits. There is deathly silence now on the other side of the chamber, but that is absolutely correct. So, if I may say so, Senator Reid's question, not surprisingly, displays a degree of confusion, as do all questions which have been written in Senator Chaney's office and handed out to people who do not understand them to ask at Question Time.

—Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware of evidence given to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade by Dr Paul Dibb of the Department of Defence last Friday? Is it true that Dr Dibb said that either the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) or China has been assisting North Korea in a possible nuclear weapons development? Would not such assistance from the Soviet Union constitute a breach of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT)? Does the Government believe that the USSR has broken the NPT in this way? If so, why does the Government hold this view? Does the Government believe that China has assisted North Korea with a nuclear weapons program? If so, why does the Government believe this? Has the Government made representations to either the Soviet Union or China concerning this matter? Will the Minister indicate the Government's assessment of North Korea's nuclear weapons potential at this time?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of what may have transpired in the Senate Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade last Friday. I will not say may I forever remain oblivious, but I will no doubt find out in due course. However, turning to the substance of the question, there have been numerous reports over the course of this year suggesting that North Korea is making efforts to construct a nuclear fuel cycle base from which a nuclear weapons program could be developed, with the possibility that a nuclear fuel reprocessing facility is being built near the existing reactor at Yongbyon, which is about 100 kilometres north of Pyongyang. Australia is concerned about these reports, especially as North Korea has failed to conclude the fullscope safeguards agreement with the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) required by its adherence to the International Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons in 1985. Such an agreement would allow international inspection of its nuclear facilities.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia is opposed, as the Senate well knows, to the proliferation of nuclear weapons, and we are strongly committed to the NPT. We have on a number of occasions, through direct contact, through other countries and in meetings this year of the IAEA board of governors, urged the North Koreans-the Democratic People's Republic of Korea-to conclude promptly their safeguards agreement with the IAEA, and we will continue to make every effort to convince the DPRK to do that at the earliest possible date.

We would certainly be very concerned if the Soviet Union and China-or, for that matter, any other state, whether or not a party to the NPT-were to assist North Korea or any other non-nuclear weapons state to develop nuclear weapons. I am not aware, however, of any evidence to suggest that the Soviet Union or China has assisted North Korea in this manner. If there were any suggestion, of course, that they were minded to do so, we would find opportunities to express very directly and vigorously our concern about just that.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES LABOR COUNCIL REPORT

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister and Minister for Industrial Relations whether he agrees with this conclusion in the New South Wales Labor Council report:

QUESTION.PARA: However, job growth of itself is meaningless as an indication of the success of the accord. The key issue is the type of job growth.

Is it not correct, as the report states, that growth in the key sectors of the economy required to produce high quality jobs has been slow or stagnant? Does the Minister share the concern of the authors of the report that a larger percentage of employment growth has been in the low paid sectors of the economy and that these jobs have moved from other advanced Western countries to low wage countries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first question I am asked to comment on is whether job growth is meaningless. The real question being put by Senator Panizza is whether it is the type of job which is important. I partly agree, although job growth is not meaningless for people who did not have jobs when the Opposition went out of office-not meaningless at all; it is very meaningful. Nonetheless, I agree to some extent that the type of job is important.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Panizza went on to ask whether job growth in those sectors which provide high quality jobs has been slow and stagnant and in other areas of less rewarding employment, both financially and in terms of job satisfaction, has been more dramatic. It is not possible to answer a question like that without looking at some sectors of the Australian economy. For example, there has been very high job growth in tourism. It is a matter of judgment whether those jobs are rewarding or not. Some people would take the view that they are less rewarding than other jobs; I do not know. That is a matter of judgment. I am sure that Senator Panizza would personally be in favour of job growth in the tourist industry because of its economic implications for the country as a whole, and there can be no cause for regret about job growth in that industry.

As far as other sectors of the economy are concerned, there has been a high job growth rate in the employment of engineers, scientists and research and development personnel of one kind or another. There has been job growth of some 200,000 in the manufacturing sector, something which never happened under the previous Liberal-National Party Government prior to 1982. Of course, the highest level of job growth has been in the services sector. The services sector embraces many things other than tourism, to which I have referred. It also embraces job growth in areas such as information industry technology, a whole range of financial industry occupations and so on. I would not have thought that they were jobs which had a low quality about them at all.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: RURAL COMMUNITIES: HEALTH AND WELFARE PACKAGE

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy inform the Senate of the details of the package of proposals affecting health and welfare in rural communities which was announced by the Prime Minister last week? Does this package involve some millions of dollars in Federal Government assistance to those rural communities? Can the Minister advise honourable senators whether any plans are being contemplated to abolish the programs under which this assistance has been given?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the uniquely two-hatted situation of representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and also the Minister for Community Services and Health in answering this question because both of those portfolios featured large in terms of the Prime Minister's--

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. Standing Order 99 provides that questions shall not ask `(b) for a statement of the Government's policy'. The question directed to Senator Cook was: what is a matter of Government policy; will he repeat Government policy; will he retail a statement that has been made by the Prime Minister in relation to Government policy? The Standing Order is specifically written: questions shall not ask for a statement of the Government's policy. That is the matter which has been directed to Senator Cook in the dorothy dix question handed out to Senator Burns. I suggest, Mr President, that in the enforcement of the Standing Orders, if the Minister for Resources-like Senator Reynolds-wants to make a statement about Government policy, let him make it; let us debate it. But it is not the appropriate vehicle in Question Time to ask the Minister simply to repeat the policy statement already made by the Prime Minister, attempt to editorialise it and to protect it from proper evaluation and debate in this chamber.

—The Minister was asked to make an explanation of Government policy. This is a form of asking questions which is allowed in here all the time. I will allow the question. I will again point out to the Minister that he should deal only with the items in his portfolio and take account of the number of questions that have been asked today.

—I will be guided by your indications, Mr President. I repeat that there is a happy coincidence between the interests of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and those of the Minister for Community Services and Health in terms of the Prime Minister's rural and regional statement. The last question that Senator Burns asked me was a question relating to whether there are any plans contemplated to abolish programs of assistance in country areas. Of course, the answer to that question is yes, there are plans contemplated to do that. The fact that those may never reach fruition is an edifying side of that conundrum. The plans are advanced under the guise of the document entitled Economic Action Plan, released by the Opposition, which purports to find savings in Government expenditure. One of the savings it purports to find is to cut the Countrylink service, a service provided by this Government to rural and regional communities, particularly those communities that do not have ready access to or availability of the range of Government services that might be available in the major metropolitan areas. It provides a one-stop shop for country people to become familiar with and be able to use the services offered by the Federal Government. It is the Countrylink plan which is one of the things that the Opposition, in its Economic Action Plan, proposes to cut out.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister stated last Friday that the Government intends to enhance that service to country people because we do not wish, as a government, to distinguish between or discriminate against people simply because of where they live in terms of their access to the services that this Government offers. As a consequence, the Prime Minister announced the rural and regional plan. Senator Reynolds has adequately canvassed many of the aspects of the Prime Minister's statement. I do not propose to repeat those aspects. The direction of this plan is to provide, as the Prime Minister has said, options, opportunities and access to information. This reflects our understanding of the effects on sparse populations of access to those services, of the narrower choices that befall country residents, of higher transport costs attending many of the services delivered, and of the substantial personal inconveniences that sometimes befall country people. We see as our role a need to bring those services more closely to them.

The context in which the Prime Minister made that statement is, of course, a background of major macro-economic reform in this country and, in particular, a successful and vigorous pursuit of micro-economic reform that has brought down tariffs and continues a program of tariff reduction that has caused Australia to lead the world in trying to open markets for rural products and unlock the doors of protected economies so that Australia, as a free trading nation, can enter there, be more competitive and win extra markets. It is in the context of an extra 1.6 million jobs created in Australia since we took office and of major restructuring.
The significant and final feature which I will touch upon to provide a complete answer to the question from Senator Burns is a paragraph from the Prime Minister's speech which states:

and, finally and importantly, there will be a review of the current system of tax zone rebates which provide relief to taxpayers in remote and isolated areas. This review will consider anomalies in zone boundaries and special zone rebate arrangements, as well as problems with social security testing arrangements affecting people in isolated areas.
This is a commitment from this Government to service the needs of regional and rural Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister representing the Prime Minister and Minister for Industrial Relations answer `true' or `false' to the following propositions contained in the New South Wales Labor Council report's analysis of the post-1987 election political and economic environment: first, `The bacon has clearly not been brought home'-true or false? Secondly, `Interest rates are sitting at 17 per cent and there is little likelihood of an imminent fall'-true or false?

—Clearly, Senator Ray does not like the question. It is getting a bit too close to the bone. The next question states, `Real incomes have fallen further'-true or false? Fourthly, `The foreign debt and trade deficit have worsened with no signs of an early recovery'-true or false? Fifthly, `Unemployment is set to rise on the back of the growth recession we are now moving into'-true of false? Sixthly, `Our international credit rating has been further cut'-true of false? And, finally, `The Government is clearly looking tired and strained'-true of false? If the Minister has any difficulty in answering `true' or `false' to any of these questions we would allow him to take refuge in the `don't know' category.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, if you will pardon me for a moment, I will have a look at the Government benches. No, they are not looking tired or depressed in any way. They look pretty good to me and, when I look back at this side, I see how really good they are. This is Question Time in the Senate, and Senator Lewis is not prosecuting drunks in the Warrnambool police court, which is what he did before he came here, no doubt. Question Time in the Senate is not a time when people ask a whole series of questions and get answers `true' or `false'.

ANSWER.PARA: But let me say a few things about the comments which have been made. First of all, I was asked whether the foreign debt has risen during the period of this Government. Yes, it has, so that is true. I was asked whether real incomes have fallen. Of course, that is false if we look at household disposable income in Australia, which we have to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is because the wives have had to go out to work.

—Senator Lewis says that is because the wives have had to go out to work. That is the most bunkum, conservative, ridiculous argument I have ever heard. It puts Senator Lewis firmly in the 1960s. Every now and again we get an interjection from the other side of the chamber which reveals the truth. The men sitting opposite-I do not know about the women; Senator Vanstone has gone home, I notice-see growth in female employment as some sort of dreadful thing whereby women are driven out to work by starving husbands. That is some of the most typical 1950s and 1960s bunkum I have ever heard. If we look at the growth in female participation rates right through the 1970s and 1980s we see what a lot of twaddle those opposite are talking by putting that sort of stuff up at Question Time in the Senate. That is the sort of rubbish that is being put up by people on the Opposition benches. All that reveals is what I have long suspected-that this Opposition has not yet recovered from the 1950s and 1960s.
—Back to the future.

—They have no view of the future. If they were ever to be in government in this country, the role model, ably reinforced by the National Party representatives from Queensland, would be the heyday of the 1960s. The Opposition really believes that nothing like this would happen in this country if Bob Menzies were still alive. That is what the Opposition really believes and what these questions indicate. I will not answer stupid questions like `Has the bacon been brought home?'. What a stupid question to put at Question Time in the Senate. It displays the quality of the Opposition when this sort of allegation is put seriously to a Minister at Question Time. I have answered the substance of most of the questions that have been put to me. I very much regret that Question Time is so abused by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. On 19 November 1987 did Senator Robert Ray give a commitment to the Senate that the Government would make a formal response to the recommendations of the Committee of Inquiry into Folklife in Australia? Was this commitment reaffirmed by the former Minister for the Arts and Territories when he released the report of the Committee for public comment in February 1988? How many responses to the request for public comment were received and did they generally support the recommendations? What response has the Government made to a proposal from the National Library of Australia for the Library to house a national folklife centre, the establishment of which was a key recommendation of the inquiry? Finally, does the Government resile from its commitment to respond formally to the 51 recommendations contained in the report? If not, by what date will the Government's response be forthcoming, given that it has now had the report for more than two years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to whether on a date in 1987 Senator Robert Ray said something is yes. I did not actually remember it having been said but we have checked and he did say it. —Senator Evans says that it will be a long wait. Mr Holding has stated that the Government is not proposing to respond any further at this stage. As far as the Government is concerned, folklife interests are not being neglected. I have already mentioned the National Library and, of course, in attempting to address the needs of multicultural Australia, there is some recognition of folklife's priority. —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories will recall stating in the Senate last week that John Singleton Advertising changed the economic message of the Buy Australian-Made campaign after being asked to do so by the ministerial committee because, in the Minister's words, `we found the economic message that he had delivered in it absolutely unacceptable. What was absolutely unacceptable about the economic message in Singleton's first submission that warranted the ministerial committee to request changes to Singleton's original proposal, and what changes were made to the economic message in the second submission which rendered it acceptable?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have now released all of the documents which were placed before the committee to enable Senator Bishop to make her own judgment on our judgment. As I have already stated in here, the ministerial committee regarded the message delivered in the first round of Singleton's submission to it as too negative. We were more than satisfied by the change that was made for the second presentation. I have made all of the documents available to Senator Short. If he has not made them available to Senator Bishop to check, I am more than happy to do so.

ANSWER.PARA: I have received a number of questions on this from Senator Bishop and Senator Short and I think it is appropriate to look at the way in which governments and political parties handle these things. It is not the case now-nor has it ever been-that an agency which has the account of a political party which is in government should be banned from receiving government advertising. The best way to consider what the ministerial committee did in this situation is to look at analogous situations. When Senator Bishop was the President of the New South Wales Liberal Party-and that is not very long ago-the New South Wales Liberal Party accounts were moved to the Campaign Palace under the stewardship of a Mr Greg Daniel. I might say that that is a 100 per cent overseas-owned agency. When Mr Daniel moved to John Clemenger, which was 50 per cent United States of America-owned, the Liberal Party account moved there as well. That agency won the New South Wales Government's $20m Lotto account. One wonders whether there was anything untoward in that. TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 November 1989 Senator Messner asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a series of questions relating to the activities of the Child Support Agency. The Treasurer has provided me with a response which, because of its lengthy detail, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Employers making deductions of maintenance payable by employees are required to pay these moneys to the Child Support Agency (CSA) by the 7th day of the month following the month in which the payments were deducted, similar to the employer's obligation in remitting tax instalment deductions made under the pay-as-you-earn (PAYE) taxation system. Payers who are not employees are required to pay directly to the Agency on the same basis. Under the legislative scheme these payments are then made to the custodial parent on the first Wednesday of the month following the month that payments were due to the CSA.

The Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 as introduced into the Parliament, identified a collection system which would be calendar monthly and a payment system which envisaged payment no later than the first Wednesday of the month after the payment was due to the Registrar. In other words, there is, and always have been, a clear timeframe between the liability to make the first payment and the date of the receipt of that payment. Thereafter, the legislation contemplates the regular and timely payment of maintenance calendar monthly by all payers. This Bill received bipartisan support from all in the Parliament and was passed without amendment.

The population that is affected by the arrangement is, therefore, every individual who registers with the Child Support Agency. Registration is not compulsory for persons other than those in receipt of an income-tested pension, benefit or allowance. To the extent that the custodial parent was receiving regular maintenance before registering with the Agency, there will be a ``hiatus'' in the receipt of payment for such individuals. Senator Messner should be aware that the Australian Institute of Family Studies in its publication ``Settling Up'' found that in the great majority of cases parents liable to pay under the old system, if they paid regularly, did so for a relatively short period. The ``hiatus'' is the small cost, if you like, for the custodial parent joining a national and effective enforcement scheme. The benefit is the security of having the Australian Taxation Office as his or her ``cost free'' enforcer of maintenance in the future and subject to their other income, eligible custodians are entitled to full pension or benefit in the interim.

Under the scheme, payments received by the Child Support Agency are placed in the Child Support Trust Account from which the Department of Social Security draws equivalent amounts and is required to pay to the custodial parent on the first Wednesday of each month. Depending on the time the payment is received by the Agency, payment to the custodial parent could be made as early as 7 days after receipt or as late as 28 days.

Prior to the introduction of the Scheme, evidence indicated that approximately 7 out of 10 persons with liabilities to pay child maintenance failed to make that payment at all, or if they did, they were irregular, both in quantum and in time. After 18 months of Agency operations evidence indicates that 61 per cent of liabilities are met on time and after enforcement action by the Australian Taxation Office some 75 per cent of liabilities are met. The Child Support Agency expects this figure to continue to improve as more payers become subject to employers making deductions on their behalf, a system proposed by the Parliament to be the cornerstone of the maintenance collection system.
