TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the eighty-second conference of the Inter-Parliamentary Union (IPU). I seek leave to make a short statement in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the eighty-second conference of the Inter-Parliamentary Union, held in London from 4 to 9 September 1989. The leader of this delegation was the Hon. Tom Uren, the honourable member for Reid. The deputy leader was Mr Roger Shipton, the honourable member for Higgins. My co-delegates were Senator Janet Powell from Victoria, the honourable member for Berowra, Dr Harry Edwards, the honourable member for Greenway, Mr Russ Gorman, and the honourable member for Streeton, Mr Tony Lamb.

SPEECH.PARA: The IPU conference in London was significant as it represented the centenary of the co-founding of the IPU by a British and a French parliamentarian in 1889. The Inter-Parliamentary Union has, as one of its central aims, the strengthening of representative political institutions. It was highly symbolic that the opening ceremonies for the conference were held in historic Westminster Hall of the Palace of Westminster. The Australian delegation was active at the conference and the official duties undertaken by each of the delegates are noted in the report, which I invite honourable senators to peruse.

On the question of human rights, the Australian delegation introduced a resolution-in-council calling on parliaments of all member countries to establish, within their parliaments, groups for the promotion and protection of human rights. This resolution was not directed against any particular country or region; rather, it was based on goodwill and the desire to support and strengthen individual human rights everywhere. The IPU council finally adopted the resolution by 86 votes to six, with 21 abstentions.

The IPU committee on human rights of parliamentarians reported on the situation of 22 parliamentarians from eight countries. Of particular interest to this region, it reported that a former parliamentarian of Indonesia, Mrs Sundari, who had been given a life imprisonment sentence in 1968 for her alleged role in the 1965 attempted coup in Indonesia, had been released on 17 August 1989. Similarly, in Malaysia, restriction orders against seven opposition parliamentarians were revoked on 20 April 1989. By contrast, one of the most publicised and brutal violations of human rights which had occurred since the previous conference did not even make it on to the agenda of the conference. The rules of the conference enable a supplementary item to be included on the agenda, provided that any such proposal receives the necessary support as set out in the rules. The Federal Republic of Germany group proposed the following supplementary item:
Repression by force of the peaceful protest made by the citizens of the People's Republic of China.
At a rollcall vote, the request presented by the Federal Republic of Germany group was rejected by 393 votes to 335, with 509 abstentions.

IPU conferences are often seen as more important for the opportunity they present for contacts and discussions between delegates outside the official sessions than for the resolutions which emerge from the official sessions. As a member of the executive committee of the Australian national group of the IPU, I, together with other members, need to reflect on whether the benefits of these contacts and discussions warrant the financial outlays which we have to make or whether other forums can equally serve this purpose. In particular, the question of the usefulness of twice yearly IPU conferences must be raised for consideration, particularly if major questions of human rights violations such as the Tiananmen Square massacre are to be excluded from the agenda or if non-parliamentary groups attempt to unduly influence resolutions of the IPU as part of another agenda.

At the London conference, the population control lobby attempted to influence the outcome of the agenda item entitled `The population and food equation and the search for rational and efficient solutions to the problem of Third World debt to ensure that the world can eat'. Their fatal diagnosis is that people growth in developing countries is the problem and that population control is the solution. This diagnosis is deceptive, simplistic and distracts attention from the real problems and their solutions. The population control lobby cannot trust parents to make responsible decisions governing their intimate relationships and the size of their families. It says that these decisions must be heavily influenced by the population policies of politicians at the behest of outside agencies and by governments no matter how dictatorial.

As parliamentarians, we must be ever wary of the attempts by non-elected bureaucratic elites to steer meetings of parliamentarians in their predetermined direction. Over many years, the population control lobby has sought to use international fora to promote a so-called `consensus' on this issue and to use it to promote their ideology of population control imperialism. As parliamentarians with both rural and urban constituencies, we are conscious of the need to acknowledge the great advances in agricultural production that have taken place in recent decades despite, or perhaps because of, increases in population and the role that innovation and optimism have played in this process. The bleak yet appealingly deceptive assertion that population growth is outstripping food supplies and ravaging the environment had its origin in Western-based population control lobby groups and academics like the recycled Paul Ehrlich. While history has savaged their pessimistic forecasts, these prophets of doom continue to capture the imagination of governments, which clutch at the straws of simple solutions to the world's problems and refuse to face the facts. Despite frightening predictions in the 1960s, we now live in a world of food abundance. Yet many people go hungry.

The fertility of poor women in developing countries has been made the scapegoat for a range of problems from environmental damage to famine, the primary causes of which are war, political instability and man's inhumanity to man. To propose population control as the panacea is to succumb to the pessimism of our age. To point the finger of guilt at the fertility of poor women is to set the stage for policies which discriminate against the families of less developed countries and to open the way for gross violations of human rights. The present unhealthy fixation on population control is economically and socially naive and dangerous. It diverts the attention and efforts of governments in both the developed and developing world away from the real and pressing measures required.

The global food outlook is not a problem either now or in the long term; distribution is. As parliamentarians, we need to shed pessimism and exude hope to work for a fair world trading and exchange system, to reduce indebtedness and unemployment, to assist with making fisheries and farming more attractive, to exchange technologies, to promote the environmentally sound and efficient use of resources, to reform inefficient or corrupt economic practices, to promote human initiatives to feed the poor; in short, to strive for an authentic socioeconomic development based on social justice and respect for human life. Faced with evidence which has destroyed the pessimistic forecast of the population control lobby, it is now using world concern for the environment to promote its viewpoint.

Parliamentarians and the IPU must take measures to ensure that the population control lobby and associated outside groups, such as the Global Committee of Parliamentarians on Population and Development, do not set the agenda or influence our work, including the work of the ad hoc committee on the environment. The Inter-Parliamentary Union was established for parliamentarians. It is important to note that this is a group not of governments but of parliamentarians. Parliamentarians are the delegates to the conference. However, it was very disconcerting to many parliamentarian delegates to the conference that in the discussion of the agenda item to which I have referred no fewer than 14 outside organisations spoke at the conference. Not all were from the population control lobby. One of them, the International Planned Parenthood Federation, had two bites at the cherry. Because these organisations ate up so much of the time of the conference for the discussion of this agenda item, many parliamentarians' speaking time was reduced to a period of only 3 1/2 minutes. To travel all that distance to speak for such a short time is also something to be questioned.

Finally, I take this opportunity to thank my co-delegates, our secretary, Mr Rob Diamond, and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade adviser, Mr Fred Peppinck, for a harmonious week of hard work at the conference. I also thank the Australian High Commissioner, the former President of this place, former Senator Doug McClelland, and Mrs Lorna McClelland, for the assistance they were able to provide in London and for their generous hospitality in co-hosting a function at the Australian High Commission for the Asia-Pacific Group. Last but by no means least, I gratefully acknowledge the splendid organisational skills and the warm hospitality of the United Kingdom Group, whose Chairman, Mr Michael Marshall, was aptly elected as President of the IPU at the London conference.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1989SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1989

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Powell has moved Australian Democrats' amendments 1 to 6 together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting for lunch, on this group of amendments some heat was being generated by discussion from the Opposition side, in particular from Senator Crichton-Browne, who seemed to be outraged that we should be concerned about a 15-year-old child from a sole parent family going to work for 33 hours a week to the net benefit for that household of $35 or thereabouts. He raised the question of need and greed. I thought that it might be useful to clarify our position on the question raised by Senator Crichton-Browne. A number of things occurred to us. Given that the weekly figure in the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) is $100, we are concerned about the effect of that figure. We ask ourselves why that child is working. Clearly, Government policy is to encourage young people to stay at school as full time students. If they were still full time students, they would be exempt from this provision even if they earned $100 a week. They would still be classified as a dependent child.

SPEECH.PARA: So why is a 15-year-old child having to do this against the whole thrust of government policy? Being virtually a drop-out from school can in many ways go against the child's own future interests. We do not have to look too much further than at the documentation of the lives of these families-I have already put some details on the record-to see why a 15-year-old might do this. We were accused by Senator Crichton-Browne of not wishing to build any incentive into the system. Apparently $35 a week for 33 hours work is an incentive in Senator Crichton-Browne's terms, but that is not the way we see it.

These children could be motivated to work by a number of factors which show up in the case studies of such families-factors I mentioned earlier-such as where a sole parent has taken on education, perhaps having been an early school leaver, as the mother of a 15-year-old is most likely to have been, and has difficulty finding money to purchase books or getting transport to the educational institution with which she is involved, or where the child itself is suffering from the social deprivation that is involved with poverty for young people and their families, such as not being able to go on school excursions or having to wear a school uniform to a party and, after having been ridiculed, saying, `I won't go to any more parties'. That happened to the 10- or 11-year-old daughter of one of the people in Jenny Trethewey's Aussie Battlers-Rosemary Young. Those pressures are at work because the benefit paid to those families is at the subsistence level or in many cases is almost below the subsistence level.

Another example is not being able to use a heater in the winter because heating bills cannot be met. One of the case studies in the book refers to a visit made to a house in the middle of winter where the temperature was freezing. There was an oil heater in the house. I think that at the moment oil heating is the most expensive form of winter heating. These families are not able to choose to live in a house with natural gas, which is cheaper. They have to take the accommodation that is available, which may be the most inexpensive-if they can get it. They have very little choice about what kind of heating is in the house and how much it will cost. We are not saying that the children of these people should not work. What we are saying is that we should be in a position to acknowledge the pressures on them and, as I have often said in the debate, the parenting that is taking place individually in a sole parent family.

We are trying to amend the legislation by making the figure an annual not a weekly one. We are concerned that the pressures imposed on such families force a child into the work force for socially generated economic reasons, such as the way they feel about not being able to participate with their peers or simply trying to bring more money into the household, perhaps being a partner in their mother's goal to educate herself and become independent of benefit or pension. The decision to work may not be a permanent one. We would go so far as to say that we would want it not to be a permanent decision. I believe that that is the Government's policy also and that it wishes to see the retention of children in school.

We are trying to break a poverty cycle-at least, I hope we are-and in that event it is bad for this figure to be a weekly one. Surely we want to reduce the pressures on these families to the greatest possible extent. I have a 15-year-old son and I can imagine times when he would probably say, `Gee, I don't want to go to school any more', because the pressures were all too much or whatever. When he goes through the bottoms of his basketball shoes one has to find the money for new ones. I have not seen any basketball shoes for under $65; they are more like $95 or $120. The families I have referred to are unable to do that. A kid in such a family is more likely to say, `It is easier for me to distance myself from that group of peers and to go out and earn some money'. It is quite a lonely decision and, as I have said before, it impinges on his future.

At the very least we are asking the Government to amend this legislation so that, if the decision to work is temporary, a parent can encourage a child to go back to school and look for ways to make that possible. That probably means going to families and friends for support. However, given the passage of the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3), I am concerned about what sort of support such a person might get if he happens to be living with those people. The situation is fraught with stress and we want to see a more long term approach taken. At the very least we want the Government to accept our amendment and make the figure an annual one so that, in an administrative sense, we might expect that a longer term view would be taken of such a family.

I feel quite distressed, not for myself but because I am a human being, at the concept of any of my colleagues in this place believing that to be concerned about this group of people is wrong and that in some way we are encouraging such people to be greedy, especially when I read newspapers and see headlines, as I did last Friday, which read, `Millionaires enjoy a better tax deal than poor'. That article told us that the Australian Taxation Commissioner's statistics for the 1987-88 financial year showed that people who declared taxable income of more than $1m that year paid only 29.1c in the dollar in tax. Think of the effective marginal tax rate of the kid who is working for 33 hours a week to increase his family's income by $35. Millionaires are paying a lower tax rate than people earning a fraction of their income. The point is made later in the article that that taxable income of $1m is only what is left after the accountants have exhausted all the possibilities of income splitting and various other, shall we say, creative accounting measures, all of which are quite legal of course. The statistics which we saw last Friday showed that the 267 income millionaires received more tax credits and rebates between them than the almost 1 1/2 million Australian taxpayers with an income below $10,000.

SPEECH.PARA: The record of the Liberal Party of Australia is unparalleled in terms of offering safety nets and providing benefits to those who are unable to achieve a reasonable standard of living as a result of circumstances beyond their control. SPEECH.PARA: The amendments to the definition of `dependent child' are intended to exclude payments for children who are independent of their parents because they are employed. The provisions are drafted so that they will not apply to a child who continues to be a full time student. Consequently, casual, part time or vacation jobs for full time students will not be taken into account when assessing parental entitlement. The Government undertakes that the provisions would be administered as follows. The provisions would apply to a child who is in permanent or in definite employment when the wage for that work is $100 or more each week, or averages that amount or more per week. The provisions would also apply to the child who has a history of at least four weeks regular and ongoing casual work, bringing in at least $100 every week. However, when there is no promise and little likelihood of further earnings at that level in the immediate future the provisions would not apply.

The underlying philosophy is that family payments will not be made if, through employment, the child is in a financial position which allows for significant independence from parental support. The Government acknowledges that to achieve this policy the legislation might be more felicitously expressed. However, the Government does not accept the Democrats amendment. The legislation as drafted is not inconsistent with what I have just indicated is the policy that will be implemented; but the concept of $5,200 per year at the centre of the Democrats amendment is a new concept of unclear meaning-perhaps Senator Powell meant an annual rate of income of $5,200, which is a concept familiar in the pensions system. Her amendment, however, does not say that. In any event it would not clearly specify the policy which the Government and the Democrats both wish to achieve. TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes the amendment and asks the Committee to note two related facts in respect of it. To date it has been the only one of three work related payments in the Social Security Act which does not have an upper age limit. It is all right to highlight one aspect of it and say we are being discriminatory but, in reality, if one looks at the legislation and at the discrepancy and the fact that one could mount the same sort of argument about any work related payment under the Act, one sees that those arguments of discrimination have no legs. That has been recognised not only by the Government; the fact that this is treated differently from the other work related payments has been recognised by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal also, which noted in the case re Blando that an absence of any upper limit for invalid pensions is `a curious feature of the Act'. —The Opposition will not be supporting the Australian Democrats' amendment. —With regard to the general principle of work related payments having an upper age limit which coincides with the pensionable age-which I suppose is what Senator Bishop refers to when she says `retirement age'-certainly in respect of social security legislation that is what we would be implementing. I mentioned the ageing community, and it seems to me that if we are going to move, we ought to move in the opposite direction. We have to bear in mind that the invalid pension, the sickness benefit and the unemployment benefit all have particular tests applied to them. They are very stringent tests; tests which have been made more stringent, particularly in recent years. The work test at the moment for the unemployment benefit could scarcely be more stringent. The test for sickness benefit has been tightened up-I think in the last batch of social security Bills that we had or in the Bill at the end of last year. Clearly people who have a choice would exercise that choice to go onto an age pension when they, as women, reach 60 or, as men, reach 65, because for the age pension-apart from the assets test provisions and more general tests of that kind-they do not have to undergo the regular and stringent testing of the work related benefits to which Senator Bolkus referred. This amendment is proposed in that context and in the context that most invalid pensioners, having reached the age of 60 or 65, have been transferring to the age pension for that very reason. The people who have not been transferring have been the recently arrived migrants who, because they have not been here for 10 years, do not qualify. That is the reason for this particular part of the legislation. We are saying that those people do not have a choice. Those in the community who do have a choice have been transferring. If we are going to move in any direction in an ageing community, surely we should move up in age in the work related benefits area, not down. I am not saying that because it costs more, as I do not think it would. —I was very pleased to hear Senator Powell say that the Australian Democrats are in favour of extending the working life of Australians because it is part of our policy to encourage Australians, where they wish to work beyond the so-called normal retirement age to so do. —I wish briefly to respond to Senator Bishop's comment. TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I say at the outset that the coalition parties oppose the Industry Commission Bill. We oppose it, among other things, for the cant which the Government has given vent to in introducing it; for the hypocrisy which it represents and symbolises as to this Government's attitude towards micro-economic reform and for the panic which in one sense it also represents as part of the budgetary processes; and, perhaps above all, for the lack of imagination which it represents in terms of the presentation of it by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister Assisting the Treasurer, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris).

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Acting Deputy President, you will recall very clearly that at the time of the last Federal election in July 1987 this Government, of which you have the honour-I presume that is the word-to be a member, at least a party member, said that the hallmark, to use its word, of the third Hawke-Keating Government was to be micro-economic reform. That was to be the theme of this Government. What have we actually seen? I will not weary the Senate this afternoon, particularly given the time constraints upon us, by reciting the litany of failure on the Government's part to live up to that promise, but I will just mention the failure in the area of privatisation of government business enterprise on which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) embarked shortly after the election and for which he was finally brought to heel and told to go and stand in the corner and put on the dunce's cap almost a year later at the Australian Labor Party biennial conference in Hobart in June 1988.

We have seen the virtual lack of movement-not total lack of movement, I should say-in the area of tariff reform. We saw some minor stumbling steps in the May 1988 economic statement by the Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), but not much more than that. We have seen the arrant failure of the responsible Minister-if that is the way to describe him-the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Willis, in relation to waterfront reform following the very good report of the Inter-State Commission (ISC), one of the institutions whose future and fate is to be determined by the Bill before us this afternoon. What we have seen as a result of that on the Government's part is simply a retreat, beaten in all possible haste, from the wrath of the Waterside Workers Federation and the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), who declared that there was no way in which they would accept the recommendations of that report.

We have seen the equal failure-and by the same gentleman-in the area of coastal shipping reform where once again we have the Seamen's Union of Australia benefit process going on whereby almost no competition is permitted on the Australian coastal shipping area from foreign ships: a closed shop against foreign competition. Instead of any real program, therefore, of micro-economic reform, we have from the Government by way of substitution what we always get from this Government-talk.

The Industry Commission Bill before us proposes to amalgamate two bodies which, in their respective ways, are very effective proponents of micro-economic reform: the Industries Assistance Commission, which has a long and very honourable history beginning under its original title, the Tariff Board, from which it was transformed in 1973, if I recall correctly, into the IAC; and the Inter-State Commission which is provided for in the Australian Constitution but which, I have to concede, we managed to get along without for about 60 years or so in that interregnum until it was finally brought back into being by the present Government. I should perhaps not fail to mention a third body, the Business Regulation Review Unit, which is presently attached to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. The Bill seeks basically to roll those three entities into one and have this new mega-quango doing the job of all three.

I have to say that on one view of the matter there ought perhaps be no particular objection to that. In a sense, one body no doubt can do the job of all three, but the Opposition particularly objects to the hype, the cant as I called it before, with which what might otherwise be termed a rather minor administrative change has been introduced by the Government as being its contribution, the thing which will actually make a difference to the program of micro-economic reform in this country. It is typical, as I say, of the Hawke-Keating Government that it should baulk at true reform and simply offer us talk in its place. We are seeing that-and I do not want to digress long on this point-quintessentially at the present time in quite another area of micro-economic reform, namely, reform of the labour market.

Yesterday the Leader of the Government in the Senate described as junior clerks employees of the New South Wales Labor Council who had the intellectual capacity and intellectual courage to write a most interesting and insightful report to the New South Wales Labor Council in effect saying that the policy of the Government and the ACTU in the area of labour market relations is wrong, has failed, and will continue to fail. The report stated also that the only policy which is being put forward by any part of the political quarter in Australia today in that area is that which forms part of the Opposition's Economic Action Plan-its industrial relations policy. I mention that the two gentlemen in question had the goodness to say that the H. R. Nicholls Society, of which I had the honour to be the founding president and from which position I only recently retired, has won the intellectual and political debate in this country on that topic. I thank them for that compliment. I think that they are right. I will not digress on that matter now. I just want to point out that that is another area in which this Government is bereft not only of actions, but even of ideas.

The Industry Commission Bill, heralded by the Treasurer and his Government as a key step in their program of micro-economic restructuring, in fact, as I have already said, does nothing more than amalgamate two major and one lesser body-the Industries Assistance Commission, the Inter-State Commission and the Business Regulation Review Unit. It is patently clear that this amalgamated body will do nothing more than continue the work being done by its three constituent units. How on earth the Treasurer can possibly hope to persuade us that that is making a contribution to micro-economic reform in this country is beyond me. Even by the Treasurer's standards of audacity in debate, that is rather a large claim. As a matter of fact, referring to the amalgamation, the explanatory memorandum to the Bill states:
There should therefore be no net financial impact.

I would not contest that claim, of course, but I point out that the claim gives the game away; there is no change. In his second reading speech in introducing this Bill in the other place, the Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer stated:

As an institution, the Industries Assistance Commission has been an important force in economic policy in Australia, building community awareness of the need for Australian industry to be outward looking and internationally competitive.
I would not differ from that judgment for a moment. But the question it raises is: in that case, why abolish it? Again, the Minister noted in his speech:

The Inter-State Commission has been at the forefront of inquiry and analysis of transport issues. It has been a dispassionate, objective and expert source of analysis in this area and has established a high quality network on transport issues which can be integrated into the Industry Commission.

On the whole that is well deserved praise but it raises, again, the question: why abolish the Inter-State Commission? If it is doing such a good job, what is the point? Is it change for the sake of change? Is it reorganisation for the sake of reorganisation? The answer to my two rhetorical questions is simple enough, and we all know the answer. The answer is that in putting the finishing touches to the most recent Budget-the 1989-90 Budget-it suddenly became obvious to a tired and listless government, stunned by Opposition calls to actually do something about structural economic reform, that there was nothing in the Budget on that subject despite the many hollow claims that the Government had been advancing for the previous two years. So the Treasurer quickly brought before Cabinet a revenue neutral proposal-in other words, one which would not in any way affect the Budget figuring-that could easily be slipped in at the last moment and which could at least give him something with which to try to fend off or, if you like, counterattack the Opposition's condemnation of his total failure in this area.

The Treasurer's own failure in this area is particularly paramount because for the past two years the Industries Assistance Commission has been within the Treasurer's own portfolio of responsibilities. Prior to that time it was within the portfolio of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, and there was a stand-up, knockdown, dragged-out fight in Cabinet just shortly after the last election when the portfolio responsibility was transferred from Senator Button to Mr Keating. I should say quite frankly that at the time I rather welcomed that change. The handling of the Industries Assistance Commission by Senator Button had been-I should not use too strong language-poor. Little had been achieved after, at that stage, nearly five years under the aegis of Senator Button. I did hope that the transfer to the portfolio responsibility of the Treasurer might result in a major improvement. I thought that perhaps with the wind in the sails of the Commission-applied by the full strength of the Treasurer's Cabinet standing and, I might also say, by a good Department, the Treasury, instead of a rather second rate one behind it-there would be a lift in its game. But there was not a bit of it.

Few things have been more disappointing in the performance of this Minister in that past two years than the way in which he has neglected this body, the responsibility for which he actively sought and fought in Cabinet just following the last election. I suppose that we have become used now to Mr Keating's substitution of rhetoric for performance. What we have in the case of this Bill is rhetoric.

I think that we have to start looking at what we are actually about with this piece of legislation. In 1987 Mr Keating said that he had solved the macro-economic problems of Australia-I think that was just before the last election-and that micro-economic reform was to be the hallmark of the third Hawke-Keating Government. He was reported-only a fortnight or so ago-in the Australian on Monday, 22 November, in an interview with Laura Tingle, as saying:
The most important continuing reform is maintaining the macro-economic policy discipline. That's number one. Macro policy is king, always was king, always will be king.
Not `micro'-`macro'. Earlier, in the same article from which I am quoting, the Treasurer is also quoted as saying:
Look, the waterfront has been done to death and overdone. It's small beer compared with macro-economic changes.

Apart from the fact that we have not had any macro-economic changes from this Treasurer for longer than I care to remember-all we have had is simply the pushing up of interest rates by one notch after another; I suppose we can describe that as a macro-economic change, but it is hardly structural reform through the macro-economic instruments-he is also claiming that the waterfront reform question is small beer. He can go out and tell that to the farmers of this country and, indeed, all the other exporters and the importers of this country whose goods have to pass across waterfronts. They have to pay their tolls to the people who have been extorting tolls from them for decades past; namely, the Waterside Workers Federation and other friends of the Government.

In other words, in the words of the Treasurer, we have a back flip: micro-reform is no longer important-small beer. The Treasurer is becoming notorious for what I might call selective interpretation. He fails to mention, in even the most general terms in his recorded interview, that the Industries Assistance Commission-a body for which, I repeat, he is directly responsible in a portfolio sense-on the first page of its annual report for 1988-89, which will be the last report that this body will make if the Treasurer has his way with this Bill, states:

Information collected by the Commission for its inquiry work and drawn together using the ORANI model, indicates that the removal of major inefficiencies in domestic water transport, international liner shipping, the transport and handling of bulk commodities, domestic and international aviation, road and rail transport could collectively increase gross domestic product (GDP) by around $9 billion annually.

That is small beer, as far as the Treasurer is concerned. That is in real terms, of course, not just money. Improved efficiency in the postal, telecommunications and electricity sectors could provide a further stimulus to gross domestic product (GDP) of around $3 billion annually. As a matter of fact, the Industries Assistance Commission has had a great deal to say, in its latest annual report, about the need for micro-economic reform, which the Treasurer now describes as small beer. In all, it calculates that the projected long term impact of various reforms would result in annual gains in real GDP of almost 5 per cent, or $16 billion a year in total. That is not small beer. That would mean a great deal to ordinary Australians.

We can talk in these technical terms about GDP and $9 billion a year or $16 billion a year, but what it comes down to in the end is the impact on the average Australian family. The IAC has actually done that calculation for us and calculates that this would amount to over $1,600 a year in real terms for every household in Australia. In addition, it would lead to employment gains equivalent to about 35,000 jobs-jobs which we might be grateful for next year, if the two authors of the New South Wales Labor Council document are correct. They foreshadow the onset of what they call the growth recession and the unemployment they believe that is likely to lead to in the very near future. As well as noting the potential gains from reform of the kind I have referred to, the Industries Assistance Commission has also made a great number of explicit criticisms of the present Government in its annual report. On page 2 of the report it states:
If we do not act now-
on micro-economic reforms, that is-
our competitive position and standard of living are in danger of decline.

Our standard of living has been declining in any case, but the report is pointing to the future. Despite views to the contrary from the Government, particularly from perhaps the least adequate Minister in that Government, Mr Willis, the IAC nominates the areas of coastal shipping and privatisation as needing urgent attention. That is its word-urgent. On the second page of its report it states:
. . . the continuing exclusion of foreign competition means that there is little ongoing incentive for domestic ship operators to keep pace with efficiency improvements abroad.
It goes on:
Moreover, the absence of foreign competition removes one of the disciplines for ensuring that the cost savings from reduced crewing levels-
and there has been some progress in reducing crewing levels, although the progress has been minuscule-
are passed on to users and the community generally.

That is, instead of being passed on to the Seamen's Union of Australia and to the shipping companies, which is what happens at the present time. With regard to government business enterprises, the Industries Assistance Commission report notes on page 3:
In the absence of competition, the benefits of recent administrative reforms-
that is, of government business enterprises-
are likely to be dissipated as new inefficiencies emerge. Opportunities for efficiency improvements are likely to be overlooked.
It continues:
As part of the process of increasing competition in services industries, the need for government ownership of enterprises should be reassessed.

We all know what the process of assessment of the case for privatisation has resulted in under this Government. It has resulted in handing over the whole process of privatisation, or rather the non-process of privatisation, to the Caucus committee-to Mr Saunderson and others. They will determine whether any such progress should be made and, by and large, their answer to date has been no, there will not be. Again, their trade union affiliates will not let them. They do not care about the consequences of that, as far as costs to the Australian people of the services being provided by the government business enterprises are concerned. What they care about are the people who pay the bills for the Australian Labor Party-the trade unions-particularly now that some of the Labor Party's great and powerful friends are looking a little less great and powerful. If all this is beginning to sound a little familiar, in other words, to sound like the coalition's policies, I simply direct the attention of the Senate to this additional comment on page 28 of the IAC's annual report:
The success of many of the reforms discussed so far-
that is, reforms in relation to coastal shipping, the waterfront, government business enterprises, privatisation and so on-

is predicated on a degree of labour market reform. The removal of many restrictive and inflexible work practices is likely to require changes to union structure and coverage in the affected industries.

Again, this is not an area on which this Government is ever likely to embark. It sounds familiar because that call parallels almost exactly the call for micro-economic reform to be found in the coalition's Economic Action Plan. That is the only document from either side of this Parliament which has put forward policies as distinct from mere talk from the Government about how much better things will be if the Australian people are so unwise as to re-elect it; just as things have been so much better for the past two and a half years after the equally false promises which were made to the people in July 1987: reform on the waterfront; reform of coastal shipping; privatisation; and labour market reform. These are the policies of the coalition. The Government has no policies in these areas-none.

They are, of course, all crucial elements of a strategy which will drag Australia out of the $110 billion foreign debt hole into which this Government has driven us. From a point at which when it took over we had a foreign debt in net terms of $23 billion, we now have one-as at the end of September-of $110 billion. The only way we will have any chance of pulling ourselves back from that abyss is if we raise productivity in this country and make the reforms which are essential to that process, without which that will not be achieved and without which we will never get rid of the high interest rates this Government has imposed upon us as its only weapon, its only economic policy instrument.

I want to come back to the point where I began on the Industry Commission Bill, namely, the Government's hypocrisy in advancing a Bill of this kind on the ground that it is going to make a significant contribution to the micro-economic restructuring process. I have already pointed to the fact that the Minister assisting in the other place has praised both the major constituent bodies which are to be amalgamated and I asked why, therefore, they should be abolished if they have been doing so well. What is the point of abolishing them? It is just reorganisation for the sake of reorganisation. It is particularly ironic that this is the same Minister, Mr Morris, who actually introduced the Inter-State Commission Bill in 1983. He said at that time:

I have great pleasure in bringing before the House-that is the House of Representatives-this Bill which will finally . . . enable us to establish the Inter-State Commission . . . We see the ISC as an important vehicle for promoting the rational development of the national transport policies. The Government's action today fulfils an important election promise in the transport field.
The Minister went on to say:
The Commission will be required to carry out wide-ranging investigations covering economic, social, institutional and legal-constitutional issues affecting interstate transport.
The Minister said finally:
There is no other existing organisation that is equipped, or empowered, to carry out such inquiries. The ISC meets the need for an ongoing independent body that performs theses functions.

My, how times have changed. The Government is now going to abolish this essential body and wrap it up in a megalith or, sorry, megabody. Perhaps `megalith' is the right word, as a matter of fact, but I will not stop on that point. The fact is that this Bill is a waste of Parliament's time. The amalgamation of the two existing commissions achieves no real purpose except to allow Mr Hawke and Mr Keating to go out and prate around the country about how they are really doing something about micro-economic reform when, as we all know, in order to do something about micro-economic reform they have to do some hard things and not merely re-arrange the deckchairs on the Titanic. Of course, we have-and I have not referred to it-the constitutional consideration which might be thought to bear upon whether we should be abolishing the Inter-State Commission. I could spend some time on that but I do not propose to as I do not have time to do so now.

As I have said before, it is true that for 60 years or so we have got on without the ISC; I suppose we would have to say that we could not argue too strongly that that in itself is a reason why it should not now be abolished. But I happen to think that the real danger we have is that we will put both these bodies in the portfolio of the Treasurer who has already shown by his performance in handling one of them for the past two years that he does not care a straw about micro-economic reform. He has failed in his administration of the IAC and I predict that he will fail in his administration of the Industry Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industry Commission Bill 1989 represents, as Senator Stone has said, the amalgamation of the former Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) and the Inter-State Commission (ISC) and also reconstructs the new body along somewhat different lines. In that sense, while it may be true, as Senator Stone has said, that it may be merely rearranging the deckchairs on the Titanic, one expresses the hope that this body will go somewhat further than that. At least in outline it has that possibility but I will indicate as I go along that we have some concerns about the way in which the body is constituted, the sorts of references it has, and the way in which those references will be put before it. Of course, the term `assistance' has been dropped from the title. I guess that this in itself indicates, to some extent, a broadening of the approach.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer (Mr Keating), in a press release on 15 August, indicated also a broadening of the functions of the Industry Commission compared to the IAC. He said that he seeks for the new Commission to be restructured `to make it an effective catalyst for change'. He went on to say:
Its charter will be greatly broadened and it will become the Government's major review and inquiry body in industry matters.

However, in the view of the Australian Democrats, the charter is unnecessarily restrictive and there is a certain incestuousness about the construction of this body, as I have indicated already, particularly in relation to the appointment of the Commission-its members will be appointed by the Government-and also in relation to setting the terms of reference. For instance, if we look to clause 6 (1) of the Bill we find:
The functions of the Commission are:
(a) to hold inquiries and make reports to the Minister in respect of such matters relating to industry as are referred to it by the Minister . . .
In other words, there is a narrowness in the way in which references can be put before this body. If we look then at clause 8 we find:
In the performance of its functions, the Commission must have regard to the desire of the Commonwealth Government.

That may be interpreted as constraining the Commission to frame any report that it might make in terms of the desire, the direction, the philosophy and so on of the Commonwealth Government. Should this Commission see a necessity to report to the Government that perhaps its direction is wrong and that it should take a different direction, I am not sure whether clause 8 (1) does not constrain the Commission in some regard which would prevent that from happening.

Of course, the danger is that the Commission may simply become an arm of government policy formation and not, as I and the Democrats believe it should be, an instrument by which there could be a wide-ranging and independent assessment of various aspects of industrial policy and direction, economic policy and the various social and environmental factors which impinge on that. It may recommend directions and policies to the Government which, in some instances, may be quite contrary to the `desire'-to use the word in the Bill-of the Commonwealth Government. We believe that there may be many instances where the Commission should be recommending directions and policies which are quite contrary to those which the Government has taken in the recent past.

We believe that the Government has taken a very anachronistic view of industry. It seems to think, in the broadest sense, that the pattern of the 1950s and 1960s in some way can be recaptured; that that period of rapid growth in the economy, of full employment and rising material consumption, can be reinstated; that the parameters that determined that period in Australia's rapid industrial development can be reinstated and those same conditions re-formed.

The directions in which we need to go as we enter the 1990s and into the next century are entirely different. A whole range of factors needs to be taken into account. The Government's pattern in the years since 1984 really has not taken that properly into account. I could instance, as I have on a number of other occasions, the much vaunted Button car plan which, in my view, merely looks at the motor vehicle manufacturing industry in this country in terms of getting the most efficient production of a limited range of motor vehicle models. Nowhere in that plan was any consideration given to the resource use of motor vehicles and no emphasis was given to the desperate need to come up with efficient motor vehicles, in terms of their fuel consumption, recognising that Australia is becoming less and less self-sufficient in fuel and that we will need to import more and more of our hydrocarbon fuel from overseas which will add to our foreign debt. No consideration was given to the environmental effects of car use-things such as the greenhouse effect and so on.

So one finds as a consequence of the Button car plan that the most efficient model, in terms of petroleum consumption, manufactured by Mitsubishi-the Mitsubishi Colt-is the one that is likely to go out of production because, under this plan, insufficient Colt models have been sold; whereas the larger models, the gas guzzlers, the ones that will add significantly to our need to import more petroleum, and the ones that will add significantly to urban pollution and greenhouse emissions, will continue to be manufactured. So, if you like, that is a practical example of the way in which this Government, in looking backwards and in instituting the patterns of the past, has failed to recognise some of the important parameters that need to be taken into account in restructuring Australian industry for the future. In the second reading speech of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris), one also finds these words:

As a result, Australian industry has been forced to face squarely the imperatives of doing business in an international environment-and it is only in that environment that Australia will be able to provide the basis for sustained and rising living standards.

Again, the assumption there is that rising living standards is precisely the same as increased material consumption. Surely it is time to explode the equation that we can in fact have a better quality of life with reduced material consumption. Those things cannot be equated. The Minister further says:

Those realities include the need to be more competitive and the need to be more hard-nosed about the use of Government resources. That debate is to be warmly welcomed-and the establishment of the Industry Commission and the transfer of the functions of the Inter-State Commission to that body will allow the Commonwealth to continue to play its major role in the development of sound industry policy in this nation.

That indicates that, in our view, the Government is really not properly aware of the conditions which will obtain in the 1990s and beyond and is simply ignoring those. The danger is not so much that the Government is not aware of those conditions but that it is now creating a Commission which will be too constrained and unable to take into account those conditions, thereby becoming a catalyst for change and being able to feed into the Government, or report to the Government, in ways which will bring the Government around to recognising the need for change.

It seems to us to be absolutely clear that the disregard in the last three or four decades of the environmental factors in industrial development has resulted in severe and exacerbating damage to the environment on a global scale and that to tackle these matters will require more than merely putting an environmental gloss over business as usual. It is not to be solved by competition. In future we surely must become far more cooperative. Indeed, in recent times we have seen such things as the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer. A meeting in Canada earlier this year called for a 20 per cent reduction in the emission of greenhouse gases. If the world is going to proceed on a competitive basis, clearly those industries and those countries which can see some short term advantage will not be properly taking into account their environmental responsibilities, and the idea that one should establish industries to be more competitive rather than more cooperative, taking into account the welfare of future generations, again seems to be looking back to the past. But so far this has been the direction of this Government. In our view, it has looked to the past rather than to the future. The restructuring of this commission does not give us a great deal of hope unless the Bill is amended so that the Commission will be able to report more broadly.

One could also find examples of the failure of this incestuous relationship with respect to previous inquiries. When the creation of the Fitzgerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies was the subject of debate in this place, I pointed out that I had approached both the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) and the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray), pointing out that it was necessary that there be a demographer and somebody with a biologist-ecologist type background to sit on that committee so that the committee itself would be aware of when it needed that expertise. That recommendation was rejected by both Ministers. Indeed, as a consequence, we saw the Fitzgerald inquiry into immigration totally ignore the environmental consequences of immigration and come up with a highly suspect conclusion in relation to the economics of immigration.

The assumption that economists are jacks of all trades seems to lie behind much that this Government has done. In view of their inability to predict what will happen next week and, indeed, the observation that economists very often-in fact, usually-disagree over explanations of what happened last week indicates that their expertise very often is merely a confident assertion of bias. When one looks at the proposed references which the Government is thinking of putting before this new body, one is also aware of the strong desirability of a wider representation on the Commission and the requirement in the Bill for consideration of environmental and consumer interests.

The press release from the Treasurer of 15 August outlines the forward work program of the Industry Commission, the first one of which is `Energy Generation and Distribution'. We should note the words `Energy Generation', because it is abundantly clear to anybody who knows anything about this matter that one cannot generate energy; all one does is simply re-form one form of energy into another. One turns coal into electricity, but energy can neither be created nor destroyed. So the use of the term `energy generation' as though human industry in some way generates energy is itself an indication of the way in which economists understand only the first law of thermodynamics, have no understanding whatsoever of the second law and, indeed, believe in perpetual motion. If one wants two words which more than any others indicate the need for a different input to this Commission, they are the words `energy generation'.

Leaving that aside for the moment, this undoubtedly is an extremely important reference. I think Senator Stone mentioned it also in his speech a moment ago. I guess that the Treasurer was really referring to electricity generation rather than energy generation-a common mistake, but again indicative of certain unfortunate attitudes. While electricity generation is in the hands of the States, perhaps the Commonwealth Government is rather loathe to get strongly involved in and to control this area, although I note that placitums (i) and (xx) of section 51 of the Constitution are explicitly written into the Bill. So clearly the Government is recognising that it does have power in those areas if it wishes to use it.

Nonetheless, one of the major sources of foreign indebtedness in this country at the present time relates to the way that the electricity utilities in the States have gone ahead and built an excess of generating capacity. It has happened in every single State. As a consequence, the States have built up an enormous debt. Some 25 per cent of the cost of any new electricity generating station immediately goes offshore because we do not build heavy generating equipment in this country. As a consequence of that indebtedness, we have had to artificially stimulate the consumption of electricity to generate a cash flow to deal with that problem of very large debt. Electricity is a very expensive form of energy in an absolute sense, and should be reserved for those uses for which other forms of energy are not available.

For instance, if one looks at the way in which the Electricity Trust of South Australia has misused the energy which it generates, it is clear that there is the potential for an enormous saving in this area. Some 40 per cent of the electricity generated in South Australia is used in private homes and for residential use-and some 40 per cent of that is used for space heating and water heating. That is an incredibly wasteful way of using electricity and using our primary resources. There are better ways, much more efficient ways, of heating that water. If one looked at the total economics of that generation, one would see that the end use, namely, warm homes and hot water, can be achieved far more cheaply than by using gas to generate electricity, as we do in South Australia, with about 30 per cent efficiency, and then using that electricity to heat water. For instance, using gas directly would achieve about a 60 per cent efficiency.

In the past, the Federal Government seems to have been unwilling-although I believe it has been able-to direct the States with respect to their management of utilities. It is pleasing to see that this reference will come before this new Commission. Again, I express the hope that this Commission is sufficiently unfettered to recommend firmly to the Federal Government that, indeed, there is a great deal it could do. For example, it could limit the amount of borrowing which the States could undertake to build further generating capacity. In view of the overcapacity that we have in this country, that in itself could substantially delay the building of more power stations and could lead to very substantial increases in efficiency.

I have indicated already that, in this area of electricity use, one could achieve significant conservation of primary energy-coal, gas or whatever-and improvements in the environment because one is not burning so many resources. At the same time, the cost of this energy delivered in the end use would in fact fall. What concerns me is that one finds in this Government the attitude that conservation-and attention to addressing problems like the greenhouse effect-will necessarily lead to more expensive industries. That is simply untrue. One can achieve improvements in efficiency with present technology; one can achieve reductions in greenhouse emissions; one can achieve reductions in the resource depreciation-and at the same time do that with decreased cost.

I stress the point that, if this Government has too close control of the commissioners, the references, and the terms of the reference, then it is possible that that same false attitude, that false assumption, will come through because the Commission will not be in a position to take a wider view of the situation. By way of example, I point out that in the Australian of 8 November 1988, in an article by Lenore Taylor, we find that both Mr Kerin and Senator Cook say:

The cost to the economy of saving the environment will be assessed industry by industry under a plan developed by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, as part of the campaign to counter the undue influence of the green movement.
The ministers have asked their departments to undertake a 12 month industry by industry study to put economic value on environmental goals such as clean air and water, or preserved native forests.
There is an assumption that it is actually going to cost more to look after the environment. We find in the Australian of Tuesday, 5 December 1989 Mr Kerin saying:
We cannot afford to wait for conclusive scientific evidence of climate warming.
He is talking about the greenhouse effect. To continue:
But unlike the Minister for Science, Mr Jones, Mr Kerin was cautious on the desirability of a `carbon tax' on the energy forms that emit large amounts of carbon dioxide.

The implication is that these measures would actually increase rather than decrease the cost of industry in protecting the environment. We find also that Mr Barry Jones, an economist with the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, speaking at the current conference in Sydney on greenhouse changes in Australia, stated:
Changes in Australia's pattern of energy consumption should be avoided unless the social benefits outweigh the costs . . .
I could not agree more with that. The implication of what he is saying is that the costs will be excessive. The point that is becoming absolutely clear is that the costs need not be excessive at all.

It is also implicit in the economic analysis which is often implicit in these considerations that the conventional economic model can deal adequately with questions such as long term environmental damage. As I have indicated already, economists seem to be aware of the first law of thermodynamics but totally ignorant of the second law. As a consequence, they tend to use discount rates when looking at future environmental damage and bring them back to the present time. The consequence of that is that over any reasonably long period of time-like 40 or 50 years-the future is essentially discounted. Of course, as we now know, that is a totally inappropriate way of addressing those future costs. The assumption behind that discount model is, of course, that the world is infinite and one can always find other resources in which one can invest; and one can then exploit those other resources and continue to have an expanding and growing and more consuming economy. Again, that is totally out of keeping and ignorant of the second law of thermodynamics.

The references which the Minister then goes on to give are interesting. Railways, passenger motor vehicles, product liability, and the economics of recycling are all very important and very significant references in which it is important to have an environmental and consumer emphasis. Without that, it is quite possible that, with those references put by a government which is orientated in the way this Government is and which is determining the terms of the reference, the Commission will not be able to report to the Government in ways which will steer the Government toward the new directions which are necessary to face the 1990s and the next century.

As a consequence, the Australian Democrats will be moving to amend this legislation. The amendments are to alter the Commission to the extent that, where a matter is referred to the Commission for inquiry and report, the Commission must also inquire into and, in the same report, report on the social and environmental consequences of any recommendations it makes. Interestingly, the Treasurer in his press release No. 96, which is undated, said, among other things:
Indeed the Commission will be taking into account the Government's social and environmental policy objectives in respect of its inquiries.

There is nothing in the Bill which gives effect to that. We will be seeking to write that amendment into the legislation. Moreover, in relation to the Commission itself, we feel that it is desirable-indeed, necessary-that there be commissioners who have knowledge, expertise and experience in the area of consumer and environmental matters. Accordingly, we will be seeking to amend that section of the Bill when we get to it.

In the few moments left to me I want to deal briefly with the Opposition's concern over the Inter-State Commission. Although the Inter-State Commission is mentioned in the Constitution, I understand that it did not come into existence until 1913. Indeed, it fell into disuse again around about 1920. In about 1975 a Bill was passed to reinstate the Commission and it was re-established only in 1984. It seems to me that, under those circumstances, one cannot rest too heavily-and the Opposition, particularly-on the Constitution as a plank for the retention of the Inter-State Commission.

Senator Stone also mentioned that the Inter-State Commission had been charged with looking at transport. In the last five years I have not seen any marked improvement, particularly in interstate transport. The railways have continued to fall into disrepair and disuse and the highways have been inadequate and dangerous while carrying increasing loads. I see no difficulty in putting that sort of reference into the new Commission and incorporating those matters where they rightly belong-with industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industry Commission Bill 1989 will establish an Industry Commission for the purposes of holding inquiries into matters relating to industry and for related purposes. The Bill also seeks to make other provisions in connection with industry and to repeal the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) Act and parts of the Inter-State Commission Act. Its effect will be, of course, that instead of three bodies-the Industries Assistance Commission, the Inter-State Commission and the Business Regulation Review Unit-looking at these matters, there will be one. Why is the Government merging them into one? Senator Stone suggested-and I am sure that this was a strong factor in the decision-that this is in order to give some credibility to the Government's micro-economic campaign. In fact, it is doing nothing about micro-economic reform; it is just talking about it. Nevertheless, this Bill has given the Budget statement something, just something, to indicate that something, just something, is happening in the area of micro-economic reform. We all know that nothing is happening. I do not want to use the terrible analogy about the Titanic but the Government is just reshuffling the pack of cards and not getting anywhere. This Government is just running on the spot, and it is not even doing that very fast. That is one motive.

SPEECH.PARA: I think there is a second motive. I think the Government has been upset by some of the inquiries and conclusions reached by bodies such as the IAC and the Inter-State Commission and wants them under tighter control. The Government does not want them to make reports which are critical of Government behaviour and performance. I think the Government has worked out that probably one body or commission is easier to control than three. I think that is the second leg of its motive in establishing this single commission. After all, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has boasted that the Reserve Bank of Australia does what he tells it to. I suppose he will now boast that the Industry Commission does what he tells it to. I am sure he would tell it not to come to any conclusions critical of total inaction by the Government. Anyone who examined what was going on in our industry and in our attempts at micro-economic reform would have to say that this Government is doing almost nothing except talk. It does a great deal of that, but there is no serious action.

If we approve this Bill, three bodies will be merged into one. Two of them are really very small. The Inter-State Commission has a staff of 18 and the Business Regulation Review Unit, which has already been absorbed into the IAC, had a staff of only 6. The IAC is by far the largest of the three bodies, with a staff of over 200. One matter must be dominant when one looks at this-the urgent need in this country for micro-economic reform and the need for that to happen quickly. People must not just talk about it. A few months ago the Treasurer said that every galah in the pet shop was saying `micro-economic reform'. Maybe the galahs were saying it. I will not be too rude about the members of the Government by comparing them to birds-they may be talking about it but they are not doing anything about it. If we wish to get out of our current economic crisis we must have rapid movement in the area of micro-economic reform. We just cannot go on as we are, with living standards declining nearly every year under this Government and with a debt which has increased by $80,000m since the Hawke Government came to power.

By any standards, this is an economic disaster. We are not taking action to get ourselves out of this situation. The need to take action is urgent. We must improve the productivity of our work force. Australians can be very productive. Our agricultural sector is per capita one of the most productive in the world. It is in the areas where we have high union control and centralised management of almost the eastern European model where we are doing very badly, and they are the areas the Government will not tackle. Every time there is a suggestion for reform to eliminate featherbedding it is, I regret, very badly presented by the media. For instance, there is a suggestion that we should get rid of several thousand people on the waterfront who have been doing nothing, or nothing effective, for generations. That is headlined `4,000 Jobs Lost'. But that is not what happens in the economy. If we run a highly inefficient economy we destroy jobs elsewhere. If we can get our waterfront effective by eliminating redundant jobs, we may destroy 4,000 unnecessary jobs on the waterfront but we will create 8,000 or more jobs somewhere else. We must get over the idea that we must give everyone the right to continue forever in his job even though it is no longer necessary or relevant. That is Third World thinking. If we want to run a Third World style economy, which we have on the waterfront and in coastal shipping, we will have Third World living standards, and that is not what the Australian people want.

I do not want to say too much about Senator Coulter's statement. I thought he said a number of things that were true but they were interspersed with a great deal of rubbish. I do not think I will go down that track, though, no doubt, it will be debated when he moves his amendments at the committee stage. I want to give one example of the Industries Assistance Commission saying things that angered the Government and that may well have been the cause of the decision to merge it with other bodies. It is in a way the Commission's epitaph. The IAC was established to replace the Tariff Board back in 1973. Since it was established it has made over 400 reports on assistance arrangements for various industries. In its latest and final annual report, the IAC has been critical. As I said, I think this attitude might have been the cause of it being closed down and brought under tighter control of the Treasurer. The annual report said about government policies:
if we do not act now on micro-economic reform our competitive position and standard of living are in danger of decline and only significant domestic reform can prevent this.
Change is too slow. Change is often undermined by misguided attempts to ameliorate the effects of these changes.
Those remarks are absolutely true but I do not think the Government will welcome them.

I would like to turn to a particular example of a report by the IAC and its reception by the Government. In July last year the IAC produced its final report on coastal shipping, in my view an excellent report, which clearly described the problems for this country-overmanning, over-generous leave entitlements and first-class accommodation on board. On one of our new ships, for example, every sailor has a single cabin with an en suite bathroom. No other nation offers that standard of accommodation on a modern ship. The result is that it costs $50,000 per person to raise, say, a Swedish ship to a standard acceptable to our sailors. This is absurd. Our seamen also get first class air fares, first class shore accommodation, unwieldly roster systems, an unwieldly employment system through the Seaman's Engagement System, and extraordinary sick leave entitlements. By international standards, a very low level of maintenance and repair work is carried out on board.

All these rorts and restrictive work practices were very carefully tabulated by the IAC. It made a strong case for the high costs of Australian shipping to be tackled urgently. It claimed that the excessive costs and poor quality of service jeopardised growth and employment prospects elsewhere in the economy. That is undoubtedly true. We must get that through to the Australian people. If we allow these rorts to go on in key areas of the economy such as the transport or waterfront sectors, jobs elsewhere will be destroyed. Do not talk about jobs lost in coastal shipping; talk about jobs created elsewhere in the economy, because they greatly outnumber the featherbedding jobs in sectors such as transport and the waterfront.

In its report the IAC also claimed that the major reason for the high costs and inefficiencies was the lack of competition from foreign flag vessels on the coast. I do not necessarily agree with that. We want competition, and I would like to see the Australian ships providing effective competition. We have to provide competition. We have to provide competition somehow and if we cannot do it ourselves, we have to bring in someone else who will do it. What was the Government's reaction to this report? All the remarks are undoubtedly true. The Government's first reaction was scorn. Senator Robert Ray called the report `a disappointing document, short on independent analysis and riddled with minor factual errors and inconsistencies'. He claimed the report's `simplistic embracing of sectional criticisms' could poison the atmosphere of cooperation the Government had fostered in the industry. I suppose in a way the Government had fostered cooperation in the industry. But that cooperation had the effect of an extortion racket on the remainder of the Australian economy. I suppose that could be described as cooperation, but it is a very odd use of the word.

After being scornful of the initial report, guess what the Government's next course was? It called for another report. It set up a task force headed by Mr Deveson. It was carefully organised. No doubt the members of the task force are excellent people but they are all people in the shipping game. As Senator Coulter said, there were no people outside the shipping industry-no shippers, no users of the services, no consumers--

TALK.START.PARA: —No users?
—No. They were ship owners, union officials and government officials.
—Deveson in car manufacturing.

—Yes. The Chairman was Mr Deveson. But I am talking about the members of the task force, not Mr Deveson, who was in the car manufacturing business. The members of the task force were all members of what might be called the `coastal shipping club'. What we really wanted on the task force were representatives of the users-the shippers or the people in the community who are suffering from the inefficiencies of the coastal shipping system, but we did not have that. Bearing that in mind, it is not surprising that one of the task force's key statements was:

SPEECH.PARA: No member of the Task Force recommends the withdrawal of the cabotage policy.

That is the reservation of Australian coastal trade to Australian flag ships. As I said, that is hardly surprising, bearing in mind the composition of the task force. The Government's criticisms have been responded to by the IAC in its final annual report, by pointing out that the Government really wants to keep its friends happy. Yes, it would like to improve efficiency in coastal shipping, but it wants to reserve coastal shipping for Australian ships. The IAC response to this is as follows:
Continuing exclusion of foreign competition means that there is little ongoing incentive for domestic ship operators to keep pace with efficiency improvements abroad.

We are not talking about flag of convenience ships or ships from low wage countries: we are not matching up to the performance of ships from countries as rich or richer than we are with as high, or higher, standard of living than we have. We do not effectively compete with them. Because of that they are not allowed to operate on the Australian coast. The IAC report goes on to say:
Moreover, the absence of foreign competition removes one of the disciplines for ensuring that the cost savings from reduced crewing levels are passed on to users and the community generally.

Senator Stone mentioned that. The reduced costs go to the shipping company or perhaps the seamen's union; they are not passed on, as they should be. If we want to be competitive in a competitive world-the great majority of Australian people do want us to be competitive-we cannot afford to go on like this. Our freight rates must compete at an international level. We have a very difficult economy to run based on a long littoral, with great distances between centres of production. If we do not have efficient transport by international standards this economy will not thrive. To allow it to be held to ransom by the people who run coastal shipping is just not acceptable in this country.

The IAC has achieved a great deal, not yet in results but certainly in public awareness. It has shown people, for the first time I think, what really goes on in coastal shipping and what the costs are for the community as a whole. Business communities and Parliament had real information with which to press for real reform in Australian shipping. Even the press, which hardly ever talks about shipping matters, has been calling for reform in this area since the IAC has started to tackle the subject. For instance, the Sydney Morning Herald stated:

Thanks to the IAC, the extent of the inefficiency in coastal shipping is now properly documented; the obvious, if difficult answer to the problem is set out for all to see. The pressure will build up until genuine reform occurs.
