Ever since, commentators in other papers such as the Age the Australian and the Australian Financial Review have called for urgent attention to micro-economic reform in the shipping area by this dilatory Government.

What is the Government doing? It would claim, I am sure, that it has set up a shipping industry reform authority. It will tell people that it is beginning to reduce manning levels on new ships. But at the beginning of this year one ship out of a total coastal fleet of 43 had reduced manning levels. Despite the fact that the Government has heaped scorn on the IAC report, it will say that it is about to extend single voyage permits and perhaps even reintroduce continuous voyage permits to allow some foreign ships, in special circumstances, to operate on the coast. That is only toying with the problem. Through the Maritime Industry Development Committee proposals, the Government hopes to bring manning levels down to 21. There is little magic in this number of 21. As I said, Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries which are richer than we are now regard crew sizes of less than 18 as mandatory. At least 23 foreign flag container ships are operating with crews of 16; crews of 14 and even 11 have been trialled. Regrettably, this Government just twiddles its thumbs and talks big about what it has achieved by bringing crew levels down to 21. It is not just a case of running hard to stand still but a case of running slowly and continually falling further behind.

It is not only a matter of crew numbers, but in Australian ships 2.3 people are required to man every crew billet. This is a matter the Government will not tackle or even discuss as far as I know. Not only are our crews larger, but we must not forget that each crew member costs $150,000 a year. Therefore if a ship has a crew of five, or six more people and 2.3 people are required for each crew billet, the costs are very much higher. That is why our ships are not competitive. The reason we need 2.3 people for each crew billet is that for each year worked Australian seamen have 338 days of holiday. That might sound not unreasonable, but do not forget that we are an internationally competitive economy now. If we are going to give our seamen 338 days leave, we have to look at leave entitlements in comparable countries. Honourable senators must remember that Australian seamen are entitled to 338 days leave for each year worked. In West Germany, with a substantially higher standard of living than we have, the leave entitlement is 174 days. In Japan, which is very much richer than we are, the entitlement is 90 days; in the United Kingdom, 184 days; in the United States, 216. Those are the leave entitlements that their seamen have; ours have 338. Not only are our crews bigger, but 2.3 people are required for each crew billet. If we go on like that, a key area of our economy will never work competitively by international standards. That affects our performance right across the board.

There is only one way that this can be overcome, and that is through genuine competition. Our coastal shipping is a perfect example of exploitation of a labour monopoly. Seamen have used it ruthlessly. They have pared the industry down so that all sorts of cargoes that should go by sea go by land. This is an absurd situation by any rational transport standards. Again, I agree with part of what Senator Coulter has said. We have to use our resources economically. The way to do this is to send cargoes by the more efficient transport means-by sea. This has the secondary effect of not exacerbating the greenhouse effect. We see single containers travelling across the Nullarbor Plain because our shipping industry and ports are too inefficient. That is an absurd use of our transport resources. This is an area which we have to tackle for all sorts of reasons.

In the long run, the only way we will get people to be efficient and to stay efficient, and stop the use of a labour monopoly, is to introduce effective competition. I would like to see that competition happen between Australians, as long as it is effective. It will be very difficult to achieve effective competition between Australian firms. If we cannot get it, we must be prepared to introduce international firms in the interests of the whole economy and the Australian community. The IAC, in its final annual report, states:

Exposure to competition is the most certain means of ensuring that production and distribution are efficient and that the benefits of improved efficiency are passed on to consumers. Reforms which do not embrace the discipline of competition cannot promote efficiency to the full.

Seven years of this Government have got us into an economic mess, and we have to tackle a few things seriously. Competition is one thing. Another matter which the Government will not tackle is privatisation of inefficiently run government organisations-not because private monopolies are better than government monopolies; although I think they are a bit, but not much. We must privatise to improve competition. That must be the purpose. We urgently need a total reform of our industrial relations system and work practices. As I said, Australians can be the most productive people in the world per capita, but in the areas which the IAC has been looking at, particularly the waterfront and coastal shipping, our performance is dismal. It is in the interests of all Australians and of the whole Australian economy that these should be tackled quickly and effectively.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Industry Commission Bill. Over the past 16 years, the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) has produced some 400 reports for governments on restructuring arrangements for individual industries in the primary and manufacturing areas. It is now the present Government's intention, via this legislation, to have the functions of the Inter-State Commission (ISC) and the Business Regulation Review Unit absorbed into the Industries Assistance Commission, putting three bodies into one. This amalgamated unit is to be known as the Industry Commission. The Industry Commission, as we are informed, is to become the Government's major review and inquiry body in industry matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not support the Government's Industry Commission Bill for three reasons. First, I believe it would be constitutionally incorrect to incorporate the Inter-State Commission into what is essentially a government-controlled body. Secondly, the Government has failed to consult at any stage with the Inter-State Commission with regard to the amalgamation. This matter is referred to in the annual report of the Inter-State Commission. Thirdly, I am of the opinion that it is not in the best interests of Australia's economic development that this amalgamation proceed.

On the first point, the Constitution says that there shall be four arms of administration: the Parliament, the Executive Council, the High Court, and the Inter-State Commission. The details are spelt out in section 101 of the Constitution, which charges the Inter-State Commission with `. . . such powers of adjudication and administration as the Parliament deems necessary for the execution and maintenance, within the Commonwealth, of the provisions of this Constitution relating to trade and commerce, and of all laws made thereunder'. Specific functions are given to the Inter-State Commission in respect of transport and commerce under section 102 and 104 of the Constitution. Section 103 gives members of the Commission the same privileges concerning appointment, tenure and remuneration as are given to judges of the High Court of Australia and other Federal judges. Thus, the Inter-State Commission is established by the Constitution and its members have constitutionally guaranteed tenure and remuneration.

Whilst the Industry Commission Bill does not repeal those sections governing the salaries of commissioners, their pensions, their right to resign and the provision which says that a member of the Inter-State Commission has, in the performance of his duties, the same protections and immunities as a judge of the High Court, it does repeal the duties of a commissioner and that is where the subtlety lies. The whole structure of the Inter-State Commission is removed by this Bill, including its primary power to conduct inquiries and report to the Government. All the moneys given to it in the present Budget are taken away and given to the Industry Commission.

I warn the Senate and the people of Australia that if the Government is allowed to do away with the Inter-State Commission by the mere passing of a Bill, all does not augur well for other constitutionally established bodies-perhaps in the most extreme case, even the High Court. If this sort of logic were applied, such a decision could be determined by the whim of a government Bill. The Bill sets a bad precedent and is a bad Bill.

My second reason for objecting to this Bill is that it was proposed and drafted without any consultation with the Inter-State Commission. The structural adjustment committee of Cabinet was given a brief to look at the future of the IAC. The committee decided to revamp the Industries Assistance Commission by creating a new body, the Industry Commission. This decision was made without any briefing on the potential role of the Inter-State Commission and without any advice from the ISC itself. Only after repeated representations by a commissioner of the ISC to the Government on the matter of a continuing role for the Inter-State Commission did the Government ask for a detailed memorandum addressing the future role of the Inter-State Commission. This memorandum was completed by 21 September 1989 and represents the first opportunity given to the Inter-State Commission to make its case to the Government in relation to the merger with the IAC. So there was not much consultation by the Government with an interested body. I cannot imagine anybody in this place, nor the people those in this House represent, accepting the way that business has been conducted by the Government in this instance.

My third reason for objecting to the Bill is that I believe that amalgamation of the Inter-State Commission with the IAC will prove detrimental to the economic development of Australia. The amendment as proposed by the Australian Democrats will not help in this direction. While the Parliament has specified the functions of the Commission from time to time, the constitutional provisions were designed to give the Commission a significant degree of independence, an independence which cannot be conferred on any other body, particularly one designed by this Federal Government as an advisory body.

The special role envisaged for the Commission in Federal-State relations, along with its constitutional independence, has led to the Commission's winning the confidence and obtaining the cooperation of the States in Inter-State Commission investigations. For example, the Commission was asked to investigate the efficiency of the handling, storage and movement of cargo through Australian ports and to formulate an integrated industry plan for waterfront reform. This report, which was compiled earlier this year, would not have been possible without the active cooperation of the States.

The other positive attribute of the Inter-State Commission is the fact that it is not purely an economic research body, nor is it subject to following any government policy. It is an independent, investigative body, with a blend of economic, legal and practical business expertise which prides itself on giving practical rather than theoretical advice. In other words, the Commission has been a source of advice of a different kind from that provided by bodies such as the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics and the IAC.

The Inter-State Commission is able to take the view that some matters are appropriate for uniform Commonwealth legislation, whilst in other matters diversity is the best option. It is its independence from party policies which allows this to happen. The Government's decision to abolish the Inter-State Commission is based on Treasury's attempt to wrap up all the significant advisory bodies with an economic input into government thinking, and thus control and dominate them centrally. The writers of the Constitution saw the need for a qualified, independent body to deal with economic matters in a non-political manner. This need has not changed.

I put it to the Government and honourable senators that the Inter-State Commission has an important role to play. In essence, that role is to be an objective, arm's length body to examine and advise on matters of trade and commerce that require a balance of national and State interests or of competing State interests. It is to the country's advantage to have a well-qualified, independent body in this role. For that reason, I cannot support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support my Liberal Party and National Party colleagues in opposing the Government's Industry Commission Bill.
—Where are the Labor speakers?
—As Senator Hill says, the debate has been marked by a paucity of Government speakers, which is usual nowadays when we consider most pieces of legislation.
—Total lack of interest in their legislation.

—A total lack of confidence. I know that it would be difficult for many honourable senators opposite to get up and say honestly what they think about some of the legislation that is going through this place.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Industry Commission Bill is to bring together into one body what comprises three bodies-namely, the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC), the Inter-State Commission (ISC) and the Business Regulation Review Unit. The Opposition opposes the Bill for several reasons. Although they have been outlined by other speakers, I think they are of sufficient importance to restate them. The first point to be made is that the amalgamation of these bodies, particularly the IAC and the Inter-State Commission, into the Industry Commission is totally unnecessary. Indeed, it is damaging because it will almost certainly detract from the very important work that each of those bodies is doing. The Industries Assistance Commission, over the 16 years of its existence-and for many years in the form of its predecessor, the Tariff Board, for which I had the pleasure to work for two or three years in the early 1960s-has played a very important role in its existing structure, as has the Inter-State Commission. The move to merge the Inter-State Commission with the IAC is contrary to the spirit of the Constitution-if not actually unconstitutional.

If the Inter-State Commission were abolished it would, I believe, pose dangers to the relationship between the Commonwealth and the States because many of the Inter-State Commission's functions relate to the relationship between the Commonwealth and the States. It is one of the very few Federal bodies that have the very important role of looking at the whole structure of competition and efficiency in State government organisations and instrumentalities, particularly business commercial enterprises. If the Inter-State Commission were abolished, the question we must ask is: What would take its place in the area of the functions of the States and the relationship between the States and the Federal Government?

In recent times the Inter-State Commission has played an extremely important role in the transport industry. Its main functions and work in 1988-89 have related to that industry. In that and in other areas the role of the Inter-State Commission is very important to the process of micro-economic reform. I find it incredible that the Government took the decision, as outlined in the Budget Statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), to do away with the Inter-State Commission-a body created under the Constitution-without any consultation with the Commission beforehand. The Commission, in its 1988 annual report, which was tabled in the Parliament in the last two or three weeks, made it very clear what it sees as the likely impact and effect on the work it is doing if it ceases to exist and if that work is brought somehow or other into the larger expanded body of the Industry Commission.
It is a very unusual body. The Inter-State Commission is a unique body which was established by section 101 of the Constitution, which makes the following provision:

There shall be an Inter-State Commission, with such powers of adjudication and administration as the Parliament deems necessary for the execution and maintenance, within the Commonwealth, of the provision of this Constitution relating to trade and commerce, and of all laws made thereunder.

Section 103 provides, among other things, that members of the Inter-State Commission shall have tenure and remuneration for seven years and they cannot be removed within that time except on an address from both Houses of Parliament for `proved misbehaviour or incapacity'. In other words, as the Inter-State Commission in its recent annual report states:
. . . the intention was to establish a body not only with a significant degree of independence but specifically with that independence guaranteed in the Constitution.

Although the Inter-State Commission ceased to exist between 1920-I think it was-and its revival in 1984 that in no way is a reflection on the nowadays importance and role of the Inter-State Commission. The annual report further states:

Since its revival in 1984 . . . the Commission has advised the Federal Government on matters that have had as their central theme the improvement of the efficiency and equity of interstate transport arrangements and the development of a balanced national transport strategy and the infrastructure for implementing that strategy.

In its annual report the Commission also makes its view pretty clear on what has been referred to as a merger decision-in other words, the merger between the Commission and the IAC. The report points out that it cannot be regarded as a merger because:

. . . the constitutional position of the Inter-State Commission cannot, of course, be replicated; the institution either exists as the Inter-State Commission or it does not. Although another body could be established to advise on matters relating to interstate transport it would not be the Inter-State Commission, its members would not hold office under the Constitution, and it could not exercise the constitutional powers or functions of the Inter-State Commission, such as those under ss 102 and 104 of the Constitution.
The report also makes the point that the Bill to establish the Industry Commission:
. . . ignores a number of differences between the Industries Assistance Commission and the Inter-State Commission. Among the distinctive features of the Inter-State Commission are
its constitutionally guaranteed independence,
its blend of expertise, spanning business, economics and law-
in relation to the IAC I believe that there is a blend of experience as well; nevertheless there is a very unusual blend within the Inter-State Commission-
its orientation towards practical solutions.
The report makes a point that I think is very important. It states:

The Inter-State Commission has provided the Federal Government with advice of a nature different from that provided by the various economic research bodies. The location of the Industry Commission in the Treasury portfolio will give that body an essentially economic policy-making focus.

Of course it will. Therefore, the blend of different experiences and qualities that are now existent in the Inter-State Commission will naturally, if not on day one, with the early effluxion of time, be lost in the larger proposed Industry Commission. It is absolutely clear from the report of the Inter-State Commission that it believes that the Government's proposal contained in the Industry Commission Bill, the subject of this debate, is a bad decision.

Appendix II to the annual report of the Inter-State Commission is a summary of a lengthy memorandum that the Commission prepared earlier this year exploring the possible future role of the Commission. It is worth quoting paragraph 10 of Appendix II which sums up the Inter-State Commission's view. It states:

The conclusion of the memorandum is that the Inter-State Commission is a unique body whose constitutional status and potential has not been well understood. Since its revival in 1984 it has won a reputation for making balanced and practical assessments of socio-economic problems facing government. Having the confidence of industry and the States, it has considerable potential to develop its intended role in enhancing the functioning of the federal system.

I believe that the case against the Government's proposal contained in the Industry Commission Bill which we are debating almost rests with that paragraph. I have heard not one significant criticism of the Inter-State Commission in the last two or three years.

I know that a few years ago people on this side of the Parliament had very considerable doubts about whether the Inter-State Commission should be revived. I remember being part of that debate in the mid-1970s. The experience that has been gained since the revival of the Inter-State Commission in 1984 has been very positive and worthwhile. Because I think it is a retrograde step, I very much regret that the Government is now proposing in effect, to wipe out the value that has been so clearly demonstrated by the activities and the work of the Inter-State Commission in the last five years. That Commission still has very important work on its plate in the transport area and especially in the area of waterfront reform. From my understanding there seems to be no obvious surety that that very important work will continue if this Bill goes ahead.

The Bill also proposes to merge the Business Regulation Review Unit with the IAC. In the Opposition's view that also would be a retrograde step. The Business Regulation Review Unit, very ably led by Dr Allan Moran, has done an excellent job in reviewing and reporting on business regulations. It has a very healthy approach to its tasks. It, too, is a most important part of the machinery to resist the excesses of regulatory government and to assist in fostering a more competitive environment for business to work within by helping cast aside the bureaucratic, regulatory red tape with which we all seem to be near terminally afflicted nowadays. It is no wonder that the long-suffering business sector of the economy is struggling, no wonder its efficiency is not what it should be; no wonder productivity growth in this country is amongst the very lowest in the Western world when we look at what we do to impose regulations, restrictions and hobbles on the business sector.

The Business Regulation Review Unit is one of those very special units of government that has played a very important role and that has a great potential future role to play in helping fight the tide of government regulation. The Bill proposes, as the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) said in his second reading speech, that we would not lose the Business Regulation Review Unit because there would be an office of business regulation, or something like that, created within the Industry Commission. There is no doubt in my mind, and in the Opposition's mind, that to submerge the Business Regulation Review Unit within a much larger organisation would be to guarantee almost certainly the crippling of its capacity to carry out its important role efficiently. For these very good and valid policy and administrative reasons, the Liberal and National parties are opposing the Industry Commission Bill 1989.

There are very few sensible rational arguments that can be used to justify the Government's proposal. One is left with the almost inevitable conclusion that the real reasons why the Government has brought forward this Bill is to divert attention from its abject failure to institute meaningful micro-economic reform during its period of government. Despite all the rhetoric and despite all the ballyhoo, when one asks what has actually been achieved in the area of micro-economic reform, the answer is virtually nothing.

The failure of the Government to institute meaningful reform in those areas, which we all know and which the Government itself said in 1987 is the key to the future of the economy, has been a vital reason for the failure of the Australian economy to come to grips with its role and necessary functioning in an increasingly competitive world. At the time of the 1987 election, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) went around trumpeting that micro-economic reform was going to be the task for the new incoming government. The Treasurer was going to be the superman of economic reform. He rolled our friend Senator Button, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, who held the IAC under his wing, where it had been for a long time.

TALK.START.PARA: —He hadn't done much with it, either.

—He had not done much with it, that is absolutely true. But we were going to have superman Keating come along and grab the IAC and shake it up. It was going to be the major vehicle for micro-economic reform. It has not been. In saying that, I am not being critical of the IAC as much as I am of the Government, because I think the IAC, in its present form, has played an important role over the last 16 years. It has provided some 400 reports on assistance for particular industries. More recently, and more productively, IAC inquiries have extended to measures impelling adjustment on all sectors of the economy. The annual reporting of the IAC has been a very important function, because through it the Commission has indicated the trends it has monitored in the overall structures of assistance, particularly in the agricultural and manufacturing sectors. The latest annual report of the IAC provides an excellent example of the work that it has been doing in identifying industry performance measures which would increase gross national product by at least $16 billion, or something like $1,600 per household income per annum. I will come back to this a little later if time permits. That work being done by the IAC cannot, as I said, mask the Government's complete lack of intestinal fortitude when it comes to taking the tough decisions in the key areas of micro-economic reform: transport, shipping, the waterfront, telecommunications and the labour market, to name the most important-although this is by no means a complete list.

SPEECH.PARA: One has to ask why there has been such a lack of progress. Two overwhelming reasons seem to stand out. The first reason why there has been such a lack of progress under this Government is that this Government is unequivocally a captive of the leadership of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). This is not a Hawke-Keating Government; it is a Hawke-Keating-Kelty Government. If recent events are any guide, we can now add another name to it-it is a Hawke-Keating-Kelty-Abeles Government. That is something that is of very considerable concern, because some of those main players are not elected representatives of the people. If we are going to have a situation in which government in this country-including the whole question of economic policy and economic reform-is dictated to by the ACTU, as it has been now for seven years, it is no wonder we are having the continuing and deepening problems that we are facing as an economy in an internationally competitive and difficult world. No wonder we are not getting anywhere with measures to produce efficiency in government business enterprises; for example, looking seriously at the sale of those enterprises to the private sector. No wonder we are not doing anything about Telecom's first phone monopoly. No wonder we are not doing anything about allowing some foreign competition into our coastal shipping arrangements. One could go on and on with what we should be doing in those areas and what is abjectly not being done.

Last week the IAC produced three excellent reports on the situation in some of the major industries at which it has been looking. The headlines that those reports occasioned in the press provide very salutary reading because they are fairly accurate reflections of what those three reports have been saying about the whole of the service industry sector and other sectors as well. The services sector collectively occupies something like three quarters of our total economy. The headlines state, `IAC hits Keating's ``faltering reform'' '; `IAC says competition is key to rail, electricity efficiency', and the article says the IAC finds that precious little is being done in those areas; `Public-sector inefficiencies costing billions, says report'; `Competition the lifeblood of future prospects for this country'; `Competition being stifled by lack of movement in micro-economic reform'; `Shake-up for Government enterprises urged, says IAC report'. The report draws attention very interestingly and importantly to the failure of this Government to make virtually any moves to shake up Government enterprises through the privatisation route.

One can go on with those headings, but they are all of a very similar nature. The problems are all summed up extremely well in the 1988-89 annual report of the Industries Assistance Commission. I would like to conclude my remarks by quoting a few paragraphs from that report, because I think it is essential reading for all economic policy makers, for the business sector and indeed for the Government which obviously has not been aware of some of the fundamental problems in our community if it is going to go ahead with such ill conceived proposals as the Bill that we have before us, which will subsume the IAC, the Inter-State Commission and the Business Regulation Review Unit into some large body which will achieve none of the results that the three have done individually.
Chapter one of the annual report of the Industries Assistance Commission says in the first paragraph:

If we are to prosper, the economy must become more productive. The search for better ways of doing things must extend to all aspects of economic life. A start has been made in a number of areas but there is still much to be done.
In relation to the services sector the report states:
Within the services sector-
which accounts for three-quarters of total economic activity-

some priority areas stand out. For instance, an efficient transport sector is essential because of our global isolation, the location of our natural resources and the dispersion of our major population centres.
The report also states:

Information collected by the Commission . . . indicates that the removal of major inefficiencies in domestic water transport, international liner shipping, the transport and handling of bulk commodities, domestic and international aviation, road and rail transport could collectively increase Gross Domestic Product (GDP) by around $9 billion annually. Improved efficiency in the postal, telecommunications and electricity sectors could provide a further stimulus to GDP of around $3 billion annually . . .
Although services sector reform should be given high priority, continuing action in other areas is also required.

It mentions the passenger motor vehicle, textile, clothing and footwear industries and other manufacturing and agricultural industries, saying that if the assistance `which will exist in the mid-1990s at the end of the current program of reductions were removed, GDP would increase by nearly $4 billion annually'. The report points out, as we all know:

Reform in many areas of the economy will not be easy or achieved without adjustment costs. But we can no longer allow these costs to unnecessarily slow down the process of change. Microeconomic reform is proceeding apace in other countries. If we do not act now our competitive position and standard of living are in danger of decline. Significant domestic reform can prevent this.

The words of the IAC annual report are words that we should all listen to. They are the most damning indictment, in my view, that we have seen for a considerable time about the Government's inactivity and inability to cope with the process of micro-economic reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have no policies.

—The Government has no policies, as my colleague Senator Stone says. It is interesting to note that this is the second major statutory body that has made damning indictments of the Government's approach to economic policy in recent times. The annual report of the Reserve Bank of Australia, which was brought down two or three months ago, attracted much debate and attention in this chamber. We are seeing a government that has said one thing-in this case that micro-economic reform will be the salvation of the world-but has failed abjectly to institute any reform in that area. The Treasurer himself, having two years ago placed it at the top of the requirements for the future of this country, is now saying that it is small beer. Nothing could be a more accurate description of the Government's inability to tackle the tasks really facing this country. The Industry Commission Bill, in my view, will make the tasks, which we all accept to be very difficult, much more difficult to tackle and to deal with. For that reason I join other speakers in opposing this Bill.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleague Senator Short and my colleagues on this side of the chamber generally. Senator Short has given an outline of the reasons the Opposition is opposing the creation of this new body, the Industry Commission. I want to add what I believe to be some significant points. It seems to me clear that the creation of the Industry Commission is a stunt by a Government which set out clearly to destroy the capacity of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) to carry out its proper functions. This Government had a total lack of coherent micro-economic measures aimed at fixing the very basis of the problems that are besetting Australia, problems that this Government has, in fact, helped create. It is in this environment that the Government has studiously ignored the great bulk of the recommendations in the Inter-State Commission report into wharves, transport to and from the coast, and so-on. In this sort of environment the Government has pulled a stunt out of its hat to be seen to be doing something about micro-economic reform. This sort of total facade is encapsulated in the nonsensical proposal to create out of various bodies one body which will be-surprise, surprise-under the direct control of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Inter-State Commission was independent. It had a responsibility under the Constitution. It had a capacity to inquire into things. In fact, as I said, it conducted a very useful inquiry into the waterfront. Of course, we all know the ludicrous response this Government has made to that inquiry into the waterfront. It has agreed to pay out multi-millions of dollars to the unions and the workers involved in the waterfront, without any effective guarantee, as required by that inquiry, that the productivity gains that are so urgently needed will be delivered. The case clearly emerges that this proposal is a stunt to resolve some problems-and I will go into what these problems were-that were developing in various internecine wars within various Public Service departments in this capital, to resolve the Government's total lack of any basic micro-economic policy reforms, behind some sort of veneer of respectability by claiming to be seen to be doing something. It represents yet another attack by this Government on the Constitution of this country. I do not want to go over the top about it, but I must say that David Solomon wrote a very interesting article in the Australian on 15 November which dealt with the constitutional propriety of this kind of move. He asserted:
But abolition of the Inter-State Commission and the creation of an awesome precedent is intended to occur before the end of the year.
He was, of course, referring to this legislation that we are now dealing with. He said it was an awesome precedent. Mr Solomon noted:

Despite the constitutional provisions, the legislation purports to abolish the Inter-State Commission. It repeals, apart from 3 1/2 sections, the whole of the Inter-State Commission Act 1975. This was the law under which the present commissioners were appointed to their office.

It is a sort of rerun of the Justice Staples situation where, in order to get rid of people, we wipe out the operation. Is there a net benefit? What are the costs and benefits of doing this? It seems to me that the benefits are political only and the costs are economic in the sense that they damage the prospects of micro-economic reform. They damage the prospects of getting State cooperation in a situation where the Inter-State Commission was independent and had the confidence of the State governments, a confidence that is required if the Inter-State Commission is to be able to report on matters which, of course, affect the States as well.

This legislation seeks to abolish all the duties of Inter-State commissioners but maintains, theoretically, the commissioners. This is just a stunt. Obviously, the purpose is to get them all to resign, to go away. As I recall, they are appointed for seven years. But if the whole structure of the Inter-State Commission is removed, including its primary power to conduct inquiries and to report to the Government, what is the purpose of it? The Commission itself, allegedly an independent body, cannot complain about it. It cannot take any action in the High Court to try to preserve its presence, its status, because the Government in this legislation has taken all its money away from it. Under the present Budget, all the funds are given to the new Industry Commission.

As I noted when reading David Solomon's article, the Inter-State commissioners wrote to the Government when it first announced its plans, pointing out the position they appeared to have under the Constitution, but their submissions were rejected out of hand and with little explanation. Obviously, the politics of this matter are that it does not matter a damn what the rights and wrongs of the issue are, whether or not the Inter-State Commission is good or sound or has the confidence and support of the State governments and, in fact, the confidence and support of those people on this side of the House who welcomed its waterfront report. The political necessity for this Government to be seen to be doing something positive overwhelmed all these other considerations, including, as Senator Watson pointed out, the decencies that one would have expected when the commissioners sought to have their point of view at least taken into account.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is some kind of ACTU payback, like the pilots federation.

—Indeed. Clearly, the Government is ramming this legislation through. I do not know what the Australian Democrats are going to do, but I suppose, as is inevitable, they have no doubt done some kind of a deal with the Government. On matters of major significance like this, where constitutional propriety is involved, where micro-economic reform is involved and where major issues are involved, one always finds the Democrats voting with the Government.
—Voting Labor.

—Effectively voting Labor, and then trying to paper over their performance by calling continual divisions on minor matters, forcing the coalition to vote with the Labor Party on a whole range of nonsensical amendments to legislation so they can then go around saying, `You cannot accuse us of voting with Labor all the time because look at all the times the Liberals and Nationals have voted with Labor'. We have had that kind of phoney stunt all day today. Because this is a matter of major principle, because it is a matter of real significance to the future of the Australian economy, the Democrats will no doubt vote with Labor because they have no major concern about such matters, let alone any basic understanding of them. As David Solomon says, when this legislation goes through:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government . . . will have demonstrated the apparent, if not real, meaning of the Constitution can be subverted by a government that has sufficient will.

One could hardly accuse David Solomon of being a friend or supporter of the coalition, but here he is saying that this legislation demonstrates that the apparent, if not real, meaning of the Constitution can be subverted by a government that has sufficient will. Quite frankly, the Opposition will not be a party to subverting the Constitution in this way. I will not go to the extent of saying that it will be the Inter-State Commission this year and the High Court next year, although some people are making that point.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is that danger.

—Yes. What is happening now is, clearly, a subversion of the Constitution. No doubt that is one of the reasons the Democrats might find it a useful thing to support. David Solomon says in this article:

SPEECH.PARA: The Inter-State Commission could have, and probably should have, a continuing role in investigating federal issues such as transport and interstate trade. To date, it has suited the Government to ignore its recommendations, including those proposing national drivers' licences.
But the Government's decision to abolish the commission is not based on what it has done or might do. It seems, rather, to be based on Treasury's attempt-
that is, the Department of the Treasury-
to wrap up all the significant advisory bodies with an economic input into Government thinking, and to control and dominate them.

That is a matter of major concern. It is vital that governments have a range of independent advisory input as well as the sort of input that should come from a proficient, competent bureaucracy. We can see what this Treasurer (Mr Keating) has done to the IAC in the years that it has taken over the IAC from the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. It has not simply blunted the IAC as an instrument, as a weapon, of economic reform. It has darn near destroyed the IAC. What sorts of internal battles were involved we can only speculate about, although many journalists have written of the heat in Cabinet discussions and of the warmth of the personality battles, that have gone on, in particular, as I understand it from reading the media, personality battles between Senator Button, for example, and the Treasurer. There is no doubt that this Government's inability to come up with coherent micro-economic reform is because of these internal wars for which the Labor Party has been famous for years but which, by the way, it seems to have been able to sweep under the carpet in recent times to give a veneer of respectability and unity. What has happened to the IAC demonstrates the consequences of these internal battles within the Labor Party. It set out, apparently, to destroy the IAC's effectiveness.

I am very keen, indeed, to see some kind of genuinely independent advice come to the Government. The Inter-State Commission clearly is independent, and it is intended to be independent. But under this Government, bearing in mind the way in which the IAC has been attacked by this Treasurer, the IAC has not been independent and the Industry Commission is not to be independent. David Solomon makes the point that the Industry Commission will clearly be subject to strong government direction.

It is not simply David Solomon who makes this kind of point. In an interesting article in the Business Review Weekly, Chris Wallace points out that, while the Budget is bringing the IAC back from the dead, it is interesting to note the different way, in this legislation, the vital review of micro-economic reform proposals is being handled by this Government.

The enormous debt that now hangs over Australia is dominating all our economic activity.

SPEECH.PARA: Before dinner I was pointing to an article by Chris Wallace in the Business Review Weekly in which she made some significant points. I want to state them because they support what I was saying before about the Government's deliberate diminution of the status and significance of the Industries Assistance Commission ever since it came under the control of the Treasurer, Mr Keating. The article, by the way, is generally favourably disposed towards the new Industry Commission. She states:
The IAC suffered a prolonged period of drift after Keating took it from Senator John Button's Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce . . . after the 1987 election.
Mr Tony Cole is the new head of the IAC. In that context the article continues:

His predecessor, Greg Taylor, now secretary of the Department of Employment, Education and Training, lasted less than a year in the job, during the worst of the IAC's period in the bureaucratic wilderness.

I stress that the Industries Assistance Commission, a commission with a vitally significant role to play in restructuring this country, as a result of deliberate Government policy has been in the bureaucratic wilderness for the last two years. Is it any wonder that the Government is so hopelessly incompetent in the area of micro-economic reform when its major instrument has been deliberately sabotaged by this Government and is only now being resuscitated by the creation of this new body so the Government can be seen to be doing something about micro-economic reform when, in fact, it has not only done nothing, it has also destroyed the effectiveness of one of its major weapons. Chris Wallace further states:

Initially, Keating pursued his micro-economic reform program without much recourse to IAC resources. Perceptions of the Commission's power and significance slid as it was obviously bypassed in the policy-making process, and many good staff left.

It was a text book example of bureaucratic infighting. One can ask why the Treasurer set out to do this. It may have been because the recommendations that the IAC was making were embarrassing not simply to the Government, but also to the Australian Council of Trade Unions, which controls the Government-that is the essence of it. If we look at the recommendations in its report on coastal shipping, we see that the ACTU would obviously not like them.

TALK.START.PARA: —They said they wouldn't have a bar of it.

—It is exactly as Senator Stone interjects. The clear and worrying question is: Why did the Government set out to sabotage the IAC when, theoretically, it was what the Government desperately needed if it was fair dinkum about micro-economic reform? We get the answer again and again-it covers so many areas-`Because the ACTU didn't like it'. What will we have in its place in this new Industry Commission? We will have something that will do as it is told. That clearly emerges. In fact, in Chris Wallace's article, which emerged out of an interview with Mr Tony Cole, who is the new head of this body, the following point is made:

SPEECH.PARA: Keating lost the battle to fold into the new body more of his Cabinet colleagues' departmental research bureaus,-
but this is the important bit-

but he won the war by ensuring that all big research projects would need prior approval from Cabinet's structural adjustment committee. Cole believes that the approval mechanism will keep the various departments from counter-productive duplication of inquiry efforts.

In other words, it will be under simple and direct control; so much for the independence that is required of proper examination and proper advice to a government on this major matter of departmental restructuring which is so essential. The article continues:
Cole believes that the approval mechanism will keep the various departments from counter-productive duplication of inquiry efforts.
In other words, it is to stop people and other departments from disagreeing with Paul Keating. The article states:

As one government source puts it, the IC has to be prepared to fashion the bullets for reformers to fire at vested interest groups: `It has to package its message in a way that is acceptable to politicians, and can be used by them in public debate.'

The only politicians who are getting their advice under this Government's proposals are Government politicians. What is being admitted here is that this new body is simply to fashion bullets that the Australian Labor Party particularly wants to serve its own purposes. They generally are purposes that must fit in with what Simon Crean of the ACTU says.

TALK.START.PARA: —He doesn't say much these days actually; it is mainly Bill.

—It may be Bill Kelty, yes; Simon has now decided to become a politician with less power than he has as an ACTU politician, where he has real power. It is now Bill Kelty who is allowing the Government to do what it is doing in this area. It is a lot less than the Government had the capacity to do under the old arrangements where there was genuine independence for the Inter-State Commission. The article continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Cole is acutely aware that he must stimulate the IC to evolve in that direction. `The IAC has been criticised over the years for being too pure, effectively taking a view that as soon as they'd signed off a report that was the end of it . . .

One would think that an advisory body should be free to be pure, that it should not, in fact, be required to fashion its bullets in a way that suits the politicians and the political objectives of those politicians. The article goes on:
The IAC's failure to fulfil Keating's expectation lies partly with the commission itself, and partly with Treasury, which has been slow to share its monopoly over policy advice to him.

That is to Mr Keating. I quoted from those articles to indicate how clearly this Government has set out to damage the IAC, to limit its capacity to be a useful contributor to the micro-economic reform debate. Honourable senators will notice that whenever any organisation such as this comes up with clear attacks on the Government it gets either killed off or massively restructured. We have an article in today's Australian Financial Review headed `Willis labels IAC shipping criticism as ``unfair appreciation'' '. Naughty IAC. It has been vaguely critical of the Government. My goodness me. It has to go!

TALK.START.PARA: —Give them a smack in the mouth.

—Yes, smack it on the hand, submerge it into a new body, and make certain that it does what it is told in future. As that article says, it has to fashion bullets that happen to suit. It has to package its message in a way that is acceptable to politicians-to Labor politicians, to the Government. That is simply not good enough. Mr Willis's attack on the IAC is ludicrous. I understand that his own Department, or at least government bodies of some kind, held up this IAC report for some months, so naturally when the report eventually came out it was a little behind the times in what had happened in some aspects of Australian shipping. But there is no doubt that the progress already made by the industry, which Mr Willis is boasting about, is massively inadequate if we are going to match what is happening overseas. It is interesting that the annual report of the IAC quite strongly outlines the failure to go far enough. The Australian Financial Review quotes Mr Willis as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if the Government had opted to allow foreign shipping into Australia, shipping would have been less costly-
that is a great concession-
but disruption of Australian shipping and transport would have resulted, ``and there would not have been the kind of growth in the Australian shipping industry that we are now seeing''.

If we are having growth in an industry which is relatively inefficient, which adds massive costs to Australian producers, which helps worsen our balance of payments, why on earth should we be welcoming this growth? It seems to me that Mr Willis has not the faintest idea about what is in Australia's best interests. He certainly does not understand the benefits of micro-economic reform as pointed out in the annual report of the Industries Assistance Commission. This report outlines the extent to which the IAC has done inquiry work that has revealed major inefficiencies, particularly in the services sector, for example shipping. The report says:
As services account for three-quarters of economic activity and are embodied in all of our internationally traded goods, removal of these inefficiencies should get very high priority.

. . . an efficient transport sector is essential because of our global isolation, the location of our natural resources and the dispersion of major population centres. It will be much harder to improve our trading performance if we maintain transport systems which unnecessarily inflate costs or delay the delivery of goods and services.
It goes on:

. . . the removal of major inefficiencies in domestic water transport, international liner shipping, the transport and handling of bulk commodities, domestic and international aviation, road and rail transport could collectively increase gross domestic product by around $9 billion annually.
That is, of course, to the benefit of all Australians. It goes on:
Improved efficiency in the postal, telecommunications and electricity sectors-
all basically Federal or State government monopolies-
could provide a further stimulus to GDP of around $3 billion annually.

Collectively, reforms in the areas that the report outlines could increase gross domestic product by around $16 billion and average household income by more than $1,600 each year. In other words, there is massive benefit to emerge from micro-economic reform. This Government has destroyed the effectiveness of one of its major bodies-the IAC-over the past two years in allegedly having a concern about micro-economic reform. Obviously it has no such concern, otherwise it would not have destroyed the IAC. What it is doing now is simply a public relations stunt. It is creating a new body to give the appearance that it is doing something new. As I have said, what it has done over the past few years is destroy the effectiveness of the IAC. I believe that it is now seeking to destroy the effectiveness of the Inter-State Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation, the Industry Commission Bill 1989, typifies this Hawke Labor Government's attitude to the crucial requirement in Australia for so-called micro-economic reform: `Change the name of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) to the Industries Commission'; that is this Government's definition of micro-economic reform. This Bill is simply another bandaid measure by the Hawke Labor Government to cover up the fact that it has made no significant progress with micro-economic reform, which even the Government itself admits is so urgently needed. The amalgamation of the Industries Assistance Commission, the Inter-State Commission and the Business Regulation Review Unit into a single Industry Commission is only changing the deckchairs on the Titanic of our economy which is sinking in the sea of world competition. If this Government refuses to act on the recommendations of this new body, as it has failed to act on the recommendations of its three preceding constituent parts to introduce real competition into Australia's product markets and to deregulate our labour market, it will achieve nothing.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has failed to provide an adequate or valid rationale for this initiative. In the light of this its real motivation must come under severe suspicion. The Industries Assistance Commission, the Inter-State Commission and the Business Regulation Review Unit have all criticised the inadequate pace of change under this Government towards a freer, less regulated economy. They have roundly criticised the Government for its failure to implement their recommendations for reform. Could it be that the Government sees this amalgamation as a way to mute the criticism? If there is only one body from which to cop criticism-and that a body under tighter government control-the criticism will be less in quantity and less publicly visible than with three separate bodies.

Instead of tackling the hard issues of reform, as recommended by the IAC and the Inter-State Commission, the Government prefers to give large hand-outs of taxpayers' money to prop up ailing industries like Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd, the airlines and the waterfront. When the Government reintroduced the Inter-State Commission six years ago it extolled the benefits and virtues of such an organisation and there is no doubt that it has performed its job very well-too well for the Treasurer (Mr Keating) who does not like what the Inter-State Commission has had to say about his economic policies. Now he wants effectively to abolish it and replace it with another organisation over which he will have much greater control. Perhaps his own pique with the Inter-State Commission has been reinforced by Tas Bull of the Waterside Workers Federation who, no doubt, instructed the Government to get rid of it after its report on the waterfront recommended measures to get rid of the cosy union-dominated cartel which costs Australians billions of dollars.

So make no mistake; that is what this Bill is all about. It is about dismantling organisations with reputations for fearless and independent analysis. Indeed, the independence of the Inter-State Commission is guaranteed by the Constitution. These bodies have shown themselves to be more interested in guarding the national interest than in stroking the Government's ego. The real danger is that the replacement proposed under this legislation will not be able to do anything that will rock the Government's boat.
The Inter-State Commission was specifically required and established by section 101 of the Australian Constitution with:

. . . such powers of adjudication and administration as the Parliament deems necessary for the execution and maintenance, within the Commonwealth, of the provisions of this Constitution relating to trade and commerce, and of all laws made thereunder.

As a constitutionally independent body, the Inter-State Commission has been able to assess the views of everyone concerned and to make balanced and unbiased recommendations which, to use its own words `are sensitive to both industry and community concerns and to the more abstract demands of efficiency and equity'. But the Treasurer, in a statement made on 15 August this year, has made it clear that, through this legislation, the Inter-State Commission is to be absorbed by the new Industry Commission and that that body will absorb the staff and functions of the Inter-State Commission. Of course, he chose not to tell us that the new Industry Commission, unlike the Inter-State Commission, is not a creature of our Constitution and will not have the same constitutionally guaranteed independence as the Inter-State Commission. In fact, the new Industry Commission will be firmly under the control of the Treasury. Furthermore, this amalgamation ignores a number of differences between the Inter-State Commission and the Industries Assistance Commission and was initiated by the Government without any consultation with the Inter-State Commission.

The effective abolition of the Inter-State Commission also warrants the strongest condemnation, because it exemplifies the manic determination of this Government to concentrate further power in the hands of the Executive. It is typical of the corporate state mentality of this Government which recognises only big government, big unions and big business. The abolition of the Inter-State Commission flouts the Constitution, which is the very basis of our parliamentary democracy. This sets a dangerous precedent and raises real concerns about this Government's intentions for other institutions established under the Constitution. Will the High Court of Australia-the ultimate protector of our freedoms-be the next to go? The evidence for this is clear. The Inter-State Commission is established under section 101 of the Constitution, as I mentioned earlier. Sections 102 and 104 of the Constitution specify its functions with regard to transport and commerce, while section 103 lays down the same tenure, remuneration and privileges of appointment for members of the Commission as those extended to judges of the High Court and other Federal judges.

The Government's proposals strip the rest of the structure of the Commission by repealing those sections of the Inter-State Commission Act 1975 which give it the power to conduct inquiries and report to the Government. This would effectively mean that the commissioners would be without a job-a repeat of the Jim Staples fiasco with regard to the former Conciliation and Arbitration Commission being absorbed into the Industrial Relations Commission.

So it seems that the Government will no longer brook any criticism from the Inter-State Commission; likewise with the Industries Assistance Commission, which has been hamstrung in its inquiries as a consequence of its unpalatable recommendations to and criticisms of this Hawke Labor Government. To quote from the recently tabled 1988-89 annual report of the Industries Assistance Commission, `The past year has not been easy for the IAC'. In particular, the IAC expresses concern about matters such as the absence of a forward inquiry program, the referral of industry policy questions to departmental research bureaus and ad hoc bodies, and delays in making appointments needed to meet the Commission's statutory minimum membership requirements. All of this fuelled uncertainty as to the Industries Assistance Commission's future role and its contribution to the micro-economic reform program under this Government's administration. The IAC was also concerned about a proliferation of ad hoc groups and permanent agencies advising on policy, each concerned with a particular part of the micro-economy and not always apparently bringing an economy-wide perspective to bear.

So this Government is giving the chop to a body which has provided some 400 reports on assistance arrangements for individual industries in the primary and manufacturing sectors over the past 16 years. A distinguished feature of those reports has been the exceptional clarity of argument which they have contained and their general high quality. That high quality was again evident most recently in the IAC's report on government non-tax charges.

So the real agenda of the Government in establishing the Industry Commission is open to question. It is further open to question because it has failed to give this new body a very important power which was earlier taken away from the IAC, and that is the power to initiate its own inquiries. The earlier removal of this power from the Industries Assistance Commission reduced its independence. When I questioned Minister Button in the recent Senate Estimates Committee A about this, in regard to the forthcoming establishment of the Industry Commission, he confirmed that the Government would not give the new body that independence. This confirms my earlier remarks that the Industry Commission will be more tightly controlled than even the IAC has become.

If more sectors of the Australian economy are to become internationally competitive, and thereby develop their export potential, more effort must be devoted to achieving real reductions in protection. This will require greater independence being given to the new Industry Commission. It should have the power to initiate its own inquiries. The provision of this degree of independence to the Industry Commission, by enhancing the transparency of our protection regime, will also strengthen our arguments against those countries such as Japan, the United States of America, and the European Community whose current behaviour with regard to international trade is both irrational and undesirable. Indeed, those countries would be hard pressed to avoid instituting similar independent analyses of their own policies if we did give the capacity to the Industry Commission to initiate its own inquiries. The Government's failure to do so merely underlines that the Hawke Government's attempts at reform of protection are half-baked and timid. The Government's statement in May of last year on micro-economic reform has been falsely touted as fundamental and far-reaching change. Unfortunately, for the people of Australia it has now been shown to be sadly failing in its original agenda.

The Government's so called tops down tariff reform has made industry protection even more haphazard and contradictory. It involves an average cut in protection of 20 per cent stretched out over four years. The Government lacked the nerve to slash tariffs across the board. Perhaps it was chastened by the Whitlam Government's experience when it slashed 25 per cent of tariffs in 1973 and was wrongly blamed for creating unemployment as a result when really the unemployment was created by a wages explosion. The resulting tentative and inadequate attempts at reform have resulted in the creation of at least as many unjustified anomalies in the system as has been rectified. There was a strong case for cutting the protection of highly subsidised industries. But this is not what the Government did. To the contrary, it specifically exempted the worst example of protection and featherbedding from its cuts.

The Hawke Government's attempts at tariff reform have done far too little and have done it far too slowly. Just as protection should never be given selectively, so it should never be taken away by the same method. The best way to help industries become more efficient and assist marginal producers to become more efficient is to cut across the board-not selectively. Most recently, the Garnaut report reinforces all that the Industries Assistance Commission and the Inter-State Commission have said. Garnaut has made it clear that the pace of reform must move far more quickly if Australia is to take advantage of its geographic position in relation to Asia. His report challenges Australia to take up these geographic and economic challenges for the benefit of all industries and, of course, all Australians-in particular, for the benefit of industries, whether they are protected or not.

Adoption of the Garnaut report could prove to be Australian's trading lifeline. It will not be an easy one to grasp and, of course, will take courage, which this Government lacks, to see it fully implemented. Garnaut identifies a loss of $20 billion a year through structural inefficiencies in our economy, including trade barriers, and through a failure to exploit the markets of Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong and China. Change of the magnitude that Garnaut recommends requires us to think about forward looking policies, not only about who can provide the greatest mortgage relief.

The massively excessive protection of the textile, clothing and footwear industries, which continues under this Government's timid sectoral plans, alone contributes two percentage points to the consumer price index. Its reduction could contribute significantly to a concerted effort against inflation. Garnaut argues that by the year 2000 all anti-dumping arrangements should be removed. He says that until recently we were the most active country in taking anti-dumping action, partly because Australia had the most inward looking manufacturing sector among all advanced economies. Export compensation is clearly inferior to a freer trade and, like other protection, in the long run is built into the cost structure of our economy so that in the end it is paid by exporters and those who are sufficiently efficient to compete against imports on the domestic market without protection.

So the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) must do more than simply applaud Dr Garnaut and his report. He must implement the report's major recommendations. This is becoming even more urgent as our failure to change causes us to fall further and further behind our trading partners and our competitors. The latest report of the Industries Assistance Commission reinforces that there has been a relatively small reduction in overall protection, especially of manufacturing industry, while, despite the extravagant claims of the Government, favoured sectors of the Australian economy remain very heavily protected. Over the past year the average effective rate of assistance to manufacturing industries fell from 19 per cent to 17 per cent. In contrast, for agricultural industries it fell from 15 per cent to 9 per cent. So it is still the case that our relatively more efficient farmers are carrying on their well-worn backs this country's economy and the standard of living we all enjoy.

More particularly, industries receiving special favours from the Government under its sectoral plans continue to receive exceptionally high levels of assistance. Despite a slight reduction, the motor vehicle and parts industry receives an effective rate of assistance of 70 per cent. The textile industry's protection has actually increased to an effective rate of 74 per cent. There has been a slight fall in the protection of the clothing industry but it still remains at a massive 158 per cent effective rate while the footwear industry's level of assistance has increased to 218 per cent. This is costing Australian consumers an extra $1 billion to $1.5 billion or between $170 and $250 per household in the case of motor vehicles and $1.7 billion of $300 per household in the case of clothing and footwear, each year.

People are entitled to know that the overall cost to them of protection of inefficient industries under this Government is about the same as the total cost which sales tax adds to the price of goods. Despite this special treatment, or perhaps because of it, restructuring is occurring too slowly to make these industries internationally competitive. For example, the Automotive Industry Authority found a lack of progress in quality control and a continuing high level of labour turnover in the motor industry-a 35 per cent labour turnover here compared with just 7 per cent in North America. The Bureau of Industry Economics found that the steel industry plan, now mercifully ended, had little effect on the industry's recovery.

But the Industries Assistance Commission not only directs our attention to the cost of protecting inefficient industries. It also has identified an extra $9 billion per year in gross domestic product which could be achieved by removing major inefficiencies from out transport sector. Another $3 billion per year in gross domestic product could be gained from improved efficiency in our postal, telecommunications and electricity sectors. These reforms, combined with the removal of industry assistance, would collectively add $16 billion per year to our gross domestic product or $1,600 per year to average household income. To assist in achieving these benefits for every one of us, government business enterprises must also be opened up to competition. Mere administrative reforms will not suffice to achieve the required efficiency.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear hear!

—I welcome the support of Senator Alston, who has been putting forward strong and rational arguments for opening up government business enterprises to competition, particularly with regard to the communications industry. So, protection continues in many forms. It is contrary to the interests of the great majority of Australians. They will be best served by improved access on world markets for Australian products which are genuinely competitive and for which we have a comparative economic advantage.

SPEECH.PARA: The influencing of the trade policies of countries such as Japan, the United States and the European Community will be of major importance in achieving that access for those products which are competitive. Our capacity to influence the policies of those countries will be significantly reduced if our own house is not in order. Continuing excessive levels of protection demonstrate that our own house is clearly not in order. But the capacity to influence the policies of other countries is not the only reason for putting our house in order by reducing protection. Unilateral action to reduce protection in a more significant way will reduce the cost burden which this protection imposes on our efficient industries-both primary and secondary-which are now competitive on world markets. It will allow those industries to generate the national income and economic growth for Australia of which they are capable. It will also impose greater discipline in the area of wages policy and government expenditure, which, in turn, will further increase the competitiveness of exporters. In turn, that will benefit all Australians through the generation of higher real incomes through greater productivity.

In conclusion, it is the inadequate record of this Government in proceeding to implement with sufficient rapidity the well researched, rational and viable recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission and the Inter-State Commission which leads the Opposition to suspect the motives behind this legislation and to oppose it. If, as it appears, the legislation passes with the support of the Australian Democrats despite our opposition, then I put the Government on notice that I, in particular, and, I am sure, my Opposition colleagues such as Senator Alston and Senator Stone, will be watching very closely to ensure that there is no interference with the operation of the new Industry Commission. If it is allowed to operate as it should, I will also be watching closely to see whether the Government improves its response rate to the sort of recommendations which I would expect to come forward from the new Industry Commission. Judging by this Government's recent record, I will be watching in vain and I will have to wait for the election of a coalition government, which thankfully now is not far away, to see the pace of change in areas of micro-economic reform and protection increase to the extent required to ensure an adequate standard of living for all Australians in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not heard the entire second reading debate. In fact, I heard very little of it.
—You were lucky.

—Senator McKiernan tells me I am lucky. I am quite willing to believe him. From the little I have heard and from what I have been told, the Opposition has postulated that the Inter-State Commission is a very important body, the continuing existence of which is indispensable to the continuity of liberal democratic government in Australia. Those of us who have been in politics for any considerable length of time have a fairly high tolerance for humbug, but that has been sorely tested by the Opposition's attitude to the Industry Commission Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that there is provision in the Constitution for an interstate commission. That remained dormant for 74 years. In 1975 the Whitlam Government, for better or worse, passed through the Parliament an Inter-State Commission Act. For more than seven years that was then sat upon by the then coalition Government and not proclaimed. It was finally proclaimed, again for better or worse, in 1983 by the present Government. Because of the Opposition's humbug and hypocrisy it should be put on the record that those opposite, who were in government for most of the 74 years when this constitutional provision was inoperative, sat on it without proclaiming it for more than seven years after the legislation had been passed. TALK.START.PARA: —What was wrong with the IAC? Tell us that.

—Whereas, of course, the policy Senator Alston's party, the Liberal Party, had followed for decades-and I see no convincing evidence that it has changed-allowed the National Party to stand over the Liberal Party and determine industrial policy in a pork-barrelling manner. TALK.START.PARA: —The fact that we are debating the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1989, and the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 just three weeks before Christmas is a testimony to the bad planning and the confused administration that typifies this Government's legislative program. This is made worse by the fact that two of these Bills, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989 and the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1989, contain extremely important taxation measures which demand serious and considered parliamentary debate.
—You haven't got the Minister here to participate.
