—We will see how well the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) takes it.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—What is even more inexcusable than the fact that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and Minister representing the Treasurer is not here to take the legislation himself is that the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) was introduced into the House of Representative in May of this year, seven months ago; yet, when it came on for debate in the other place, seven months late so to speak, the Government used its numbers at that time-
—They gagged it.

—As Senator Michael Baume has just said, the Government used its numbers to gag it through. The Government brutally put the guillotine on it and shoved it through, if I recall correctly, without its even being debated in committee. It is a disgrace and a travesty of the legislative process. It is an affront to parliamentary democracy and highlights the genuine hypocrisy of a government that has been bleating for months about the state of affairs in Queensland, for example. Such obviously curtailed parliamentary debate is a curtailment of democracy.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to begin my discussion of these three Bills by first disposing of the least of them, the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989. I could spend a deal of time no doubt discussing the merits and nuances of that Bill, but priorities demand that I allocate most of my speaking time to the other two more contentious Bills. The Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill (No. 2) gives the force of Commonwealth law to protocols recently entered into and which amend the existing comprehensive double taxation agreements between Australia and Singapore on the one hand, and Australia and France on the other. The legislation also seeks to give equal force of law to comprehensive double taxation agreements between Australia and Papua New Guinea, and also between Australia and Thailand, covering all forms of income flowing between Australia and those countries. The coalition parties do not oppose this Bill.

Let me come now to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) which introduces a host of changes to the taxation laws of this country. I will concentrate my remarks on three aspects of the Bill. The first is the new system for the collection of company income tax and the acceleration of the timing of payment of company income tax. The second relates to the changes proposed to render, in respect of companies, the payment of income tax subject to a self-assessment procedure rather than to assessment by the Australian Taxation Office in the first instance. Thirdly, and admittedly a more minor matter, is the deductability of fees charged in relation to taxation advice. As the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1989 now stands, we shall not oppose its second reading.
I now foreshadow an amendment to that second reading which we shall move at the appropriate time:
At the end of the motion, add: ``, but the Senate:

(a) condemns the Government for its flagrant disregard in its taxation policies of the circumstances faced by many small businesses in Australia, as typified by its original 1989 Budget decision on company tax collection-
with which this Bill deals-
(b) rejects the Government's proposals on self-assessment of company tax because of the inadequate safeguards to protect the integrity of taxpayers''.
As the second part of that amendment indicates, we will be opposing clause 30 of the Bill when we come to the committee stage.

Small business people in particular must have been totally dismayed when they heard the Treasurer (Mr Keating), in his Budget speech this year announce the Government's proposals in relation to the timing of the payment of company income tax. Those proposals were dubbed the killer tax by the Business Review Weekly because, had they stood in their originally announced form, they would have been the killer for a very high proportion of small businesses in this country. Those proposals would have involved a massive acceleration of the payment of company income tax throughout this country, including by the 750,000 or 800,000 relatively small businesses, who do not have large teams of tax accountants at their disposal, unlike the major corporations with which this Government feels so much more comfortable. Under the existing company tax collection arrangements companies and unit trusts taxed as companies with a tax liability of $1,000 or more pay their company income tax in four instalments spread over the 12 months following the end of their income years. For example, a company balancing on 30 June would pay its income tax in the months of August, November, February and May-four instalments.

In the Budget, out of a clear blue sky, without the slightest word of consultation with the business community-not a word-the Treasurer announced these absolutely draconian changes which meant that companies, complying superannuation funds, complying approved deposit funds and pooled superannuation trusts would be required to pay company income tax in two instalments each year. It might be all right to say that they have to pay two instalments rather than four, but the king hit is that the first of those instalments, as originally announced by the Treasurer, was to be the payment of 85 per cent of the so-called notional tax on which the company would be assessed for the income year just ended-the notional tax in practice being the tax payable for the previous year-with the other 15 per cent nine months later. The company would have the option, if it believed that its so-called notional tax liability was higher than its actual tax liability proved to be, to assess for itself what that liability would be and to pay tax accordingly. Of course, if it took that course it ran the risk of finding that its calculation was in error, and if it was in error by more than the usual 10 per cent then it would be liable to heavy penalties for falsification-as the Taxation Commissioner would no doubt call it-of its estimated tax liability. That was the original proposal.

It took some time for small business people in this country to understand what the Treasurer was actually proposing for them, and how this would almost certainly have the effect of driving so many of them out of business. Having finished paying the last instalment of their company tax in May this year, those businesses balancing on 30 June would have found that, by 15 July, they would have to pay 85 per cent of the whole of their tax for 1990-91. That was the proposal that this man-the Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Australia-was actually setting out to impose upon all businesses in this country.

After some time light began to dawn-or perhaps I should say political terror began to dawn-upon the Government's ranks and it began to get the message that this was unlikely to be totally popular with the business community. As a result, it backed off to some degree by announcing some changes which would have had the effect-I will not weary the Senate with the full details-of exempting half of those taxpayers who were not already exempt under these arrangements; that is to say, half of those taxpayers with taxable company incomes of more than $1,000.

The Opposition intervened and, if I may say so, intervened extremely effectively. On the morning of 22 November the Opposition, after consideration by its shadow Cabinet, announced that it proposed that the exemption threshold, which had been announced by the Government in its first backdown, of a taxable amount of $20,000 per year would be quadrupled. On that basis we calculated that about 90 per cent of companies paying tax would be exempt. We also indicated at that time that, because there would have been some relatively modest cost of that measure, that cost should be funded in manners which we indicated, particularly by reversing the notorious Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd decision and by terminating the payment of so-called compensation to the Government's friends in the airline industry.

Within hours of the Opposition announcing that decision, the Government had made its second and much greater backdown in a statement of some length by the then Acting Treasurer, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins)-Mr Keating was disporting himself in London or somewhere at the time-virtually throwing in the Government's hand, at least as far as next year is concerned. The Acting Treasurer announced that the threshold below which these new arrangements would not apply would be increased to a tax liability of $400,000, which would be roughly equivalent to a taxable income of about $1m since the tax rate is 39 per cent and that also the so-called 15-day rule, which I mentioned earlier, would be somewhat elongated by rendering the first instalment payable, not within 15 days of the balancing date but within 28 days. So on both these points-but particularly the former; the exemption threshold-the Government, spurred finally into real action by the Opposition's announcement earlier that day, began to see some sense. That is how we have got to the point where we have this legislation before us which contains the final product of that somewhat long, drawn-out exercise.

The reason I have taken the trouble to spell a bit of that out is that it shows what kind of a government we have in this country today. We all know that the Treasurer's introduction of these measures was one of two major elements introduced into the Budget documents in order to purport to provide a tougher fiscal policy this year than last year simply by pulling forward, as this provision does, into 1989-90 revenue which would otherwise have been collected in 1990-91. That is because some companies which balance early, the so-called early balancers-Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd is known to be by far the most important of them balancing on 31 May-would have to pay under the 15-day rule, and, indeed, under the 28-day rule as now amended, 85 per cent of either their notional liability or their personally assessed liability before 30 June. On the original estimates, that was estimated to bring $885m in revenue otherwise payable in 1991 into 1989-90. That is the kind of Budget or financial juggling, financial sleight of hand, for which Mr Keating has become famous, if that is the right word-perhaps `notorious' would be a better one.

I now move on to a different aspect of this decision. The Acting Treasurer in his statement on 22 November indicated that these now changed arrangements will apply only in what he calls the transitional year. In other words, the Government's intention is quite clear. But after the election is over, which is putting it another way-he did not use that phrase; he talks about after the end of the transitional year-the Government will in fact be reverting to something like what the Treasurer originally announced in the Budget speech. We will not have this presently comfortable exemption, which the Acting Treasurer calculated as involving 98 per cent of company taxpayers; we will be back to trawling almost all of them back into the net. So if the small business community of this country thinks that somehow it has been let off the hook-I think it can be confirmed that it has been let off the hook temporarily for 12 months-it should be very well aware that the hook is still there and is being sharpened in preparation, should the Australian Labor Party win the next election, which, of course, I do not for one moment think it will. Nevertheless, I think that point should certainly be noted. The coalition will review this whole shambles when it takes office after the next election.

I also note another somewhat disturbing feature of the Government's panic decision of 22 November, namely, that no figuring was given for the actual cost to revenue of the decision and by comparison with the Budget proposal. This decision meant that the Budget is that much less in surplus than it would have been, but we have not been told what that diminution in the surplus is. Certainly, the Government has made not the slightest attempt to tell us that it would offset any such loss in revenue by, say, cutting its spending in some area, unlike the Opposition's announcement earlier the say day, to which I have already referred.

I want to briefly touch on the issue of self-assessment, having already foreshadowed that we will be opposing clause 30. There is considerable concern among tax accountants that the new self-assessment provisions in relation to companies substantially reduce what protection taxpayers presently receive under existing legislation when they make what is called in the accounting parlance a full and true disclosure to the Commissioner of Taxation of contentious issues in their income tax returns. Mr Deputy President, I am sure that you are familiar with very difficult questions of interpretation which arise under the enormous Income Tax Assessment Act which we have today. Even with the technical expertise which big companies at least can call in, companies are often in genuine doubt about how they should treat a particular matter and, therefore, the extent of their liability.

Therefore, what they do today is in effect make a clean breast of it to the Commissioner, saying, `Look, this is the situation and this is the problem. We are not quite sure how we should evaluate this in terms of our liability, but we put the matter before you. We think it should be evaluated in the following way but, of course, you may think differently and in the end you have to make the decision. If we do not like the decision, we have got rights of appeal and all that'. That matter is then, so to speak, fully and truthfully disclosed. The important aspect of that is that under those circumstances the Commissioner does not, of course, have any right to say to the taxpayer, `You have been attempting to cheat', and to impose penalties as a result.

Under the amendments contained in this Bill-under the self-assessment procedures contained in this Bill-the act of lodging a return by a corporate taxpayer is deemed to bring into being an assessment by the Commissioner. The act of lodgment by the taxpayer is rendered the same as an assessment by the Commissioner; that is, the legal process involved. But that cuts out these existing protective provisions because, as we understand it and, for example, as the Tax Institute understands it, section 169a (2) does not permit a corporate taxpayer to require the Commissioner to give attention to a matter prior to assessment.

In the absence of an amendment to that section which might permit corporate taxpayers to require the Commissioner to give attention to a matter before assessment, or at least prior to the date upon which a corporate taxpayer's return is required to be lodged, a corporate taxpayer will now have a greater potential exposure to interest penalties than he has at present and, for that matter, than an individual taxpayer would have. It seems to me that, under the legislation as now drafted by the Government, the corporate taxpayer is between the devil and the deep blue sea: he must file a self-assessed return and pay the tax that the company assesses, but he is not given any means of making a clean breast of a doubtful point and gaining exemption thereby from penalties which, under the law, can now be imposed upon him under the self-assessment procedures if, in fact, he is found by the Commissioner-with all the discretions at his disposal-to have under-assessed. That is rather objectionable-in fact, it is very objectionable.

Before leaving this Bill, I want to say that we are very glad to see the incorporation in it by the Government of what I might call the `Watson provision'-the provision to allow deductions for expenditure incurred on or after 1 July 1989 by taxpayers in connection with the management or administration of income tax affairs. Mr Acting Deputy President, you will recall that this was the subject of a private senator's Bill introduced into this place by Senator Watson not so long ago which I am glad to see the Government has picked up and incorporated into its own legislation. I wish that would happen more often; we would get better laws.

Finally, I turn to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989, which is principally an omnibus Bill but which, for the most part, includes a number of quite non-contentious proposals. The Bill's principal purposes are: the extension from 30 June 1991 to 30 June 1993 of the 150 per cent research and development deduction scheme and to 30 June 1995 of a reduced rate of 125 per cent on that scheme; and a number of other minor changes relating to the concessional taxation treatment of research and development expenditure. In addition, there are a number of minor matters which I do not think time will permit me to enumerate at length.

I will make a couple of short comments. First, in relation to the research and development concessions, the cost to revenue of that extension is to be $200m in each of the years 1992-93 and 1993-94 and $120m in each of the years 1994-95 and 1995-96, because the rate is then reduced from 150 per cent to 125 per cent. That is a very substantial financial impact. I note, for example, that private sector research and development rose from $646m in 1984-85 to $1,070m in 1986-87, two years later. That was, one might say, a successful outcome because research and development expenditure increased by $423m in those two years. But I point out that the cost to the Government, to the taxpayers, was $310m in that time. Some people would question whether that was a particularly profitable trade-off as far as the general body of taxpayers is concerned. We will be wanting to have a very thorough and objective look at these provisions in due course because it is not altogether clear that what is happening in that area at the moment is totally defensible.

Finally, I want to note some difficulties arising from the Bill's capital gains tax provisions for the long term leases of land. The Bill seeks to amend the capital gains provisions-and this is a rather technical matter; I apologise for that but it is an important matter-relating to the treatment of the premiums received by a taxpayer on the grant of a long term lease or sublease of land. Under the existing provisions of the capital gains law the grant of a lease or sublease is taken to constitute the disposal of an asset for a consideration, and that consideration is taken to be the premium paid or payable for the grant of the lease. The only costs now which are allowed to be offset against that premium are costs associated with the grant of the lease or sublease-presumably contracting costs, payments to solicitors and so on. Only those are included in the cost base of the asset deemed to have been disposed of. The effect is to treat most of the premium as a capital gain and to tax it accordingly.

This amendment will allow a taxpayer after 16 November 1988 to elect to have the grant of the lease or sublease treated as a disposal of the underlying freehold or leasehold interest in the land, but only where that lease or sublease is granted for more than 50 years on terms that are substantially the same as those which attach to the underlying freehold or leasehold inherent in the land. One can see, in a sense, the logic of that, so far as it goes. In so far as we are talking about an actual lease proposal, the logic of the matter is that the taxpayer continues to be the owner of the land and, therefore, is not, in a sense, permitted to set off against the premium he receives for the lease the cost of the land itself because he continues to own the land although he has leased it to somebody else. As I say, one can find that defensible.

What is indefensible is the situation of a sublessor who has himself purchased a lease for a consideration and who then sublets that property and acquires a premium for doing so but is now wholly taxed for capital gains purposes on that premium and is not allowed to offset against that the cost of the lease. I put it to you, Mr Acting Deputy President-and I will put it to the Government in due course-that this is quite inequitable. I can accept the logic of the Government where we are talking about a lessor because, as I say, he remains the owner of the land in question and, therefore, it would not be right for him to be able to offset against the premium received for the lease the cost of land because he still owns the land. But a lessee who has himself paid a premium to gain the lease of the land but who then sublets it is going to be taxed on the premium he receives for subletting but there will be no allowance made for the cost to him of the lease which he has purchased in the first place. That seems to be totally indefensible. In due course, I want to hear the Government respond to that matter.
I therefore foreshadow that I shall be moving an amendment to the motion for the second reading of this Bill also. The amendment reads:
At the end of the motion, add: ``, but the Senate:
(a) deplores the Government's economic mismanagement and, in particular, its record as the highest taxing government in Australia's post-war history; and
(b) calls on the Government to allow a full cost factor to be taken into account in determining the capital gains tax liability of sub-leasing''.
I now seek leave to move both amendments together.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) and the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill (No. 2) but because of the time limitation and the fact that we are debating three allied Bills which have an extensive coverage, my comments will be restricted to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5), which covers the new arrangements for the collection of tax by companies. However, before I go on to that, may I say that perhaps the only really good feature of this package before the Senate tonight is that Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) picks up my private member's Bill, which was introduced in the Senate in May and which was passed unanimously in this place. We have the most unusual situation of a Labor Treasurer incorporating the thrust of a tax Bill from a member of the Liberal Party into a Labor Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: The good news is that as from 1 July 1989 expenditure incurred by a taxpayer in complying with all Australian taxation laws will be deductable for income tax purposes. The costs of preparing and prosecuting an objection or appeal against a determination made under an Australian tax law and in seeking advice on the taxpayer's business and financial dealings will also be deductable. The allowable expenditure will be confined to payments to registered tax agents or to solicitors or barristers who are exempt from the requirement to register as tax agents but will include expenditure incurred where the relevant services are provided by employees of the taxpayer. Unfortunately, the Bill does not use my identical words in all circumstances. I think there is an unfortunate unintended consequence in the drafting. If we had an over-zealous Commissioner of Taxation we could quite easily have a situation where a taxpayer had a problem because of undisclosed interest of perhaps $1 in a bank account. This could certainly negate the provisions of this Bill if literally interpreted.

I must commend the Government for finally-and the emphasis has to be on `finally'-listening to the business community and others and making changes to what the Business Review Weekly referred to as this `killer tax' arrangement announced in the Budget and originally incorporated into the Government's Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5). The Government's constancy of change in this issue from Budget time onwards indicates to the community that the Government and the bureaucracy have little appreciation of how businesses are run.

The original changes to the collection of company tax were announced in the August Budget. We understand that the idea was from a junior Treasury official. But it was not until 2 November, almost three months later, that the Government acknowledged that it had not thought out the economic and business implications of these Budget proposals. So the grand change was made. In fact, the changes were not really so grand for most businesses. In effect, they amounted to little more than minor changes. It was announced that companies with a tax bill of less than $20,000 would be given a reprieve and an option of six months until 15 December to pay 100 per cent of their tax bill. The rules for balancing companies were also changed. However, the companies that pay $20,000 tax or less are really quite small companies. Their problems, consequently, for financing are comparably smaller. Much has been made of the relief given to small business by the changes proposed in this Bill allowing companies with an annual tax liability of less than $20,000 up to 15 December to pay the full 100 per cent of the liability.

But the relief given is very much a token gesture on the part of the Government because the Government completely ignored the submissions from the entire business community with regard to cash flow and major liquidity problems that Australian companies are destined to face from having to pay a double tax in the one year-the last quarterly tax payments from May in the previous arrangement and then 85 per cent of their tax by mid-July.

I point out that 15 different industry associations presented, in October, a unified submission. These industry associations included the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Business Council of Australia and the Australian Chamber of Manufacturers. While I and others in the Senate maintained a regular questioning of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), finally on 22 November-after the Opposition again pointed out the inadequacies of this tax in the other place and the need for amendments to this killer tax-the Government finally looked at this killer tax again and allowed a five-month extension for all businesses with tax commitments of $400,000 and under. Also, it extended by a further 13 days the previous 15-day rule for payment.

However, I must remind the Senate that these latter provisions are merely transitional. The other unforgiveable aspect of these provisions is that they were not even costed. We are constantly harassed by this Government about the need to cost all of our proposals; yet a momentous decision is made by the Government on the run and without adequate costing. It is an absolute disgrace given the amount of time that the Government considered this whole thing. Mr Dawkins admitted that these changes were made on the basis of submissions put by leading business groups-quite true. But this statement certainly indicates that the Government was previously not aware of the impact of the original tax regime on companies. The Government showed a distinct disregard for the harsh realities of the commercial world. Again, it showed the Government to be naive in its understanding of how business works.

However, with the legislation before us there will still be cash flow problems because very large companies, those with tax bills over $400,000, will still be required to pay the full 85 per cent of their tax commitment on 28 July and to pay the remainder in the following year. I remind the Senate again that this $400,000 figure is merely a one-off or a transitional arrangement. We await the Government's announcement on what the permanent taxation effects on companies will be. For these large companies to have such a large amount taken out of their cash flow at one point of time can only result in the deferral of investment opportunities and the possible loss of business opportunities. Unfortunately, as a result of high interest rates and government action in the taxation field, we have seen a decline in the number of investment decisions and in the amount put forward for investment, but consumer expenditure has continued to move on unabated.

It could be a bitter pill for many small businesses to swallow in the present economic climate. In 25 years, our economy has gone from an inflation rate in 1963 of 0.4 per cent to 8 per cent in 1989; a housing loan rate of 5.25 per cent to 17 per cent; and a current account deficit of $457m to $18 billion. Relief has been given to 98 per cent of companies for only one year. It seems coincidental, or it may be the result of unintended consequences, that Australia's largest company, Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, with a tax commitment of approximately $536m, which happens to balance on 31 May and thus will have to pay 85 per cent of its tax commitment by 28 June, will give the Government a windfall revenue of approximately $456m towards its overall Budget surplus this financial year. It is this sort of Government action that is so detrimental to the future of Australia. This Government is collecting a maximum amount of revenue under unreal circumstances and is displaying a complete lack of concern for business and knowledge of how business works.

The Department of the Treasury has extended the 15-day rule for payment by 13 days. Mr Dawkins stated that this was a positive approach. However, the extension was given not because business requirements were being considered but because of the `substantial implications for Budget revenue'. Many of the objections that applied to the 15-day rule could still apply to the extended 28-day rule for payment of the tax. It is still too short a timeframe in which to complete all the necessary paper work and discussions concerning the tax payment, especially when coupled with the self-assessment procedure which I will discuss later on.

According to the Australian Society of Accountants, with most corporations the auditor has a role in determining the corporation's net profit. Often it would be August before the auditor and the corporation's office could complete their discussions about contentious items, the recognition of profit and so on. Further, it would still be difficult to try to estimate company tax only four weeks after balance date because companies working on a three-month payment system would be paying tax before all the money could be collected. Most accountants in the suburbs have between 40 and 60 clients and the timeframe given is still not long enough to service them all. Yet the only way a business can make a proper estimate of its tax liability is to call in an accountant and get expert advice, particularly when one reads the self-assessment provisions. The provisions, coupled with the self-assessment provisions which are embodied in the legislation, are indeed onerous.

Companies with large stock inflows and outflows that bear a complex relationship to profit will find it difficult to assess their tax liability. Price sheets have to be finished and profit needs to be assessed. It is necessary for the Government to consider business requirements when considering this time limit, certainly under its new legislation. It is too late for those 2 per cent of companies. As I have said, most businesses would see a longer period as the minimum timeframe.

Under the old system, interest on borrowed funds, by default, tended to be tax deductable. That was not the law but it tended to be the practice because of the difficulty of trying to identify the borrowings. But now the Australian Taxation Office has advised that the current policy is not to allow deductions for interest on money borrowed to pay tax. However, we have a conflict because the Acting Treasurer stated at the time that the policy was under review. How do businesses know where they stand, particularly in relation to self-assessment, when the Taxation Office can go back under the revised timeframes of audit and disallow with penalty when companies in a permanent overdraft situation claim interest on their borrowings to pay tax as a deductable item?

Until now the Taxation Office has advised that in order to get a deduction for any claim, it must be shown that the claim is instrumental in generating assessable income. If companies borrow to pay their tax bill that is not contributing to assessable income. That has always been the law; it has not changed. It was more honoured in the breach than in the observance because of this difficulty of being able to identify the category into which a company falls. In all my years and with my knowledge of tax, I do not think that I could identify one particular company that has fallen into that category. Because of the new provisions, companies will certainly be under notice.

Companies will now need to demonstrate clearly that the money is being borrowed to produce assessable income or is necessary for the carrying on of the business. The proposal seems to be quite unfair. The payment of tax is just another incident of being in business. It has been estimated that the lack of tax deductability could add 2 per cent or more to the corporate tax rate of 39 per cent. It will threaten to extract an extra $650m in a full year from the corporate sector into the Treasury, adding another 6 per cent to the company tax collections of $11.36m estimated in the 1989-90 Budget. Therefore, I call for an amendment to section 51 immediately to allow interest on borrowings to be tax deductable to enable companies to pay their tax.

The Australian proposal goes against the general trend of tax law in both Britain and the United States of America, where corporate expenses generally are deductable for taxation purposes. The only exception in the United States is a penalty interest charge for underpayment of tax. The Australian Taxation Office already gets taxpayers both coming and going: late payment interest cannot be deducted and interest paid by the Tax Office to taxpayers is assessable as income and is thus taxed. The present position is not a level playing field. I believe that not allowing interest on borrowings to pay tax is an inequitable step. Businesses will need to use cash from sales to pay tax and to use borrowings for wages and investment. Cash flows will need to be meticulously planned. But can companies plan and survive the unexpected-for example, the devastating effects of the pilots dispute?

In addition, for a business which is always in an overdraft situation, how will the interest applicable to tax payments be calculated in the absence of apportionment provisions? There is a definite need for companies to be allowed to write off interest on borrowings for tax payments. Given today's steep interest rates there will be little to choose between paying a penalty, which is at a rate of 20 per cent, or paying interest if the tax deduction on borrowings to pay the tax is not allowed. If companies can survive the forward payment of tax, inevitably they will have to pass on the cost of higher borrowings in prices for goods and services which ultimately will cause an inflationary reaction.

Those companies which have to pay 85 per cent tax generally on 28 July or, in the case of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd on 28 June because of the substituted accounting period, are definitely disadvantaged when compared to those companies paying the whole 100 per cent tax liability on 15 December. In the interests of equity between taxpayers, I suggest that all groups should pay along the lines of the old quarterly basis. Senator Walsh could quite easily bring the date forward-for example, with the first payment being 40 per cent, the second 30 per cent, the third 20 per cent and the last 10 per cent-without making horrendous changes to the old provisions.

I would like to make a few comments in relation to the new self-assessment arrangements which I see as quite inequitable. Companies now have a choice as to how they estimate their tax liability: they can use the previous year's assessment or provide a new one. If the new assessment proves to be inaccurate by 10 per cent or more, a penalty of up to 20 per cent applies. Companies that are struggling may find that they will be overpaying their tax liability by 30 per cent or 40 per cent when they have to rely on last year's results because of the tight time-frames. Companies that have falling incomes should be the last ones that should be paying too much tax. They may get a refund later. In many cases it could well be too late. Thus, there is a high probability of a greater tax payment as a result of penalties incurred through what I call full disclosure and, maybe, honest mistakes. Little time has been allowed for the introduction of what I refer to as a confident self-assessment system.

Few corporate taxpayers fully understand this new process and their obligations, and they are certainly not aware of their rights. There is a need for a process, which is lacking in this legislation, which requires careful thought and consideration with regard to taxpayers because self-assessment requires certainty, not the discretion of the Commissioner no matter how objectively he administers the system. Further, companies with overseas branches and networks and companies with wide variations from year to year are going to have some problems. The possible difficulties with the Australian Taxation Office over the self-assessment procedure have come to my notice. Consequently the receipt of tax will not be dependent, as a result of this legislation, on the prior issue of a notice of assessment. The Tax Commissioner sees this as a very important step towards increasing the efficiency of the system of tax administration, as does the majority of the accounting profession. It certainly is the way to go.

Although the Tax Commissioner has indicated that he will continue to consult with taxation practitioners to establish what further changes are needed to make self-assessment in its totality work, the arrangements have not been finalised. I contend that they should have been finalised before this Bill was introduced into this place. When partial self-assessment was introduced in 1985-86 there was no consultation with those in the general community concerned with taxation. Naturally there were difficulties in the system, and it was not the full-blown self-assessment that we have here tonight. In 1985 it was a modified system of self-assessment. We have before us tonight a Bill relating to companies and complete self-assessment in terms of section 166a which, in summary, says that the Commissioner is deemed to have made an assessment after an entity furnishes a report as required, fulfilling the requirement of subsections (a) and (b). In such instances there is no piece of paper issued as in the form of the traditional assessment. However, the Commissioner is looking, I understand, to the creation of some sort of a document.

As legislators we are put in a dilemma because we do not have that document and we do not know what it is all about or what it requires. So we have a Budget Bill before us tonight but not a tax Bill. We have a situation where the Treasurer (Mr Keating) believes it is the responsibility of the Commissioner to determine the fundamental policy in relation to the administration of the income tax legislation. The administration of tax must rest with the Commissioner. There are circumstances, we acknowledge, where the Commissioner does need wider powers for investigations into fraud and evasion. In all other cases the taxpayer needs far greater rights, but he does not have them. We have a situation nowadays where the taxpayer is shown what his obligations are, but he does not have any rights. That is a complete abrogation of democratic principles.

To recapitulate, the tax decisions involving administration should always be the responsibility of the Commissioner of Taxation. But other areas involving tax decisions relating to policy-I am distinguishing between administration and policy-should involve recommendations from a wider area, or from a tax policy division. We are therefore being asked tonight to pass full-blown self-assessment, something which is in advance of what applies to individuals, and yet we are not even given an aide-memoire. We are not advised that others within the profession have been adequately consulted; we are merely told that there is an intention to consult at a future time.

The Taxation Institute of Australia advises that full self-assessment is a process which requires careful thought and consultation with taxpayers, a process which, at best, to date has occurred only partially. It advises that self-assessment will require certainty, not a reliance upon the Commissioner of Taxation, no matter how objectively he administers the law. All people associated with the administration of income tax should be aware that self-assessment will greatly improve the efficiency of the administration and collection of income tax, but there are problems for taxpayers' individual rights. While the Government believes that the Taxation Institute is supporting self-assessment-and indeed this is the logical direction in which we must ultimately move-the Institute further indicates that there are deficiencies in the legislative process before us which reflect a lack of preparedness to consult in a timely way with outside experts who are prepared to provide objective input.

It is not surprising that the Opposition has put up this amendment. We regret that it will not be supported by the Australian Democrats, the so-called protectors of people's rights, and we are disappointed that the Government will not accede to our request. We agree with the Institute that this issue is so fundamental that there should be a bipartisan approach to its implementation. We were prepared to provide an input. We were prepared to send the matter off to a committee for further evaluation, but the Democrats were not. We were prepared to pass the tax compliance and tax collecting provisions of this legislation and we were prepared to have a committee report to ensure that there was adequate coverage and an orderly development of the self-assessment system. But the Government was not prepared to help. It was not prepared to ensure that taxpayers were not going to be overridden by the Taxation Office. However, I think there will be an attempt at some consultation. I only hope that it is full and complete.

In order to meet the legitimate claims of the sorts of people who will be given advice on this provision, this issue really should be deferred until there is adequate consultation leading to the proper implementation of a full self-assessment system for companies. Self-assessment is covered by clauses 13 to 27, 29 to 32, 40 and 41, and 51 and 52. Honourable senators will note that in our amendment we have not gone as far as seeking the deletion of all of those provisions. In fact, we have just related it to one particular provision. The concept behind the philosophy is that we do not want to be seen as not supporting the principle of self-assessment; rather, we wish to draw attention to a deficiency within the system. It is not done with a lack of knowledge; it is done with the deliberate intent of showing that we understand what is required. We understand the need for the introduction of full assessment, but it must be accompanied by adequate consultation.

Changes to both the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Taxation Administration Act are needed in a legislative form to show the bona fides of the Government and the Commissioner of Taxation to consult with taxation agents and professionals in the industry, including the Institute of Chartered Accountants, the Taxation Institute, the Australian Society of Accountants and others. The problem is that, under taxation administration, taxation commissioners' discretions do not fit easily with self-assessment. Therefore, we are contending that there has to be a mechanism to ensure that the internal arrangements within the Australian Taxation Office are so rearranged as to cope with self-assessments and are fair and reasonable so far as taxpayers are concerned.

There are a number of problems. We understand that the Tax Commissioner is reviewing the question of providing an avenue by means of remission of interest payable where an assessment is amended, to encourage businesses subject to the new self-assessment system to lodge these requests ahead of their returns. But this new ruling masks a major problem with the new self-assessment program. Many tax commissioners believe that the Tax Office will be swamped with requests for rulings and will be unable to provide clarification within a reasonable period, thus leaving companies in the dark. With only a short time to go before the new system is in place and no binding rulings as yet issued, companies have no guarantee of protection.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I address the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1989 and the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, I would like to add my support to what Senator Stone said this evening about the management of Government Business. These three important Bills have been introduced at a time when the Senate should already have risen. The House of Representatives has risen. However, the Bills could pass backwards and forwards between the House of Representatives and the Senate and, therefore, the House of Representatives may be recalled towards the end of the year. It is a case of total mismanagement. It amazes me that, in such enlightened times, we came back after a winter recess of some two months, sat and listened to the Government's Budget, did nothing for the rest of the week, got up for a fortnight and then came back for another two weeks of doing nothing while the Government sold its Budget. We now have 44 Bills before us that the Government considers very important and we must deal with them in the dying moments of this year and of the decade.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to direct my remarks to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5). I will further define my area of interest to the changes in: firstly, the company collection of tax; secondly, self-assessment; thirdly, the amendment of assessments; and, fourthly, deductability for the cost of tax advice.

Probably the most far reaching measure of this legislation is the earlier collection of company tax. This measure is designed to bring forward the collection of taxes in general but, in the short term, it is to bolster this financial year's Budget surplus. This measure is also one of a long line of earlier tax collections, such as prescribed payments and the fortnightly remittance of pay as you earn collections, whose purpose is to quickly supply money for this Government's ever increasing social security bill.

These moves pretend to remove advantages enjoyed by companies in the payment of tax-that is, by the earlier collection of company tax-in the name of levelling the playing field. I thought we had a level playing field in the collection of company tax with the quarterly payment of company tax that has existed for quite a few years. But no, this Government had to do it differently. The results of this measure alone will add $880m to the Budget surplus. In the following year, the measure will bring in another $130m. The $880m is a one-off sum which will be paid by companies that close off their financial year before 30 June-in other words, by 30 April and 31 May. I understand that the companies that do that are subsidiaries of overseas companies. They do their end of financial year returns to work in with the overseas owned company.

The Bill puts into effect the collection of 85 per cent of a company's tax within 28 days of the end of the financial year. When the Bill was first proposed, that time was to be 15 days. It seems that the Government had second thoughts and extended that period to 28 days after the end of each financial year. The final 15 per cent of the company tax is to be collected by the fifteenth of the ninth month after the close of that financial year. I know that the 28 July tax bill for 30 June financial year payment can be calculated on a notional basis; in other words, the company can pay tax on the previous year's income and adjustments to it are made later. That is all very well if the income for that year is likely to be higher. The company would then pay a lesser amount than it would pay be assessment, by calculating the amount payable on actual balances. But if the income for that year is reduced and a company uses the notional system of paying 85 per cent of its tax, it is penalised by giving the Australian Taxation Office an interest-free loan which will not be recalculated again until the fifteenth of the ninth month after the close of the financial year. In the case of 30 June, the relevant date is 15 March.

The requirement that all the accounting be done within 28 days will have an enormous impact on the accounting profession. It is already overloaded. Although it is an expanding profession, it is vastly overloaded, even without this measure that will require it to calculate a company's tax liability in 28 days, let alone the previously intended 15 days. The accounting profession is already doing a massive amount of work to comply with other measures brought in by this Government requiring substantiation of figures and the increasing paperwork associated with the capital gains tax.

The capital gains tax has had quite a lot of publicity lately, mainly because the coalition has a policy to change it to a speculative gains tax when we get into government. The problem with the capital gains tax measure lies in keeping track of what is going on-not so much with the purchase of a farm, block of units or a piece of ground in the central business district of Canberra or elsewhere, but with the purchase of shares. We may buy a parcel of shares for which, we hope, we receive a dividend every year. In many cases, dividends are reinvested and we may get a new certificate every year. We might buy more shares with the dividends received so that five or six pieces of scrip may come in every year. They will have to be recorded for as long as we hold onto those shares. The capital gains tax alone is creating enormous work, therefore, for the accounting profession.

To show the Senate that I have an idea of what I am talking about, I remind it that a few weeks ago Senator Walsh came into the chamber and in answer to a dorothy dixer said that only 0.3 per cent of Australians pay capital gains tax. Probably to suit his own argument he used the 1986-87 return figures. When the 1987-88 returns are taken into consideration, we find that 64,453 people paid capital gains tax compared with the 23,225 that Senator Walsh indicated under his figure of 0.3 per cent. So in 12 months the figure jumped by about 40,000. What will that do in the next 12 months-that is, if this Government is still in power, of course--
