DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Sheep: Export for Middle East-Australian Labor Party Governments-Naval Facilities: Transfer to Jervis Bay-Rix Creek Open-cut Coalmine

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Tate) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on Australia's participation in the live sheep export trade and the crisis that has developed as a result of the refusal of Saudi Arabia to take Australia's sheep. The crisis affects Western Australia severely as some 40 per cent of the Middle East exports come from Western Australia, as indeed was mentioned in the Australian magazine of 24 October 1989. I refer to the statement by Senator Panizza in the chamber on 21 November that at least 300,000 to 400,000 export wethers in Western Australia were being held in paddocks while farmers tried to find markets.

SPEECH.PARA: Like Senator Panizza, I call on the Federal Government to resolve the dispute which is now in its fifteenth week. The return to the farmer on sheep for slaughter has fallen by 41.3 per cent since June this year, according to a report by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics. Some of this fall can be attributed to the crisis in the live sheep export trade with Saudi Arabia, which in the past has been paying very high prices for Australian sheep. With this trade stalled, prices have plummeted. I refer to a report in the Perth Daily News on 1 December 1989, which states that the value of a Mount Barker farmer's ram lambs had dropped from $34.75 to $5.30 each as a result of the Saudi Arabian stance. This article by Zac Donovan is headed `Cash crisis for sheep man'. It states:
A south-west sheep farmer will get less than a sixth of the price initially promised for his flock by live sheep exporters.
A Mount Barker farmer stands to lose $11,000 on 400 lambs contracted to live sheep exporters. The report continues:
He is one of many WA sheep farmers who will lose because exporters have cancelled their contracts.
A clause gave the exporters the option to cancel when the export deal with Saudi Arabia fell through.
The live sheep exporters continue to buy lambs for overseas markets but are refusing to pay the high prices offered in the Saudi Arabian deal.
WA Live Sheep Exporters Association vice-chairman Steve Meerwald said other overseas markets were not offering the same price as the Saudis.

The likely consequence is that farmers may hold onto stock in the hope of prices improving. There are indications that this could lead to land degradation at a time when the Federal Government has singled out land degradation as a high priority environmental issue. In fact, Senator Cook has identified soil conservation as the No. 1 environmental priority in Australia and has allocated considerable resources to reverse the degradation process. Further land degradation must be prevented.
I refer also to an article in the Australian of 4 December headed `Farmers threatened by mutton mountain'. Rural writer Paul Downie states:
. . . falling wool prices and the added burden on pastures caused by the increased number of sheep have forced farmers to reduce sheep numbers.
Some, especially in NSW and Western Australia, are shooting and burying their sheep on the farm because the saleyard price does not pay for transporting the sheep to the yard.
Speaking at the AMLC annual general meeting in Rockhampton last week, chairman Mr Dick Austen said the corporation would increase promotion of mutton on the domestic and export market.
Mr Austen and the managing director of the AMLC, Dr Bruce Standen, will leave on Wednesday for Saudi Arabia to discuss the future of the live sheep trade with Saudi officials.

Theirs will be the fifth high level sheep industry delegation to visit Saudi Arabia since the AMLC suspended the trade on August 23 after Saudi health officials rejected five shipments of Australian sheep.

The low price for mutton, the uncertainties of the market and the threat of land degradation are alone sufficient reasons for Australia to end the live sheep export trade. The deaths in transit of 30,543 export sheep since July of this year have shocked many Australians. The Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (RSPCA), as reported in the West Australian newspaper of 1 December 1989, points out that the high death rates would have been preceded by substantial suffering. This is in addition to the suffering of those sheep which managed to survive to their journey's end.

I suggest that it is timely for the Australian Government to carry out an independent review of all aspects of the trade, including an investigation into providing facilities in Australia for ritual halal killing which would meet the Middle East market needs. The review could also examine opportunities to increase, on a sustainable basis, the sheep carcass export trade worldwide. My office in Perth has received many calls, including some from farmers, expressing concern about the cruelty involved in live sheep exports. A rally held at Fremantle on 18 November, which was very well attended, restated the abhorrence of many Australians to the trade. A 1980 Morgan Research Centre public opinion poll commissioned by the RSPCA showed that 27 per cent of people favoured the trade; 61.7 per cent were opposed to the trade; and 11.3 per cent were undecided.

Many Australians question our right to be regarded as a civilised society while we condone and actively participate in cruelty which results in sheep dying at the rate of one every four minutes-and this under `normal' transport condition, not the diabolical conditions which have been occurring in recent months. In excess of half a million sheep have died in transit since 1985 when the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare report on live sheep exports was published. There have been 2,500 deaths within three weeks on each large boat-they carry some 120,000 sheep-due to the appalling `normal' conditions under which the sheep are housed on these ships. This cruelty has also resulted from a failure by Australia to require that all sheep ships leaving Australia have on board an Australian veterinarian to monitor the condition of the sheep; the degree of foreign ownership of the ships and of the companies involved in the trade with companies able to set and to vary standards unilaterally; the inability of Australia to maintain responsibility for the well-being of the sheep once they left Australia; and, finally, the deficiencies in animal welfare and abattoir standards in some areas of the Middle East.
On this last point I refer to the 1981 report by a RSPCA inspector who, having reviewed the processes in the Middle East, stated:
Sheep first drove through slaughterhouse, then were dragged back on top of dead and dying animals where they had their throats cut.

For the information of Senator Panizza-I refer to page 2901 of the Senate Hansard of 21 November-I do know the difference between live sheep and frozen beef, although I understand and sympathise with a slip of the tongue.

While I support the freedom to choose one's diet and to choose to be or not to be a vegetarian, I join with many caring Australians who oppose unnecessary cruelty to animals. In respect of animal husbandry I believe that we need to improve current practices. Certainly, we should not be condoning a lowering of standards. I believe that, if an independent public opinion survey on the live sheep export trade had been carried out in the last few months the percentage of Australians opposed to this cruel and unnecessary trade would be higher than the 61.7 per cent result obtained in 1980. Animal welfare groups, including the RSPCA, the relevant union and many others who are not members of these groups, oppose the trade.

Provided an orderly marketing system with reasonable and stable returns can be established to sheep farmers through a carcass trade, I believe that farmers would concur with the phasing out of the live sheep export trade. My opposition to the trade stems from the cruelty inflicted on the animals involved. Now that the trade is also beset with environmental and economic problems there can be no reason for Australia to continue to participate in it. I seek the support of Senator Cook, on behalf of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), to carry out a review of the industry. The recent statement by Senator Gareth Evans, also reported on page 2901 of the Hansard of 21 November 1989, that the development of a frozen meat market would be a more satisfactory way of conducting the trade is wholeheartedly endorsed by the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Briefly, I would like to take this opportunity to join with other honourable senators who have congratulated Wayne Goss, his Labor team in Queensland and, of course, the rank and file members of the Queensland branch of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) for their magnificent win in the State election last Saturday. I want particularly to dwell for a moment on the historic hegemony that Labor has established in Australia with its victory in the Queensland State election. At no time in its history has the Australian Labor Party held government in all six States of the Commonwealth simultaneously. However, there have been some three previous occasions when Labor has held national government and government in five of the six States of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The first of those occasions occurred during the period of the Fisher Government and the Hughes Labor Government-the term of the Fisher Government being 17 September 1914 to 27 October 1915. Of course, the Hughes Labor Government followed. During that period Labor was in opposition in Victoria. However, William Holman was Labor Premier and led a Labor government in New South Wales; T. J. Ryan was the Labor Premier of Queensland from 1 June 1915; Crawford Vaughan led a Labor government in South Australia from 3 April 1915; John Scaddan was Labor Premier of Western Australia throughout that period until 27 July 1916; and John Earle-of course, the history of John Earle is very well known to Senator Tate-was the Labor Premier of Tasmania from 6 April 1914 to 15 April 1916. So for the period from 6 April 1915 to 15 April 1916 Labor found itself in government nationally and in five States, the exception being Victoria.

During the period of the Curtin Government, Bill McKell was the Leader of a Labor Government in New South Wales; Robert Cosgrove was the Labor Premier of Tasmania; John Willcock was the Labor Premier of Western Australia; Frank Cooper was the Labor Premier of Queensland from August 1942; and on 15 September 1943, John Cain formed a Labor Government in Victoria but, of course, resigned his commission some four days later. For that marvellous period of four days Labor found itself in government nationally and in all Australian States with the exception of South Australia.

During the period of the Chifley Government, Bill McKell was again Labor Premier of New South Wales until 6 February 1947. When he became Governor-General, he was succeeded by James McGirr. Robert Cosgrove was the Labor Premier of Tasmania until December 1947. After John Willcock's resignation on 31 July 1945, due to ill health, Frank Wise led the Western Australian Labor Government until April 1947. Labor was firmly in government in Queensland with both Frank Cooper and Ned Hanlon at the helm as Premiers during that period. John Cain senior again formed a Labor Government in Victoria on 21 November 1945 until 20 November 1947. Unfortunately, it was still the dark ages in South Australia with Playford as the Premier. But from 21 November 1945 to 1 April 1947 Labor found itself in government nationally and in five States of Australia, the unfortunate exception being South Australia.

Labor now finds itself in its strongest electoral position for some 40 years. We have strong and effective Labor governments in the States of Victoria, Western Australia, South Australia, Tasmania and now Queensland, as well, of course, as our long term and stable national Government. It is four decades since the conservatives have been routed in this country to the extent that they find themselves routed today. Unfortunately, it is in my own State of New South Wales that the conservatives still hold government, albeit, Mr President, I am sure you would agree, a Government that is well and truly on the skids.

I believe that Labor's record of electoral success in the 1980s is a tribute to the hard work of its membership at all levels. I think it is appropriate to congratulate our ALP colleagues in Queensland for their efforts over the past few months. They deserve a great deal of credit for their victory last Saturday, and I look forward to a similar rout of the conservative forces in New South Wales at the next State election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to put before the Senate my views on the future of the Government's plans to relocate naval facilities from Sydney to Jervis Bay. In particular, I want to address my remarks to the directive of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that his Ministers should take a fresh look at alternative sites. It may appear to some that there is no need to waste one's breath on the Jervis Bay issue, because the relocation plan appears to be in a state of terminal decline. Indeed, there is a lot of evidence to support this view. The preliminary draft environmental impact statement (EIS) has been thoroughly discredited, along with the consultants who produced it, Sinclair Knight and Partners Pty Ltd. The promise that large tracts of waterfront land in Sydney would be released has largely evaporated. The only significant site to be vacated would be the Newington armament depot land near Parramatta, which happens to be contaminated with industrial waste, making it rather less attractive than was first thought. Professor John Toon, a consultant to the New South Wales Government on the Homebush area-which includes Newington-has advised against the Federal Government's tentative plans to establish a housing estate on Newington land. Furthermore, 90 hectares of Newington-roughly one-third-is already to be sold off without jeopardising the depot's operations.

SPEECH.PARA: The New South Wales Government's long-standing plans for an Olympic-standard sporting facility, which for years provided the impetus for plans to vacate the armament depot, are no longer contingent on the release of the Newington land. And no prime land on Sydney Harbour would be released by the removal of the Woolloomooloo fleet base. Even now, many Sydneysiders do not understand that there are no plans to move Garden Island Dockyard. Consequently, moving the fleet base is not going to change the landscape much, and is not going to yield any useful land to anyone.

Against the advice of the Department of Defence and the Navy, the Government included HMAS Waterhen in its original relocation plan. It has now realised the foolishness of depriving our largest trading port of a mine-countermeasures base, and has opted to retain Waterhen, and indeed to modernise it. The Prime Minister has backed away from the relocation plan, having initially been one of its most enthusiastic supporters. The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), the architect of the move, has dumped the sorry mess onto his junior Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Simmons).

But the Jervis Bay scheme has built up momentum and, despite the loss of power, the ship is still moving and is still on course. The sum of $5.3m has already been spent by Australian Construction Services on planning studies; $5.5m has already been committed to the three-year marine studies now under way-studies which are premised on the relocation plan being approved. And $3.1m have been thrown at the EIS, up from the original 1987 contract price of $1.5m-a massive 100 per cent cost blow-out. All told, nearly $14m have been committed to the Jervis Bay plan, with a Cabinet decision still many months away. While the Navy and Department of Defence are largely wary of the relocation plan, key officers and bureaucrats have built a mini-career on it. Furthermore, there is no guarantee that the Hawke Government will be a government for very much longer, and the coalition has not revealed its hand on the future of the plan.

Finally, Government Ministers have not grasped the unique nature of Jervis Bay, and have dismissed suggestions that plans be made to protect it permanently and effectively. For this reason, I want to suggest the direction that this new study of alternatives should take. This study is a golden opportunity to produce a rational and responsible plan, and to consign the present scheme to the dustbin of history. Senator Button, in a letter of 24 October clarifying the Hawke review, assured me that it will canvass `the option of retaining the facilities in Sydney Harbour'. This is the most important part of the study. Despite all the money that has been spent on so many previous studies, no convincing justification has been given for moving any naval facilities from Sydney.

There is no point in proceeding to a consideration of alternative sites until the justification hurdle has been jumped. Take the Newington armament depot, for which several key justifications have been advanced. One is that the Jervis Bay arrangement will be more efficient than the present ammunitioning pipeline in Sydney. In April last year, Mr Beazley told Parliament that it takes two or three days to ammunition a ship at Man O'War Anchorage in Sydney Harbour, whereas at Jervis Bay it would only take six hours-less than a working day.

It seems that the Minister was stretching both figures to make his case. According to the preliminary draft EIS, the Sydney process normally takes two complete days, rarely three. And senior Navy officers have told freelance journalist Rod Kirkpatrick that to ammunition a guided missile destroyer or frigate at Jervis Bay will take longer than six hours and will certainly not be completed in one working day. In other words, the time taken will be reduced only from two days to between one and two. In any case, efficiency cannot be judged solely by the time taken to load or unload a ship's arsenal. The operation of the pipeline, as a whole, has to be looked at. In Sydney, there are clear inefficiences at present. The ammunition has to be transferred from trucks onto concrete barges at Newington wharf and from the barges onto warships in Sydney Harbour. At Jervis Bay the weapons would be transferred directly from the truck to warships. However, the Sydney operation has some advantages. The most bulky and dangerous weapons, the missiles and torpedoes, are stored at Kingswood armament depot near Penrith. The distance they travel between Sydney Harbour and Kingswood is presently about 66 kilometres, 44 kilometres by truck and 22 by barge. The distance they would have to travel between Jervis Bay and Kingswood would be 200 kilometres, three times as far.

Every time a warship discharged ammunition at Jervis Bay, the missiles and torpedoes would have to be trucked to Kingswood for routine maintenance and replacement weapons would have to be trucked all the way back to Jervis Bay. This is hardly efficient. It is worth noting that there are only notional plans to relocate the Kingswood armament depot to Jervis Bay. There is no money in the Budget for the move, no timetable and no guarantee that it would ever happen, even if the relocation of Newington proceeds. There is even less interest in relocating Kingswood's missile maintenance facilities. Yet the road traffic of explosives between Jervis Bay and Kingswood could be ended only if they moved too.

The main argument used to justify the relocation of Newington is safety. Civil encroachment has made it difficult for the depot to meet the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) explosives safety standards, according to the Department of Defence's 1987 notice of intention. But, according to Mr Tony Hetherington, a Defence Department officer with responsibilities for Newington, the depot does conform to safety standards and will still do so if the plan to sell 90 hectares at the southern end proceeds. Mr Hetherington's views were reported in the Canberra Times of 2 October. The only parts of the Sydney pipeline which do not meet NATO standards are the Newington wharf and Man O'War Anchorage during intermittent ammunition transfer operations. However, the danger zones at both points largely fall over public waterways, where population densities are, of course, low.

Furthermore, the most likely cause of an accidental explosion is virtually absent at the wharf and the anchorage. Contrary to popular belief, unfused ammunition is particularly insensitive to shock-for example, as a result of being dropped during a crane transfer-but is much more sensitive to the effects of fire. But the possibility of a fire at the wharf and anchorage is very low-much lower than during road transport, when spilt fuel could be ignited following a collision.

In 1984 the Navy's chief of supply wrote that `the greatest risk' of accidental detonation `is through fire' and that ammunition is `not readily susceptible to shock'. To illustrate the point, in May this year four forestry workers were injured, one seriously, when they lit a camp fire above a buried 105-millimetre antitank shell at Puckapunyal army camp. The shell had apparently failed to explode from the shock of hitting the ground. It is little wonder that in 1979 a working party established by the Deputy Chief of Naval Staff concluded that the most likely risk of accidental detonation is during a fire following a road accident. Yet, under the Jervis Bay plans, the present 44-kilometre road route along the Western Freeway and Great Western Highway would be lengthened to 200 kilometres, including some notoriously dangerous roads such as the Old Northern Road, the Hume Highway and the Princes Highway. There would be a much greater likelihood of an accidental explosion along the proposed route than there is on the existing one.

It has been argued that because the Sydney route passes through the western suburbs, the consequences of an accident would be greater than along the sparsely populated Jervis Bay route. Therefore, the argument goes, the proposed route is safer because the greater risk is negated by the reduced carnage. Wrong again. The Jervis Bay route would pass through many towns along the way and the city of Wollongong. And the people most likely to be hurt on either route are those in cars who stop to render assistance or whose way is blocked by debris from the collision. In any case, traffic and population densities along the proposed new route are scheduled to grow dramatically, with the planned construction of an airport at Badgery's Creek south of Kingswood and a satellite city between Campbelltown and Kingswood.

In short, the proposed Jervis Bay ammunitioning pipeline would be more dangerous than the existing one in Sydney. Senior Navy officers have confirmed this in interviews with freelance journalist Rod Kirkpatrick. It would be irrational in the extreme to close the Sydney pipeline so that NATO storage and handling standards were not violated and, in the process, increase the public hazard caused by the transport of explosives. Yet this is what the relocation scheme proposes. History shows that the Sydney pipeline is extremely safe, which raises the question as to whether it should be moved at all on safety grounds. Under the current scheme at least, the answer is emphatically no. The balance sheet in favour of relocating Newington is not impressive: reduced safety, the release of some polluted land, marginal efficiency gains in some areas and efficiency losses in others. No responsible government can commit $176m to such a proposition.

The justifications for moving the fleet base are just as tenuous. One argument put forward is that increasing urban constraints are placing the operations of naval facilities in jeopardy. The preliminary draft EIS notes that HMAS Waterhen is one of the most constrained facilities. Yet, as the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (DASETT) has noted in its assessment of the EIS, Waterhen is about to be substantially upgraded to accommodate more vessels and to operate well into the next century. DASETT was also moved to ask `how Garden Island Dockyard will be able to operate indefinitely when, presumably, it will be subject to the same constraints as the other naval facilities in Sydney'. This is a good point. The dockyard is still being modernised, along with the fleet base, and is not going to be moved. The urban constraints argument is a red herring.

A variation on this theme is the claim that increasing water traffic on Sydney Harbour will increasingly constrain Navy operations. But according to a spokesman for the Maritime Board, reported in the Canberra Times, shipping traffic on the harbour has been fairly static for the past five years and is unlikely to increase in the foreseeable future. Another argument which has been put forward, including by Mr Beazley when tabling the Fleet Base Relocation Study in 1987, was that the collocation of the fleet and submarine bases and armament depot in Jervis Bay will offer advantages in efficiency. In fact, the opposite is true. As the Department of Defence noted in a 1976 study, `the co-location of'-the dockyard and fleet base-`within the same harbour is central to the efficient operation of the fleet'. Furthermore many of `the other principal naval establishments in the Sydney area'-such as training colleges and supply depots-`require, in the interests of the efficient operation of the Fleet, to be located in the same general area as the fleet base and dockyard'. In other words, the present collocation in Sydney offers maximum efficiency. Separate the fleet base from the dockyard and other naval establishments, and those advantages are lost. The only way to regain them is to move everything-dockyard, stores and colleges-down to Jervis Bay. The cost in 1975 prices was estimated at $1.9 billion. In 1989 prices, that equates to $6.4 billion-more than the estimated cost of the very fast train project.

In 1987, Mr Beazley hinted twice that the dockyard would eventually move. Clearly, however, it would be a gross waste of public money. In any case, Garden Island Dockyard has been privatised, which would greatly complicate any Government plans to shift it. Other alleged benefits of relocating the fleet base are said to be reduced commuting times for Navy personnel, and allowing the Navy to tune its radars out of monitoring range of foreign ships. But these are trivial grounds on which to spend over $1 billion of public money. Some people feel that the fleet base should move because it would be a target in the event of war. But the dockyard would remain a target, so the advantages are minimal. Finally, to move the fleet base south when the likely focus of Navy operations is to the north is inefficient and would increase operating costs. In short, there is nothing to commend the relocation of the fleet base.

If the Government decides to pursue the Jervis Bay plan, or to select an alternative site for the same relocation scheme, it will have to produce an entirely new set of justifications which stand up better than the present house of cards. If the armament depot is to be moved, a rigorous hazard analysis will have to be produced to show that the current dangers are unacceptable, particularly when compared with other more hazardous activities such as the passage of liquefied petroleum gas through Sydney streets and waterways. It will also have to be shown that substantial reductions in hazard will be gained by the move.

Similarly, cogent reasons will have to be given as to why options need to be reserved for a totally unnecessary fleet base relocation, particularly to a site south of Sydney. Much more would be gained by exploring the recommendation of Robert Cooksey, made in his 1988 report to Mr Beazley, that intermediate level maintenance facilities which do not require a dockyard should be established further north. Port Curtis, near Gladstone, could be the site of such a facility. Contingency studies could also be done of the possible relocation of storage and maintenance facilities at Newington and Kingswood further north-again, perhaps to Port Curtis. The Newington Wharf and a buffer zone encompassing the northern third of the present depot would be retained, along with reduced storage capacity at Kingswood, which will remain occupied by the Royal Australian Air Force. Ships operating in the south-east of Australia would carry minimal arms for training, supported by a low level of ammunitioning activities along this residual Sydney pipeline. They would only pick up a full armament load at Port Curtis while heading north for a tour of duty. They would off-load most of it on their way back to Sydney.

But for such a scheme to proceed beyond the study stage to a firm proposal, a rigorous justification would have to be produced. None has yet been forthcoming. For this reason, studies of alternative sites deserve a low priority. By far the most important study which needs to be done is of ways to protect the unique qualities of Jervis Bay. One activity for which alternatives should be urgently considered is the bombardment of Beecroft Peninsula, or Bundoola Place, on the north side of the bay. Specifically, there would be no loss of training amenity, or defence skills, if bombardment were practised against targets moored at sea.

The overall focus of any protection scheme would be to protect the rich marine ecosystem of Jervis Bay, as well as the glorious beaches and other terrestrial wonders. It would also seek to preserve the extraordinary spiritual qualities of the bay, which have been enshrined in Aboriginal mythology, and are obvious to most visitors to the region, but cannot be documented by science. Those qualities are threatened by a number of proposals, of which the relocation plan is but one. A coordinated and comprehensive protection scheme is urgently needed. It is my understanding that environment groups are drawing up proposals for a marine reserve and national park. I urge the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) and the Prime Minister, to give them serious consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to make some brief comments on the proposed Rix Creek open cut coalmine. The site of the mine is very close to Singleton. It is only about 1.5 kilometres from the northern suburb of Singleton Heights. The developer of the mine is a company called Bloomfield Collieries Pty Ltd. The company wants to mix high quality coal from the new Singleton mine with lower grade coal, which has a higher sulphur content, from the company's East Maitland mine. It wants to export about 200,000 tonnes per year for the first two years, and it claims that the value of the deposit is some $900m. The site is to be mined over a period of 21 years. Very few jobs are involved. Only about 15 local people would be employed in the mine.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no suggestion that there was anything improper about the application for development, but the company must have been fairly confident of getting permission because it has, I believe, already spent about $17m on testing and on an environmental impact statement. It may have received some assurances, of course, from the New South Wales Minister for Planning, David Hay.

There is widespread opposition to the mine from the local community. Those people are not what one would characterise as greenies or conservationists. They are, in many ways, ordinary members of a community that has always been heavily dependent on coalmining. One such person is Mrs Alison Howlett, who has been very active in the relatively newly-formed Singleton community group. Mrs Alison Howlett became involved in the group because she had quite serious asthma and her children also suffered from respiratory problems when they lived near coalmines at Ravensworth. The family moved to Singleton recently to escape the pollution and they are worried about being faced with further pollution from the opening up of the new mines.

The Singleton community group was set up to represent the local concerns and to examine the possible environmental impacts of the mine. They were particularly concerned about noise from the machinery and from blasting and about destructive vibration from the blasting which would disturb their peace and have a possible effect on their homes. They were also worried about the dust which is carried into Singleton by the prevailing winds, which affects the quality of life in Singleton and, most importantly, has a noticeable effect on the health of Singleton residents, especially children. The residents believe that there is a higher than average incidence of respiratory disease in the area. That would not be surprising considering that there are already about 12 open cut and underground mines in the area. In the light of residents' health concerns, a health survey which concentrates on respiratory disease needs to be carried out in the area.

The community opposition to the mine was supported by local members of the major political parties, including the local State member of parliament, Mr Bob Roberts-a Liberal-the local Australian Labor Party branch, the Upper Hunter Trades and Labour Council, and the Singleton Shire Council. In fact, the Council voted unanimously to oppose the mine. It was the first time in the Council's history that it had opposed a mine. The Council also hired independent consultants to evaluate the impacts of the mine.

In August this year I was approached by the community group who were going to Sydney to meet the Minister for Planning, David Hay. They had made two appointments in succession and both had been cancelled. They wanted to see David Hay and also the Minister for Minerals and Energy, Mr Pickard. The representatives turned up at Mr Hay's office but he still refused to see them. Although this is largely a State matter I felt an obligation to support the residents because of their environmental concerns and because I have some ability to raise these matters during an adjournment debate.

For a number of reasons, including personal family matters, I was not able to give the matter the attention that I would have liked at the time. I believe that there was also some misunderstanding that my support was conditional in some way. However, with the benefit of hindsight I feel that even had I given the residents of the area the most vigorous support when they first approached me, I doubt now whether the result would have been different; I doubt whether my support for the residents would have been successful in getting the application for the mine or for the development rejected. The development has been given the go-ahead. But a commission of inquiry which was held earlier this year and which brought down its findings in July placed some stringent conditions upon the mine. In its report which was written by Mr John Woodward and Mr Kevin Cleland, it recognised the strength of the local concerns. That report--

TALK.START.PARA: —Just incorporate it.
—I seek leave to incorporate the relevant paragraph of the report in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The paragraph read as follows-

There is widespread and deep concern in the Singleton community in relation to this proposed mine and its potential adverse environmental impact on residences within the town and on rural residences surrounding the proposed mine site. This concern was reflected in numerous submissions put before this Commission of Inquiry by the people of the Singleton area and in the submissions by Singleton Shire Council. The submissions of the Council and the local residents strongly opposed the mine and requested that this proposed mine be refused consent.

The Commission has placed the usual conditions on the mine. These relate to dust, machinery noise, noise and vibration from blasting and waterway pollution. It also imposed monitoring and quarterly reporting conditions, these being especially important because of the proximity of the town to the mine. Special conditions imposed upon the mine include that when the wind speed exceeds a given value of 5.6 metres per second, all work at the mine must cease. Special limits have also been imposed on the mine. Hours of operation are now restricted to between 6.30 a.m. and 8 p.m.

Bloomfield Collieries Pty Ltd has accepted these conditions and has indicated that it can operate successfully within the constraints. I hope that it will continue to hold this opinion and will not seek to dilute the environment protection provisions at a later date. The residents have now accepted that the mine will go ahead but there is still concern that the conditions might not protect them. One aspect that particularly concerns me is the permission for the operators to transport the coal from the mine by road. This will amount to 200,000 tonnes per annum to be carried through the town during the first two years. Clearly, there is a danger to the community on the roads. There is the possibility of quite considerable dust pollution. There will be noise. There will be damage to roads. One calculation has estimated that there will be 124 truck journeys through the town each day.

The commissioners recommended that a rail coal loading facility and a spur line should be constructed away from the town by the beginning of the third year of mining. If that is not done five times the tonnage will have to be carried through the town. This could amount to one million tonnes per annum. The roads in this area are being used because of the ridiculous situation that it would cost the company $7 more a tonne to transport the coal by rail. One of the most interesting recommendations of the commissioners was the establishment of an overview committee to monitor the maintenance of environmental standards for the community. I gather that the current prospective membership for the monitoring committee will consist of a representative from the Department of Minerals and Energy, who will be in the chair and a representative from each of the State Pollution Control Commission, the local council, the Department of Environment and Planning, Bloomfield Collieries and the local community. This committee is an innovation. I regard it as a very useful one. I hope that it will be able to perform the function envisaged by the commissioners as well as giving the community confidence that standards are being adhered to.

Some aspects of the situation are still causing local residents some concern. They feel that there ought to be more than one representative of their community on the committee. Two would be desirable, if only to spread the workload particularly considering that the community resident on the committee gets no financial support. I also think that the six-monthly meetings may not be frequent enough. It would be useful to have three-monthly meetings, particularly in the event of some urgent situation. There is also an apprehension that the local residents will not be able to contest arguments filled with complex statistical data. Obviously, bodies like the council and the State Pollution Control Commission ought to provide support in this situation and I hope that they will.

Obviously the special conditions on the mine and the monitoring committee are very much a second best for the residents of Singleton but it is a lot better than open slather unrestricted development. A lot of people such as the Singleton residents are realising that they cannot merely leave the protection of their local environment in the hands of official bodies but that they have to take an interest as members of communities. Already there are 12 mines in the community and in the new climate of concern for the environment and especially of concern locally for the apparently high incidence of respiratory diseases in the area, the residents have recognised there is no reason for another mine to be accepted unthinkingly and indeed every reason for examining the proposal carefully. All the residents, including Mrs Howlett and others, should be commended for raising the issue and taking action which initiated what the New South Wales Minister for Planning, David Hay, called the strongest protective measures ever issued on a surface mine in New South Wales. The residents of Singleton will set an example for residents of other similar communities by their energy, dedication, sincerity and capacity for organisation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.11 p.m.
